I actually spit it out to make sure I didn't accidentally bite some tin foil off. The girls' burritos were majorly lacking meat, though they had a fair amount of shrimp. One roommate is susceptible to spicy foods and rarely adds hot sauce to anything, was overwhelmed by how hot her burrito was and mostly suffered through it, though neither me or our other roommate had that issue. 

Just a bad day at Vallarta all around, which is sad because I usually get good food there.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Great taco place, not a long wait, choice of multiple salsas and open late every night (till 3:30am on Fri/Sat!!!). 

Gotta get the Suadero! You won't be disappointed!
author: Vasiliy M.

description: I've been pretty disappointed with Taqueria Vallarta lately, giving them a higher rating in hopes that things turn around. I've been coming here for over 10 years, I don't know if there was an ownership change but it's been different in the last 8 months or so. This is the 3rd time I've come home with the wrong order. Quality has gone down a bit and no shade to the gente there now but I miss the women who used to work behind the counter! The tacos are great but if you want anything else, make sure you double check your order and don't expect free chips anymore- what's up with that?! Vallarta you used to be my favorite, I'm still holding out tho.
author: Anna H.

description:
We came here on a Sunday night. The tortillas were over-toasted. However, they provide generous portions of meat.

In terms of personal preference: Cabeza was the best...and then Chorizo...and then Carne Asada. Some meats were over-cooked. I think the meat cooker is over-worked..he was sweating balls.

Service is fast. You need to portion your own onions/cilantro/sauce: huge negative for lazy people.

Price: expensive compared to CA average but normal for SF standards.
author: Sang P.

description:
I ordered an enchiladas plate... The taste was very american style...I found a piece of wire or metal inside an enchilada...I went to the counter to return it and no one resolved my problem...and absolutely they not say anything.
Y el plato de enchiladas es demasiado caro.
author: Sandra H.

description:
A popular place where the "mixed" crowd of inhabitants and transients of the inner mission, seek nourishment. Taqueria Vallarta produces a solid and "traditional" taqueria fare. Fast and efficient. The taco "bar" at the front is a shining example of American capitalism, churning tacos as fast as the makers hands can move. Other fare...  the other counter where it is not quite as fast. Order and wait. They WILL call you. Sporting tables for the masses to enjoy their taco or burrito or plato conquests, it is a welcomed accommodation for some. 

Gotta carnitas burrito, various tacos and a plato to go - it was a Delicious high calorie, high fat indulgence. Basic and good... what else could be conjured from a taqueria ? It was GREAT !
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Taco Bar.

A big taqueria that's divided into two rooms: taco bar and other Mexican plates in one room and in the other room is some tables for you to enjoy your food at. This place is a genius. They put a taco bar right at the front door and the alluring smell of their different types of meat cooking is very tempting. At $2 a taco, this place is definitely worth every penny. I definitely enjoyed their carnitas taco over their carne asada tacos.

Parking is all on the street and it's metered until 6pm so finding parking could be a bit of a pain, but just try to keep your patience under control.

Service is quick. The tortillas were already cooking when we got there so all the person had to do was add the meat into it and we got to add the onions, cilantro, and salsa ourselves.

Overall, yum. Definitely a good place to go for tacos and I am willing to come back again soon, hopefully.
author: Venus L.

description:
Damn Damn Dammit Better than most. Call me an Uber to get me home. I'm Done. That Mission Love on a plate.
Soul Food by Mi Gente!!
author: Jboogie X.

description:
5 stars strictly for the legit street tacos! 
The carnitas tacos are the best IMO! 

I started coming here years ago, when the tacos were only $1.50 each & you could salsa on Sunday's to a live band at Jelly's! *sigh* Jelly's is now closed & tacos here are now $2.50, but I'm thankful the tacos are still delicious!
author: Geraldine R.

description:
I've lived in San Diego, the Mexican food mecca of California, for the past 3 years. Upon moving back to the Bay Area, I have been searching for the perfect taco spot to send my taste buds back to Tijuana. Tonight, I finally found my haven. 2 carne asada tacos and 2 al pastor tacos and I was sent right back to TJ (minus the kids selling "chicle"). Anyways, these tacos were exactly how I remember them in TJ. Meat so juicy the tortilla soaks up the flavor yet still holds its form, and fresh cilantro, onion, and salsa to go on top. Only thing missing was the guac, but I was too happy to notice. Price was $2 per taco, but for an authentic TJ street taco, it was well worth it. 

Vallarta's really is the little Tijuana of the Mission... Fresh tamales, a taco bar, and even a little Mexican corn station too! I will, without a doubt, be coming back to fulfill my weekly mexi cravings.
author: Brie R.

description: Opening hours are 8am. I've gone there 2x in the morning for a breakfast burrito. Beside the fact that they are over prized, the workers are never ready. They open the business and are not prepared AT ALL! We went there this morning, called at 8:40am and cashier told me to go at around 9:15. Got there and the cook had to run out to buy meats, took him about 15min to come back. The cashier is rude, the cook is not ready to take orders. They should first have the food all set up first before opening ANY business. Why open a business when your not ready for customers. I'm not gonna lie there taco bar is good in the afternoon. Manager should really take control of his business and make changes.
author: Jessica M.

description: The worst Service as soon as you step into the Taqueria. Besides the attitude they take over 30 minutes just to do two breakfast burritos due to the fact that they ain't have their shit together. The guy right now and took 15 minutes at to buy the ingredients and came back and started talking to the staff instead of finishing up with the orders. They are bad at customer service and at the end messed up on simple orders. Last time I step foot in this place
author: Carlos T.

description: In our opinion, they have the best street tacos in SF.  The taco bar is immediately to the right as you walk in and they have maybe 6 different types of meat with toppings for you to put on yourself.  Their Chipotle salsa is pretty great and they are open late.
author: Ca A.

description: Crappy service with an attitude and expecting a tip. Food was ok but difinetly did not get my money's worth. Cashier was the worst. You'd do better business without the woman that's there. Best part was the taco bar
author: Alex S.

description: I find the food at some places tastier, but enhjoy some combinations here that don't show up elsewhere
author: Stephen C.

description:
I come here for a quick lunch or snack. Their veggie burritos are great, and so is their wet burrito. They've given me free chips on multiple occasions, which I thought was nice. They're decently priced with VERY generous serving sizes and portions.

If I'm looking for a quick snack, I usually go for the quesadilla de harina. They have 3-4 salsa options at the salsa bar, which is cool. They're all decently spiced, which is what I look for in a salsa to give my food a nice kick!

I've taken my friends here, too, and it was great. I also made a couple friends here too! Nice environment and definitely expresses true Mission culture.
author: Raakin H.

description: Honestly, the best tacos I have ever tasted in my life! I dream about these tacos every Tuesday. Treat yourself to a Taqueria Vallarta taco, you will not be disappointed.
author: Lovejoy K.

description: After visiting the Balmy Murals we wanted authentic Mexican food and this restaurant came through for us. When you first walk in, you get the feeling you're in Mexico and not in San Francisco. In addition, there is a chef who was running a taco bar and you take your orders with him. They had eight different types of meat for your tacos. We believe a good taco must have flavorful meat. This taco was so good that you didn't have to put any toppings on the taco. In addition, we ordered aside of rice and beans, which was also delicious. The location of this place is right next to the Balmy Murals.
author: Terence W.

description:
Get the Meat Piles!

I mean tacos. 
Isn't lower 24th the best?

Too good not to Vallar-talk about it!
(I know, a stretch, but I MUST)!
author: Maya L.

description:
Found this gem by chance. We were so famished after visiting the Balmy St. and this is the nearest food place at the end of the street. And we never regret it!

I had the loaded Lengua Quesadilla that's really delicious. The serving is enough for two and their pricing is very reasonable. My husband grabbed several kinds of meat & salsa from the taco bar. Just make sure to ask about their sauces before pouring it (especially if you can't read spanish like us) lol or else you'll end up pouring a sauce that looks like "mild" but is hecka hot.

After eating their quesadilla, my standard for quesadilla has never been the same.
author: Julie O.

description:
Cheap food explorer taste test heaven!  They have a taco stand right at the entrance with about 9 different meats... each of which can be served in a taco for $2.25.  

The winners and losers depend somewhat on when you go... There are different chefs, and the meats kind of sit there so some of them may be fresher than others - or even unavailable! But in two visits here's what the winners were: tripita (tripe, really! Get the charred parts) pastor and carnitas. Buche was also pretty solid as were chicken, carne Asada and lengua. But Cabeza, suadero and chorizo weren't the best. 

Yum.
author: Aaron M.

description:
The food is definitely worth 5 stars but the service is a little more complicated than that. 

My friend and I ordered food and my order came out just fine. My friend's tacos however were messed up when my friend asked for a side of rice and beans and received two tacos covered in just that. My friend had to eat it all with a fork. The only difference I ordered my food in Spanish and she did not. Every experience I've had I've always just ordered in Spanish so in that sense it's always been good.
author: Estela D.

description:
Came here for the first time the other day and thought it was good. The tacos were a bit of a hit or miss - I loved the al pastor but the carne asada and carnitas were mediocre compared to some other taquerias in the neighborhood. The burritos or filled quesadilla here are the way to go. 

On top of the food the atmosphere really feels like late 80s / early 90s with cheesy arcade / fair style games - think drop a quarter on a toy wrapped in plastic or a gum ball. 

The one noticeably missing aspect is the lack of beer. Not the worst but when I came here I was really hoping to have one. 

All in all it is a good spot but not my favorite. I'd  come back for al pastor burrito any day tho. I definitely recommend trying this spot if you've never been.
author: Derek S.

description: This place is really getting crowded, so I would suggest to get there before lunch. I would like to say that there is always normal food.
author: Liliana P.

description:
5 stars because I have finally found legit tacos in San Francisco!!! My friends were hungry after drinks & karaoke and this is place seriously made my night. Fresh hot tacos, you order as soon as you enter (literally, that's where the line starts), cheap tacos $2.25 (none of that overpriced subpar lukewarm tacos you find downtown) and PLENTY of seating. This was a SF dream come. 

I didn't take any pictures because that's how quickly I devoured those tacos. Very. satisfied. *insert photo of me with smug smile* ;]

Now I want to get me some tacos.
author: Grace J.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

1/1 Star: parking want too hard to find. No wait.

_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

0/1 Star: fast food service. A bit dirty feeling. 

_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

2/3 Stars: tacos are good but not the best. Tacos from the taco bar aren't loaded with as much meat as other places. More greasy than normal as well. 

_____

Overall Experience

3/5 Stars 

_____

Last Words

The tacos here cost a little more than other places.
author: Elliott N.

description: 5 stars for the taco bar.  $2.50 per street taco.  The lengua and al pastor are tender and delicious.  Onions, cilantro, salsa verde, and lime are all I need to top my tacos, and I'm a happy man.  Best taco in the City in my opinion.  So long as their taco bar keeps up the quality I'm used to, I'll keep coming back.
author: Alan C.

description:
A taqueria that's open late & serves fresh ingredients in all there food and has an open taco bar is always a win. But when there entire menu is filled with awesome tasty meals and takes you on a trip to flavor town the you're winning all around and taco Vallarta has all of that.

The first thing everyone seems to talk about is that fact it's open late. It's open till 3am which is a plus when you're out late with friends and need a quick meal. But the food is also a top notch reason to go here. I'm a burrito guy and all the burritos are below you're average cost (about $7 a burrito) where most places start at $8 and range up to $13 dollars, depending on the size and choice. There taco bar is also a fantastic way of bringing a traditional Mexican meal with a twist to people with a fun twist. 

The food is prepared right in front of you (which is always good) and the freshness of the tomatoes, onions and salsa is refreshing for the palate. I've noticed all the different flavors of meat are juicy and the quality has always been top notch. With so many options to choose from, I find the more fattier meat holds its flavor a little better.

The restaurants ambiance is terrific. The location is large and fits numerous amounts of people. The decor looks great because the walls are covered with hand painted murals the showcase the history of the mission and San Francisco. A very nice twist from traditional taquerias that all seem to look the same.

Overall great place for Mexican food and tacos are to die for. The late hours make it a big plus for the twenty something crowds especially after midnight. The only downside is the lack of parking and the fact that the lines get really long due to the popularity of this location. But hey that's a great sign if you ask me.
author: Donald W.

description: Food was ok. Kinda Pricey. The older lady who took my order was a tad rude. What really killed it for me was seeing a cockroach crawling on the floor where we were sitting my little girl noticed it and freaked out.
author: Allie F.

description: Great authentic taco place in the Mission district. Usually less drunken bros and douchebags than you'll find at comparable places on Mission Street. The taco bar is excellent, and they're open late.
author: Ronald F.

description: Can't beat the taco bar for authentic Mexican food! I love the tacos al pastor, carnitas, pollo asado, and suadero. The best part is the fresh chopped cilantro, onions, radish, and the dark red chile salsa- so fresh! It really hits the spot!
author: Anne B.

description:
I don't see how you can get better than this. 

Legit street tacos. Fantastic burrito selection. Check out the vegetarian selection! A bewildering variety of mariscos and plate offerings. 

Although we typically don't do burritos anymore, we couldn't resist the veggie burritos. Mainly because you may get one veggie burrito on a taqueria menu. If you're lucky. And that vegetarian selection may or may not throw in a few measly pieces of grilled or sauteed vegetables into their beans, rice, and cheese. (if you are vegan, the choices are even more meager). 

This place had no less than six or seven veggie burrito choices. I went with a regular nopales burrito. No sour cream or cheese. My husband went with a super eggplant. Also no sour cream or cheese. We also ordered two super carne asada burritos, a side of rice, and a regular bean and cheese for the family. 

The bag must have weighed 15 pounds. No joke. We debated while we walked all the way back to my sister's apartment exactly how much it must weigh. Greater than 12? (certainly felt like it), but definitely less than 20. My husband got an arm workout that day!  When we returned we pulled out the burritos. The super burritos each felt like they weighed at least 2 pounds. Even the regular were stuffed and were probably a good pound of food each. The side of rice wasn't a side. It was a full heaping box full. 

But how was the taste? We had been so seriously disappointed in veggie burritos lately (a major reason why we have given up on burritos), these were delicious. A great balance of beans, rice, and veggies. Not just beans and rice. I had a taste of my sister's carne asada burrito and it was wickedly good (too rich for me). Meat was fantastic. Burritos were all rolled perfectly and toasted on the outside. We tried some of their hot sauces and they were excellent. Very spicy. If you are not tolerant of extreme heat, try them before applying them to your burrito. 

Best of all are the prices. Some of the mariscos items were expensive but no more so than any other taqueria. Prices on the burritos, especially for the size, were excellent.
author: Nora S.

description:
Probably the only food place open late on weekdays in the area. Very suitable for those late nights after coming home from a party, concert, etc. and you need a cheap little snack (or 2) to complete the evening. 

I've only had the tacos here (not really a burrito person), and the quality of the meat has been consistently amazing. They are only $2.25, too. So many options to choose from - go for more of the fatty meats as they are usually most juicy. We love al pastor.

Environment and ambience is that of a typical Mexican restaurant. If you are looking for a modern, spot clean taco place, this is not going to be it. But if you want a real Mexican environment, check this place out.

There is tons of seating available and it never gets too crowded. That alone makes it better than La Taqueria (the overrated and crowded one!)

Definitely recommended.
author: Elisa L.

description:
This place has no ambiance or even very clean tables but they do have variety. I'm talking 12 types of tacos at the taco bar. I crave the barbacoa (lamb), for its gamy flavor. Biting into the two fresh warm tortillas that tastes of corn with a slight sourness, mixed with the greasy lamb juices and kissed with salsa verde, minced onion and cilantro. Is your mouth watering? 
I've tried the Perbil (chicken liver) and the Carnitas and Suardo (sp?) all are good but nothing compares to the lamb.
author: Lhm M.

description:
Their hours omg... not sure it's the best idea to be wolfing down fat burritos at midnight (or later), but it hits the spot to have non-Taco Bell delicious Mexican food when you have the munchies, or even more so, the drunchies.

Because I knew it was against common sense to be wolfing down fat burritos at midnight, I abstained from getting anything when I came here with my friends.  However, someone found her burrito too spicy and couldn't eat it... so I began to wolf down a fat burrito at midnight.  

It was indeed intensely spicy (like extra spicy at a legit Korean restaurant, or spicier than Local Edition Bloody Marys--pick your scale).  Wolfing down is not an inaccurate term, since your mouth is on fire in between bites and you have to keep eating until you're full.  Assuming you can eat it, I'd say the burrito was pretty solid.  There's Mexican food and good Mexican food, and Taqueria Vallarta belongs to the latter--Mexican food that makes you wonder why you once thought Chipotle was the best thing in the world.

The next day however, one of my other friends who also ate the spicy burrito ended up getting food poisoning... sigh, the dilemma that good Mexican places often seem to entail a health risk.  Fortunately my stomach of steel protected me and I felt fine (possibly from having eaten way more questionable Mexican food in SD), though slightly guilty at having wolfed down a fat burrito at midnight.

So I know this does not make a very good review considering I did not know the name of what I ate and did not even order it or intend to eat anything here in the first place, but I write because 1) that's what Yelpers gotta do 2) I think it's useful to know that:
(+) Good food and too-good-to-be-true late night hours
(-) Very spicy burritos and potential food poisoning so don't come here the night before you have an interview or a flight
author: Edna C.

description: 6 tacos came out to $16., they are amazing ., perfect for a late night sober up good., lots of options.: good food
author: Eva S.

description: Best tacos to date. We come here late night just for the tacos. My favorite is the chorizo tacos. The salsa is off the hook. They also have a lady in there that sells elote, champurado, atole, and tamales. Very good. Pricing is great. Highly recommend this place.
author: J. P.

description:
As any proper San Franciscan, of course I must have an opinion on the best tacos in town. And Taqueria Vallarta's are mine. 
Served from a large beautiful grill of meats, this place takes mission tacos to a whole new level. Favorites: chorizo, carnitas and al pastor (although they tend to run out of carnitas). They grill the tortillas before serving you the tacos, which gives them a nice toasty flavor, as opposed to nice meat on a cold tortilla. I would also recommend asking them for the grilled onions. Their sauces are excellent as well. 
To be honest, I've never had anything there but the tacos. Don't see why you would, but maybe someday, the day will come.
author: Rita K.

description:
Today I had the most pathetic al pastor burrito in my life!  Growing up in the heart of the Mission, I've had a many burritos and today's burrito wins in the MOST PATHETIC award.  

The al pastor burrito was basically loaded with beans; and it was a scavenger hunt to find a fleck of the al pastor!  The appropriate menu name for the burrito should be "flavorless bean burrito with a possible fleck of al pastor."

The popularity of Taqueria Vallarta has negatively affected the quality.  Never again...there are many better options on Calle 24!

Also, I paid for sliced avocado which was left out of the burrito...and the cashier was extremely rude to everyone!   I retrieved my $3.00 tip from the tip jar and gave it to the homeless man who was on 24th & Alabama.  
Good thing I didn't give him a burrito...he would have been disappointed!
author: Lucky L.

description: So thrilled they where open!  Midnight and in down town S.F.  Went to one other place and they switched to bar drinks only after 10pm.  This is a nice place descent pricing fresh grilled meats!  Dining room little on the dirty side but for all it offered it was a place to stop in!
author: Rusty C.

description:
There are plenty of Mexican restaurants in the city, especially in the Mission District. How do you pick one?! Play row-sham-bow with your friends? Toss a coin to choose between the top two favorites? Close your eyes, spin around in a circle, and point? Whatever method you choose to do, definitely keep Taqueria Vallarta in mind as a choice.

I've been to the Mission more than a couple times but I've never seen this place. My friend took me here because he says their quesadillas are delicious. He has good taste in food so I trusted him.

I walked in and my first thought was, damn this place is huge. It has 10+ tables that looked like the wooden picnic tables in neighborhood parks. We walked to the front counter and placed an order for one Quesadilla De Castillito, which consists of your choice of meat, cheese, sour cream, avocado, tomatoes, and jalapeños (~$8). I also grabbed a few containers of sauces at the sauce bar: tomatillo, habanero, and chunky salsa. My favorite was the tomatillo sauce! Spicy and slightly sweet. The salsa had an odd (almost bitter) taste so I stopped eating it after one bite. And the habanero sauce fared the worst.... it was watery and had no flavor.

I pretty much ate my share of the quesadilla with tomatillo sauce and it was heavenly. A side of fried tortilla chips would've been nice but alas, it's an additional 75 cents. Oh well, I saved money and calories!
author: Annie S.

description:
BEST carnitas taco I've had in a loooong time.

Food: 5 Stars
OMG, The carnitas taco here was delicious. We also got an asada taco, but that one was pretty average. I'll definitely make the trip back to eat more carnitas tacos though

Atmosphere: 3 Stars
The taco bar is by the door and there was a line when we got there. The interior looks like the average mexican joint. You know the food has to be good when the taco line goes out the door.

Value: 4 Stars
$2.50 for a taco is on the steep side, but they give you a decent amount of meat and you get to add your own toppings.

Service: 3 Stars
No frills here. You get your tacos, pay, and get out. You can eat in as well.

Overall: 5 Stars
Yeah yeah, 15/20 =/= 5 Stars, but I weigh each category differently, with food obviously holding the most weight and value coming in above Service and Atmosphere. 5 stars for great tacos.
author: Courtney Q.

description:
Oh my god, this one is way better than the one on 16th!!!

First of all, there are like NO homeless people lingering in front, or almost none? Walking there I did see a woman who was laying on the ground in front of the convenience store.. I'm hoping she was alive.. she had a cushion under her head so she was probably sleeping?

Anyways, I had the pescado frito and it was awesome! A tid salty on the skin, but the meat was good and it was so worth the price ($11.25). I was so excited because I've tried to order this from the 16th street location, and menudo and they always say they don't have it. The 24th location has everything, yay!

Come to this one instead!! BTW, I had a groupon, $12 for $20 so I brought a friend who enjoyed our burrito and we each had tomales too!
author: Angela L.

description: Solid Carna Asada plate. Wait can be long but it was worth it.
author: Steve K.

description: Came in here around 6:30 pm on a Saturday because I wanted to try the elote. There was lots of seating room available. There was a specific station to pick up elote, separate from the order counter, close to the front door. A woman there made me my elote. She grabbed a cooked ear of corn, slathered mayo on it, rolled it in a container of cotija cheese, and asked if I wanted chili spice on it (yes!). I paid her right there - $3. Great price for a little snack. I'd had elote at a burger restaurant before, so I wanted to compare. I was a little disappointed that this one wasn't as salty.
author: Kayla M.

description: this place has the most amazing tacos hands down. Their buche and tripas alone is worth he trip!!
author: michael m.

description:
Don't ask me about the main menu items, it's all about the taco stand INSIDE the restaurant. Yes, you read that right - there's a taco stand INSIDE the restaurant that functions almost independently from the rest of the joint. For just a couple bucks per taco, this place is a real bargain. 

They offer up a ton of different meats but I stuck to three of my favorites - suedero, carne asada and al pastor. 

SUEDERO TACO ~ 3.5 stars: Suedero is typically fried thinly cut brisket. I've had it many times and a lot of places have screwed up on their take of suedero, however, I was very pleased with how TV's version turned out. Not my favorite but it was tender and pretty flavorful. 

CARNE ASADA TACO ~ 4 stars: Not kidding, TV's carne asada tacos are probably the best carne asada tacos I've had in the Bay Area. If I wasn't comparing them to some of the best ones I've had in SoCal, I'd automatically give this 5 stars. It's THAT good. 

AL PASTOR TACO ~ 4 stars: Almost the same story as the carne asada tacos except for the fact that I've had al pastor tacos just as good in the Bay. Check out Tacos Negris in Fremont - SO bomb! However, these are delicious. If you like al pastor, you won't go wrong with this. They're awesome. 

http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=dL3Nig4jgm6ldcuMEECfMg&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A
author: Bruce C.

description: I've never been disappointed by this place. Burritos, tacos, quesadilla, tortas and tamales, i tried all of them and they're all tasty. The food comes out pretty fast, unlike other places in the area.
author: Xavier R.

description:
Yuck!!!!! VOMIT!!!!! Disgusting, do not go!!! They tried to sell us spoiled food, and would not refund us. I bought a taco from the taco bar, and you could smell the spoiled meat, that nasty sour smell. We also ordered Menudo, and first of all there wasn't any Homny, second the meat smelled bad, sour and gross. We didn't even touch our food and I asked for a refund. The store manager said "no" and I wasn't going to put up a fight, so we left. Never go here!!!
San Fran you need some real Mexican food restaurants!! Take SAN diego Mexican restaurants for example.
author: Mark L.

description: Seriously awesome tacos! Loved the carne Asada and the Tri tip. There are also many vegetarian options that can either be made into a burrito or a quesadilla, both of with are great. I would definitely go again!
author: Hasher221 H.

description:
Who doesn't like a little tongue and head action in your mouth?

Ok, you perverts; I'm talking about lengua and cabeza, two of the MOST underrated meats. 

Taqueria Vallarta has that AND more...

In the gourmet ghetto part of The Mission, Taqueria Vallarta serves up some of the most authentic and cheap street tacos in town. Upon entering, you will find a taco stand with a sizzling meat wheel that you will make you want to faceplant into it. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/y00vIJzvt1Fveq_Um_9egw?select=D42OzAJCp8b898bYb_PU5w

For a mere $1.75, take your pick from over 8 kinds of meats. You can order the *yawn* standard carnitas or carne asada or be adventurous and order pancita (sheep stomach), tripas (beef stomach lining) or buche (pig's esophagus). RAWR!

Tell the taco man, your choice of meat(s) and watch him go into taco ninja action. He dips the tiny corn tortilla disks in water and warms it in the center of the meat wheel. When the slightly wet corn tortilla hits the sizzling meat wheel, it creates a steaming sensation making it soft and pliable. Topped with your choice of meat(s) and then a generous sprinkle of sweet caramelized onions, you are now ready to top your tacos to your liking. Cilantro, diced raw onions, radishes, lime wedges and three salsas; free feel to make it rain to your liking. 

My two go-tos meats: 

*LENGUA TACO
 http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/y00vIJzvt1Fveq_Um_9egw?select=lGw1yDWttaliFJl9WC2FTw
The small chunks of lengua was boiled to a perfect soft tenderness with just enough seasoning to bring out all the beefy goodness. Very solid though my favorite is from La Taqueria and Mexico Tipico. 

*CABEZA TACO
 http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/y00vIJzvt1Fveq_Um_9egw?select=Zaos-rvxBHZiNKc8eClCJQ
Don't let the word "head" deter you from trying one of the richest beefy meats out there. Just like beef cheeks, the chunks and shreds have a long stewed consistency giving the head a smooth and slightly silky texture. 

I bet you never have tongue and head like this before, not together at least. NOOOOO PUN INTENDED.  ;)

OTHER NOTES
*Closes at 3:30 AM on weekends
*Ample seating; 10-12 tables 
*Just steps away from Humphry Slocombe
*CC's accepted
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I found this gem of a taqueria on the first night I moved to the neighbourhood. I had just spent the whole day moving house and it was getting late and I needed food. Luckily for me, Taqueria Vallarta is open from the early hours of the morning all the way to 12:30 am on weekdays and even later on the weekends.

The variety and quality of their food is always exemplary and the price is very reasonable in comparison to other local taquerias.

I have friends that will travel far and wide from the Bay Area to dine on their fantastic super burritos. There's a taco stand and a corn on the cob station as well within this establishment.

Give it a try, you'll love it.
author: Lawan H.

description: Cali Burritos in SF!!! Tacos are always amazing. How good the burritos are have a lot to do with the chef on hand.
author: Austin H.

description: Don't ever walk in here from outta town and slightly tipsy....my man and I bought only 2 super burritos thats it and the next day I see a charge on my card for 27.00 dollars! This broad last Saturday night overcharged me and I guess wrote in a TIP for herself...eff this place! Burritos were small and not very flavorful.
author: Nellie S.

description:
Best tacos I ve had in the city. 

I ve tried the pollo asado and the pork ones. You stand in line ask for the tacos and then put your own toppings and sauces. Toppings include lime onions and cilantro. 

For a hearty meal I d recommend getting 4 to 5 tacos and they are only 2 bucks each and consistently tasty. Be careful of the red sauce - it's pretty hot !
author: Priyanka P.

description:
A mission treat! Gotta say I'm happy to have gotten some good Mexican food while visiting my family. :) 

Food: I had 3 tacos. Lengua, carne asada and carnitas. My oh my were they all super good! The taco bar, where I got my tacos, is a bit awkwardly placed. Its near the register, but males the line come out the door. Regardless, they have all the toppings you might want. Chopped onions, cilantro, Chile Verde, red Chile, radish...all that good stuff! 
My little brother had the steak nachos. Steak was amazingly seasoned just like all my meats. Good amount of cheese plus it had chunks of avocado, salsa, jalapeños, sour cream...oh man. Yummers!
Horchata was delicious :) legit! Good variety of drinks. From agua frescos to mexico coke, Arizona's and more.

Price: I was a bit frustrated when it came to the drinks and tacos. Everything else was reasonable. Basic pricing however the drinks made the bill sky rocket. Seems my horchata was around 5 for a small size. Bummer :/ also, there were two different signs for the tacos. $2 outside and $2.25 inside. 25¢ makes a difference! 

Place itself: A bit dirty. Hence my 4 stars. They don't really clean after people leave. I understand you have pretty decent traffic..but sweep maybe? I sat in something too. 

Anyways, it was a step up from places I've been going to in the OC. Yum :)
author: Rosa S.

description: Friends and I were craving Mariscos (seafood) in SF & this was the closest place with better reviews. Food was good but wouldn't say amazing for my first time there.. I got the #2 combination plate which was good except the shrimp cocktail was very warm. The cashier seemed frustrated and annoyed, and bathrooms were horrendous which is why the rating is a #3 instead of 4.
author: Monica G.

description: Very good! Classic traditional tacos that I had been looking for! Lots of options on the menu but we chose the taco bar. Multiple meat choices, waited for the tortillas off the grill. Top with an array of cilantro, limes, radish, and many different salsas. Hard to choose so I grabbed many!! Enjoyed with a side of salsa!
author: Katherine L.

description:
Having gone to school in San Diego, I went for the regular California Burrito. Big mistake. Wish we went for the tacos instead. 

Charged an even $25.00 for 
2 California Burritos at $7.95 each
2 small agua frescas. 

Very much over charged I asked her, if the price was correct and she confirmed that it was. 

Not going back if I can't trust the cashiers.
author: Geordie E.

description: Went here the other night late at night. I never made it to the regular area to place my order because they were seving fresh street tacos at the door. Honestly the tacos were amazing. The fresh salsa to put on top was great. It was a little unclear where the line was supposed to form and a little unclear where to pay. The only reason i knocked off some stars was because of cleanliness. They had several garbage cans in the restaurant but there was still a lot of garbage all over the floor. This is mostly the fault of the patrons that do not respect the staff or the place. But I will admit it was unclear whether i was supposed to bus my own table or not. I would have liked to see the staff a little more strict with the patrons. When you walk into a place that is clean then I feel like people are more inclined to respect the level of cleanliness of the establishment.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
The taco bar is the star of the taqueria, unsurprisingly. At $2 per, the price is right for the quality of the meat (decent), the quality of the tortillas (decent) and the variety of toppings (good).

The dining room is flanked by claw games and other "pay a quarter and kill ten seconds" novelties. What that means is for five bucks, you can get two tacos, a plate of chips, and potentially win a stuffed animal.
author: John S.

description: Hey y'all fuck you this place is bombas fuck. Taco bar at 3am, that's 5 stars all day
author: Yocelin C.

description: Wonderful surprise in finding this place.  Authentic taco bar, with a great selection of meats-lengua, cabeza, tripe, chorizo, etc.  I enjoyed the tacos de lengua, cabeza and chorizo.  Seasoned very well.  Only added lime, cilantro and onions.  Atmosphere is very laid back.  Good sized place for large groups.
author: Mickey H.

description: Loved it. Probably the best value for the buck in the whole San Francisco. This place definitely made it to one of my favorite places for tacos in the city.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
The Mission is jam-packed with amazing Mexican joints, and while I didn't love this place like I do La Palma and El Farolito, it's still damn good.

For starters, it's dangerously cheap. Like, why would I ever buy a burrito anywhere else, ever, cheap. Second, the portions are fit for Hobbits. The burrito is a two-fister with room to spare. The El Mexicana burrito (with chicken) is a solid meat delivery system, but I think on a repeat visit I'd omit the meat entirely and toss in some sour cream.

If you've never been to The Mission before, or if you have but you've only walked by this taqueria, it's definitely worth it.

$10 would be a fortune to spend for a single meal here.
author: Nick S.

description: Yah, this place pretty much seems like the place where you take your out of town friends for some good mexican food, but the price has gotten to be a bit ridiculous. I could find cheaper, better food elsewhere.
author: Jason And Janelle P.

description: When I asked a friend of mine who lives in the Mission where he thought the best tacos in town were, he sent me here. Many misguided people think La Taqueria has the best tacos. They're wrong. The little bar up front at Taqueria Vallarta has the best tacos in the city. Juiciest flavorful meats, perfectly cooked corn tortillas, and simple salsa bar. A must-go-to for lunch or dinner, and great place to take out-of-town guests to give them a real flavor of the Mission.
author: James M.

description: Taqueria Vallarta use to be my go-to taco place, but the prices have increased so much! I remember when the taco costs $1.50, and now it's $2.50 each. I guess this is normal, and I would be okay with the increased prices, but I feel like the quality has decreased. I've tried the burritos; it's huge! I will stick to the burritos for now on. BTW, pay attention when they are charging your credit card. My meal cost $20, but they charged $22 on my card.
author: Michelle O.

description: This is a great place to get some quick tacos, whether for lunch, dinner, or just a snack. All of them are $2.50 each, and it's never too busy so they make it for you in 2 minutes. My favorite flavors are cabeza and al pastor.
author: Bai L.

description:
I thought this was a hidden gem but with the hundreds of reviews that might not be the case.

Craving a burrito for dinner and drop by this place rather than Farolito across the street (wanted to try something new). Instantly became a fan! In addition to the kitchen, there was a taco guy on a griddle by the door. Plenty of vegetarian choices from the looks of it ... I've never seen an eggplant burrito before. 

I judge taquerias on their salsa bar as well. Vallartas does it right and definitely knows the key to the heart as soon as I saw that habanero salsa. Service was friendly too. I'm adding this to my rotation along with Los Coyotes, Cancun, San Jose, and Farolito.
author: Tee T.

description: Once upon a time this place was decorated inside with fantastic historical murals.  Everyone from Franciscan monks to Joe Montana adorn the ceilings and walls.  Now many of them are faded, peeling or gone, which is line with whole place.  Somewhat shabby, slightly grungy.   And the woman working the counter seemed like she wanted to slink into the fading murals herself.  Anything would be better, it seemed, than serving us.  But who cares?  A massive plate of crispy and tasty carnitas, with delicious rice and beans literally oozing off the edge of the plate, accompanied by plentiful steaming tortillas, more than made up for whatever shortcomings this place may have in ambiance and decor.  It's a mission district taqueria after all, and if you are looking for flavor and value, this place will more than satisfy.  And even in their state of faded grandeur, the murals are pretty cool.
author: Doron A.

description:
I like to stay away from fast food joints, but sometimes you really don't have a lot of time. My favorite fast food in San Francisco is Mexican Food. Always easy to prepare, fast and yummy, wrapped up and ready to eat.

Taqueria Vallarta has a walk up taco counter to purchase yummy meat tacos ala cart, super easy and fast. Chicken, Pork or Steak. Easy simple good tacos, at $1.50 or $1.75 each - you can order and eat as many as you like.

I usually pop into Taqueria Vallarta when I'm in the neighborhood running errands or visiting my favorite nail shop. I get a little cranky if I haven't had any lunch so quick food is good.

I like things spicy, so I order the Mexican Burrito with Grilled Chicken. It's pretty big, so I usually eat 1/2 at a time. I love their little salsa bar too, I like to mix and match the spicy and cool salsas with my Mexican food.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Horrible service! Found a hair in my flautas and they only wanted to return $2 of the $8 I paid because I ate the other flautas! How ridiculous is that! That's I no way to treat a customer. If I could give no stars I would.  Never coming back!
author: Celia R.

description:
There's a taco bar by the entrance when you first walk in where you can get any meat on your taco for only $2! They have: 
Barbacoa (stewed meat)
Pansita (stomach)
Carnitas (pork)
Carne asade (bbq beef)
Cabeza (beef head)
Lengua (beef tongue)
Chorizo (spicy sausage)
Al pastor (bbq pork)
Pollo asado (grilled chicken)
Tripita (beef tripe)
Suadero (tender beef)
Bunche (pork neck). 

The condiments are all set out right in front of where you get your tacos. They have fresh cilantro, limes, sliced radishes, and three sauces (two red and one green).

If you want anything else besides the tacos, bypass the line and head to the cashier in the back. What surprised me was that they have many varieties of tortillas! Not only do they have the regular flour tortilla, they have whole wheat, spinach, and tomato! They also have a lot of veggie burritos if you're vegetarian (or trying to eat healthier).

Since I wanted to try multiple meats, I ordered two tacos (one lengua and the other carne asade) and a regular burrito with pollo asado in a spinach tortilla. I really enjoyed the two tacos. The meats were tender and juicy (so much that it kind of made the first layer or taco rip). They were packed w/lots of flavor. The burrito had a good mix of meat and filling. The chicken was tender and juicy but nothing special. The spinach tortilla just tasted like tortilla with a hint of spinach, so it wasn't overpowering the rest of the burrito. My friend ordered the cantaloupe juice with a little bit of horchata mixed in and it was amazing! The juice was so refreshing and quenches your thirst (even when you didn't realize you were thirsty!)

The seating is a bunch of tables w/benches that are fairly grimy, but it's in the mission! What do you expect? They can sit about six per table, so if you have more people, you gotta move some tables together.

Would I go back? I'd definitely go back for the tacos & the cantaloupe juice, in addition to trying other meats. Love anyplace that serves lengua! You gotta try them!
author: Kitty K.

description: The cashier touch the food with her dirty hands.  She counts the money and then go and pack chips  with out gloves or washing her hands. After I saw that I didn't come back...nasty
author: Lm M.

description:
Love this place. The serving sizes are ridiculous in the best way possible. 
The lengua is DE-MOTHAWATCHAYAMOUTH-LICIOUS and I'm pretty pissy about who's lengua I eat.

Everytime I'm in S.F. for work I try to stop by here if I'm in the mood for Mexican food. The taco bar always smells so tantalizing...don't walk by this place go in and absorb the deliciousness.
author: Autumn A.

description:
Oh man, they have the best street tacos ever!  

They have a great taco bar right at the door, you just choose what you want and the food is being cooked right in front of you in a huge pan. All the toppings and sauce are at the bar as well. Oh, and you pay the lady with the apron since there's no register. As far as customer service goes, it's pretty much "fend for yourself." It wasn't the greatest, but hey, I love their tacos anyway.

But back to the tacos: the taco de pollo was my faaaaave. The chicken was so tender and delicious. As mentioned, the taco bar has the usual toppings: onions, cilantro & salsa. I made the mistake of getting the green salsa thinking it was mild but whew! WARNING: It's HOT if you're into that. 

Seating is a little limited since it was busy at the time I went (around 6:30 on a week day) so luckily we ended up sitting at the window which had a seating area for 3 people.
author: Sammie T.

description: Five stars for the tacos - burritos could be a little better.  I've also had their enchiladas and fried fish, which were both excellent.  I hear they've got a pretty good menudo as well.  Interior leaves a lot to be desired though - take it to go.
author: Thomas R.

description:
After biking to the Mission for Sunday Streets, we decided to stop by here for cheap yet good tacos.  

It looks unsanitary because the self topping station is placed right next to the door.  

We got the chorizo, tripe, and two other types of meat...sorry, my bf did the ordering, I did the eating.

Don't be discouraged by the set up, try it!
author: Linda N.

description:
$2 tacos 
You dress your own taco however you like (which means as much cilantro as you want). 
No thrill. No mess. It's a good pit stop. But I've still had better tacos in East Oakland. But that's just me.
author: Meshell C.

description:
This is my favorite location for the famous tacos sudados (aka. tacos al vapor) for $1.50, http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/xYjVG-ZB2EoDWDZ2RvdSSQ/l these are only available at the food stand grill near the entrance. http://media3.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5MQe_5_CvmBem6kceHX9Iw/l It's a very popular place with good turnover, so less chance of getting overcooked meat.

The round grill contains small mounds of different meats cooking along the edge. The cook dips 2 mini tortillas in water and places them in the center of the grill to steam-grill. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/TeX06-qNbti-wkwWw3H92w/l There's exactly one dozen meat choices listed on the wall (barbacoa, pansita, carnitas, carne asada, cabeza, lengua, chorizo, al pastor, pollo asado, tripita, suadero, buche).

What to do:
1 - Place your order at the stand, takes less than a minute to assemble.
2 - Garnish your own tacos - chopped onions, parsley, sliced radish, lemon wedges, and 3 sauces.
3 - Go to the cashier in the back to pay.
4 - Buy a drink or help yourself to a cup of water. Grab some napkins.
5 - Find an empty seat to enjoy the feast!
http://media1.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/EtvEEKLR6PvXjdcldtKLVw/l

If u want standard tacos, burritos, quesadillas, tostadas, etc. just order from the menu next to the counter area inside. This is a large restaurant, has a separate dining room with plenty of seating space and a jukebox. About 3-4 years ago this place had many problems, wasn't very clean, and was forced to close for more than a year. Maybe it changed owners, not sure. Anyways, it's been great ever since.

Hours: 8:30am-midnight (Fri-Sat until 3:30am)
author: Luis C.

description:
The food was good! But not excellent, there is definitely just as good and better in the mission. The burrito mojado was very good. But the lengua tacos were very bland. 

We brought a printed out groupon, which they refused to honor (even though on the groupon it explicitly says you can print it out and bring it in). It was pretty dirty, but also busy, so I understand why. And when we tried buying a side of chips with a five dollar bill they said they didn't have change.... you don't have change for a five?? Okay.
author: Isabella G.

description: The tacos had no taste, plus the guy didn't give me the order I said terrible taqueria
author: Angel G.

description: Filthy restaurant with too many health code violations to count.  Disorganized service and greasy, flavorless food.   Stay away.
author: EC N.

description: Great tacos, but the rest of the menu was hit-or-miss.  The ordering process is a little inconvenient because if get tacos from the guy at the front, you have to take them to the counter inside to pay, and so you could find yourself standing in two long lines.  The breaded shrimp was decent, and the fried fish was surprisingly good - no overbearing fishy flavor or aroma, and no oily taste.  The shrimp and steak combination was a little disappointing, in that the meat was fairly tough though the flavor was pleasing.  Beans, rice, and tortillas come with the platters, as would be expected, and portions were generous.  Overall a very good dining experience here.
author: Lee L.

description: Good lord the tacos... get the al pastor.  I also see people get the lengua a lot.  I wish they were as cheap as they used to be... but then again nothing is cheap anymore.
author: Ems G.

description: I got a super burrito al pastor.  The al pastor was okay at best and there was hardly any of it.  For an $11 burrito, I felt completely cheated.  I went early, so the place was clean and without a line.  From reading other reviews, it sounds like if I went at night, I'd be giving this place one star.  I don't don't know what all these good reviews are for, maybe drunk taco munchers don't care.
author: seth c.

description:
The bathroom.. lord, the bathroom... it has seen better days. This is a hole in the wall kind of place.

That being said, we had some late night burritos and nachos. The refried  beans must be cheap and easy to get because the nachos were basically a few chips buried under a mountain of beans! Too much... but it was tasty.
author: Nancy A.

description:
Service = meh
 
Food = okay.  Chicken's a bit on the dry side.  Chips are okay.  Salsa, one of them is super spicy, and the chipotle one is a bit too smokey though.  I love the two green salsas.  

Drinks = lots of bottles of sodas and beers.  Woohoo.

Prices = Cheap.  Of course, I had the $10.00 Groupon voucher too...
author: Fannie S.

description: Large range of food options. Flavorful and fresh. I got the regular burrito and had leftovers! With your order you also get a chip bag and BOMB salsas, hint - there are unlimited salsa containers!
author: Bryn C.

description:
delicious mexican food!! We always come here when the Cesar Chavez parade is in the area. You will Be SATISFIED. #superCHICKENBurritoPlz 
#WithEverything
author: Dawnn P.

description:
If you're able to make it through the crowd of sagging skinny jean  hipsters at the $1.50 taco stand near the door, do yourself a favor and
make your way to the back burrito counter and order the Super Shrimp Burrito. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/y00vIJzvt1Fveq_Um_9egw?select=mM1BDFjjy9NPrZZAjt9EsQ)

It's 8 bucks and it's shrimpy, juicy, goey, cheesy, and filling. The shrimps have a grilled flavor and you get shrimp in each juicy bite.  

With all the colorful SF murals inside, there always seems to be a couple tourists taking pics while having lunch. 

Even with all the other taquerias in the neighborhood, this one is pretty solid.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/y00vIJzvt1Fveq_Um_9egw?select=faqoymDYtunrZpRQWTh8iw)
author: Earl G.

description:
I have said this again and again... for Mexican food the dirtier the kitchen the tastier and genuine the food. DO NOT BE FOOLED BY THE OUTSIDE LOOK OF THE SHOP!!! TV is actually pretty clean but definitely dirty enough. Let me just say its damn amazing! 

This restaurant symbolizes everything I love about the ghetto areas of a city. Cheap, no lines, and good taste. I got their quesadilla castillito and it was one of the better dirty mex quesadillas I have had. The cheese was a little stiff but all the ingredients complimented each other well. The dish was a bit overprices... the real value are in their gigantic burritos which are almost half the price of the quesadilla. They also have a taco bar in the corner of the store with an assortment of meats and salsa. 

The owner lady was extremely kind. Also... this shop has all the flavors of jarritos (my favorite mexican soda) that exist. Nice seating areas around the shop.
author: Dan K.

description:
If your looking for cheap tacos ($2), look no further!! Their tacos are very tasty and authentic. During my visit I also ordered their super nachos w/ chicken. I wasn't to impressed with their consistency. This visit  my nachos were soggy and had to eat them  with a fork - slightly disappointing. I will continue to come for the tacos and my give the super nachos another try (it maybe a hit or miss).

Happy eating!!!
author: Kristina S.

description:
So what I really want here is the big roulette wheel hubcap with the raised center where all the mini-tortillas get heated up and toasty. It's like an open-faced George Foreman 360 grill, slightly used. OK, majorly used. But that's the point as the taco maker holds court for all of us to drool (see photos). Tiny tacos. Taco tapas, that's how I'd describe them to a foodie. And dangerously bargain-priced at $1.50. Yes, $1.50. You could order ten and still consider it a cheap meal. 

Not that I would order ten. At least sober. Jamie W. and I were here during Sunday Streets having been previously lured here but never when we had mutually empty stomachs. This time, we were strolling after being rebuffed yet again at the always-depleted Dynamo Donuts. It was our time to try the tacos. So many meat choices... al pastor (spicy pork), beef, chorizo, chicken and carnitas (pulled pork).

We decided to split five - 2 of the al pastor and 3 of the carnitas (see photo). It was a pork kind of Sunday. Delicious especially with the caramelized onions on top. Fresh cilantro, salsa, and green onions are also options but scoop fast 'cause hungry people are waiting in line. You move your flimsy paper plate to the next counter to get your beverage and pay. Then you move into the next room, the spacious one with the showgirl mural and colorfully tiled picnic tables (see photos). Time to chomp. 

FOOD - 4 stars...taco tapas in a recession-proof enclave 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...feels authentically Mexican like you landed in Guadalajara next to a taco stand in a lunch room 
SERVICE - 4 stars...the taco maker knows when to hold 'em, knows when to fold 'em, knows when to walk away when the dealin's done 
TOTAL - 4 stars...perfect meal for the penny-wise, pound-foolish crowd
author: Ed U.

description:
$2.25 for tacos in The Mission,.. Meh, not too surprising. 
$2.25 tacos at Taqueria Vallarta's Taco Bar is AMAZINGGG! 

I'm pretty sure it's up to 12 different meats you can choose from at the cart. The corn tortillas are a perfect fluffiness and the Carne Asada, Pollo Asada & Chorizo are so scrumptious you'll be begging for more!! 

3 different salsas to choose from and all the onions, cilantro and peppers to slap onto your yummy plate of delicious-ness, you seriously just. Can't. Go wrong.

I need more of this yumminess in my life!!
author: Karen G.

description: I am from concord and we have a mini mexico the food is legit so it takes an extremely  good place for me to say I am leaving the east bay and going back ASAP  cuz I don't leave my area. this place has done it. I had the San Francisco platter hands down amazing it's a must!!! Will be back for sure!
author: Melissa P.

description:
I should have gone for the tacos, looking at yelp!

But instead I had la mariscada, which lemme tell you, was eye-rolling good.  All sorts of crab legs, mussels, pieces of fish, avocado.  I died and went to marisco heaven.

I'm a bay area native in exile in Portland, OR at the moment, and when I returned to eat this, I legit wished I had never left.

They just don't do it like this up north.  Fuck.  I got water in my eyes just thinking about the insanely delicious food here.  

:(
author: Olivia O.

description: Yearning for Mexican food, we passed a few American-Mexican joints and nearly risked it. Lucky for we went here on a recommendation from a friend while bumming around the mission and weren't disappointed. This is authentic Mexican cuisine. My girlfriend is a vegetarian and sometime Mexican can be limited to veggie-burritos. We were thrilled to see the great selection of vegetarian options; something that works for both of us. She was torn between the rajas and cactus but went with the cactus. I got the chicken enchilada dinner plate which came with rice, beans, avocado, sour cream and some nice fresh veggies. Coming from San Diego we're very particular about our Mexican food; prior to moving to San Fransisco it was a staple of my diet. Come to Taqueria Vallarta for reasonably priced and very good food.
author: Alex R.

description: This place has your typical "whole-in-the-wall" qualities, variety of meat choices, soups, bare-bones look and you feel more comfortable ordering in Spanish than English (they speak English perfectly well). The staff was friendly and polite and they give you free chips while you wait for your food. I got a burrito and enjoyed it. The food definitely isnt unique, but if you like your Mexican food staples youll like this place a lot.
author: Jess C.

description: This is what tacos should be, simple flavorful, loaded with toppings and a good dose of hot sauce. And yes for a couple of bucks. This little gem used to be the secret of all the restaurant workers getting off shift, now I'd say the majority of customers are of a different type. At least the tacos haven't changed.
author: Matt A.

description:
Barbacoa, chorizo, al pastor, carnitas, pollo asado, carne asada, tripe, cabeza, suaaaaderoooooo, lengua, buche, and pigeons, o my!!! 

Wait.. what???

Pigeons galore, yes. That was in a past life, but they've cleaned up their act. They got shut down by the health dept for having a pigeon infestation, pigeons flying here and there, pigeons hovering and lusting over your al pastor, pigeons living in the grafts. But, really, who could blame em?? Those pigeons knew whats up. And, that's the tacos. No one really cared. We just gobbled the delicious meat, while shoo'ing the pigeons away. Go away, bird! Git away from my meat! GIT!! You wanna fight??!! I'll do it!! It's just THAT good. 

All of these meats sit happy and sizzling around a circular grill and just merry their gluttonous goodness together. Tortillas get warmed with a quick sizzle in the middle of the grill, getting a taste of the meat's savory juices. Pick your meats, as they get topped with onion and cilantro, and ladle the salsa of your choice. 

So, with all the mouth-watering, satiating meats, why the 3 stars you ask??

It's due to the GROUPON DEBACLE. 

On a routine trip to get our taco fix, I recalled seeing a Groupon for Taqueria Vallarta. Heck yea, can't pass this deal up! Sitting in my car, parked right outside the restaurant, I hurriedly purchased the deal, like it was going out of style, thinking, oh, man, these tacos are going to taste all the better as I get $25 worth for only $12. Oh, the possibilities! SCORE!!!

I walked in, ordered my tacos, and got in line to pay. In front of the register, was a sign that said Taqueria Vallarta was no longer accepting Groupons as of "whatever date a week ago from that date." I thought, no way, I JUST purchased this. Literally, 5 minutes ago. We told the cashier, 6 tacos, and we have a Groupon. They pointed to the sign, "Duh", and said they were no longer honoring it. UGHH, what the heck!!!?? I JUST purchased it!! Why would Groupon have it up if they weren't going to honor it? They referred me to go back to Groupon for a refund. So, we tried calling AND emailing Groupon and, of course, got a response, saying, no, Vallarta is accepting it. Go back. They'll take it. They just started offering this as of 'whatever date Vallarta said they weren't accepting it". Several weeks later, we go back to get our fix. And, guess what, no, they're not taking it. Read the sign. %&*#!!! 

STUPID GROUPON and STUPID VALLARTA! Why would you sign up to offer it if you were no longer going to accept them?! $12 down the drain, which is not that big of a deal, but it's the principle. 

Thus, concludes, why I went on strike and have not been to Vallarta since. Not gonna lie, I still miss their tacos, but not enough to go back. This girl has principle, man.
author: Angela W.

description:
We dropped by here for the first time for lunch.  We each had four tacos which were delicious.  I had a chorizo, a carne asada, a carnitas and a chicken taco.  All four were just great!
We were going to save a couple to take home but they were so good, we ate all four on the spot.  This is a great, inexpensive place for tacos.
Now I want to try other items on the menu.
author: Philip C.

description: Best place ever!  The tacos are so goooddd. I love how you can control how much cilantro and onion you can put too! Definitely will come back and much recommended!
author: Alejandra T.

description:
Everyone (should) have their 3:30 am taco place. It may be close to home, or on the way back from your favorite bar. Ideally it should be cheap, appealing to the drunk palate and a fun place to bring friends. Taqueria Vallarta hits all of those notes.

At the same time, it is rare that I find myself visiting my last night taco place at noon for lunch. That's how great this place is. Buy three tacos, pay $8 bucks, and enjoy. Be careful with the haberno salsa, it will leave your mouth burning for quite sometime.
author: Jake B.

description: Its a good size burrito for its price. It opens late and you can go to this place instead of El Farollito to avoid the long line!
author: Cavin T.

description:
THE. BEST. TACOS.....EVER.

Late night munchies should definitely lead you here.
Tacos de buche and the tripas(crunchy goodness).
Indescribably incredible!
Really wish they opened one up in the South Bay that I could stalk on a consistent basis.
author: Tera S.

description:
Call us crazy!  We waltzed right past the taco bar and ordered combo plates.  5 minutes later, heaping plates of delish food arrived.  For me, the steak and prawns, for hubby, carnitas.  

The carnitas was better.  Crispy on the outside, moist, flavorful meaty chunks made it easy to enjoy our own perfectly-made tacos.  The steak was flap meat and they over-cooked it so dry and a bit flavorless, unfortunately.  Prawns, sautéed mushrooms, Mexican rice and refried beans, plus a refreshing green salad all made up for the steak.

Next time?  Tacos!!!
author: Lxs S.

description: If your Hungry and you want a meaty burrito. Get the all meat burrito for 7 bucks. No beans no rice just double meat guacamole sour cream and salsa. It's messy prepare to use 20 napkins but the best deal I've seen at any taqueria.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
AMBROSIAL TACOS!!!!! Live, love, Vallarta. Tacos are sublime. Haven't tried anything else there because I always get sidetracked by the tacos.

Cheap, quick, juicy.

Authentic. Imported from Christmas Island.* 

Not a great place for a date unless you're trying to impress him/her/phe with your earthiness and quirkiness. There are some indecent men here who will try to ask you out on dates late at night if yr as hot as these tacos.

Al Pastor is Al Master. Carne Asada is better than nada.
author: Mila K.

description:
Whenever we have a serious craving for tacos, we make a trip here.  It's the street style that we really enjoy...and the price is still ridiculously low at $1.75 each.  

Today we had the tripe, lengua and buche - the buche turned out to be our favorite as it was super tender.  Lengua was good and the tripe was just a bit dry...but an easy fix with some toppings and hot sauce.

We also had a super burrito with carnitas at $5.95.  It was not bad - it was with whole beans, we really like refried beans in our burrito.  We didn't find any hot salsa and only very little avocado.  

The horchata is still tasty.  The bottled coke is always a good choice and I noticed they have the old style bottled Fanta orange soda!  I will have to try next time.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Yum yum!!!  My best taco tuesday yet was had at this amazing taqueria.  It's your typical hole-in-the-wall taco place, though the space is quite large and roomy.  The meat in the tacos are grilled to perfection (I had both the carnitas and the carne asada, both of which were delicious) and the DIY topping bar is easy and fun.  The salsas were delicious!

Being from out of town, I haven't tried too many other tacos in the SF bay area, but I can say that these were better than the ones I had at El Farolito in the Mission and Mexcal Taqueria in Menlo Park.  But all of them are of a quality I can only dream of getting (for the price) in Pittsburgh!
author: Ran L.

description: Best tamales in the Bay Area! There's a lady standing at a table when you walk in that sells hot corn on the cob and tamales. They have cheese w/pepper(and it's not over cheesy), pork, chicken, and some desert tamales strawberry or pineapple. SOOO GOOD. we are done searching for where to go for tamales now. The tamale table is only open 6pm to 11pm.
author: Nikki P.

description:
4 stars for the tacos. We had the lengua, chorizo, and al pastor. All were delicious and for $1.75 each. The tacos are made fresh with the soft tortilla warmed in front of you and the D.I.Y. condiment station (includes cilantro, radish, onions, lime) at your disposal.

I also ordered the shrimp burrito. It was good but not spectacular. For the shrimp burrito, I'd hop on over to El Farrolitos. But for the soft tacos, I'd definitely come here!
author: Elaine T.

description: The tacos here a second to none. They have a wide variety of meats right by the entrance and the smell just draws you in. Theres the typical al pastor, pollo, and carne asada but theres also tripe, head, and other goodies you should try. The food taste amazing. The only down side is that the tacos themselves are a little pricey. Around $2.50 a pop. That can really add up
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
OH MAN 

What an amazing place. Only a couple blocks from the BART station and it smells great. The aroma from the taco bar is tantalizing. Came here with my brother. I got the carnitas and the lengua taco. Loaded it up with the 3 different salsas. They were all very good and delicious. The lengua was nice and tender. Good meaty flavors. The carnitas was even better. Porky, fatty and full of delicious flavor. Ugh and the carnitas went very very well with the lime and the salsa. So good. Kinda pricey though. 2.25 per taco, but still very very delicous!

5/5 coming back to try the other meats!!!
author: Ernest C.

description: Tacos are the best. Al Pastor is the best.
author: Alex C.

description:
I came in here starving after working a 12 hr shift and about to start an extra overnight shift and I was so hungry I didn't even know what I wanted. The guy was super helpful and set me up with a big carne asada plate and chips and a pineapple drink and I think I'm ready to tackle my next shift! 

Everything is tasty and the people there are super nice. Definitely gonna come by again.
author: Aimee P.

description: I've had great experiences here way in the past but recently I went here and I'm sure that I'll never go back. I have a problem with spicy food, and my throat closes up if I eat it. I asked them not to put and spicy sauce or tomatoes on my burritos in which they did by accident. Totally fine. But when I went back to ask them to remake it and apologized for the convenience the lady scowled at me and said something along the lines of "stupid b****" in Spanish not knowing I knew what she had said. She threw the new burrito onto my table, which I'm pretty sure she probably spit in or something so I just left it. Super sad this was my absolute favorite place to get Mexican food despite my food intolerance. Customer service goes a long way you guys. I'll take my money elsewhere thanks
author: Shayna S.

description:
Immediately upon entrance, overpoweringly aromatic waves of charbroiled meat emanating from the grill directly to the right begin remorselessly beating down on your nostrils.  Before halfway reaching the register to consider menu options, you powerlessly return and dutifully join the line for the taco cart, anxiously awaiting your turn.

Only the meat you select is placed on the twin-layered tortillas, giving you free rein to heap on cilantro, onions, lime, radishes, and salsa.  The lengua suffers from being imprisoned too long on the grill - most likely to retain its warmth, and lacks the juiciness typical of the meat.  However, the flavoring holds strong and is enhanced by the fresh-off-the-grill taste.  Although the tortillas are heated on the grill as well, the outer layer remains limp - you can probably ask for them to be left on the grill longer.

$1.75 for a taco is on the pricier end, but with Taqueria Vallarta's ample seating, limitless toppings, and well-stocked napkins, the taco cart is ultimately satisfying.
author: Andrew M.

description: We came here for a quick bite after touring Balmy Alley. This is a no frills taqueria that reminded me of those cheap taco stands in Mexico. The tacos were cheap (a little over $1), delicious, and fresh. What more do you want????
author: Michael J.

description: The tacos here are the best I've had in San Francisco. When you walk in, there is a huge frying pan where all the meats are sectioned off and cooking. I had the carnitas, pollo, and barbacoa and they were all amazing. There are multiple hot sauces to choose from - the habanero is crazy hot. Definitely come here if you are looking for a quick bite, affordable ($2.50 per taco), and super flavorful food!
author: Emmy Q.

description:
Overall, Taqueria Vallarta is a 3-star joint.  Yes, the tacos are delicious and worthy of 4 stars, but everything else is just mediocre. 

Tacos!  Don't waste stomach space on anything else.  We were with a big group, so in addition to tacos, we also got a burrito and a quesadilla.  No bueno.

Line up and order 3-5 tacos.  When your tacos are done, be careful, the plate is HOT!  Then smother your taco with as much of the 3-4 salsas offered.  Then, throw on top as much cilantro and onions as your little heart desires.

Then, go pay and maybe, just maybe get some juice.
author: Christina L.

description:
The lack of meat in my tacos was embarrassing. It's like I ordered plain corn tortillas with some carnitas garnish. 

Looking around, the Latino folk who got tacos definitely got their money's worth of meat. Sucks!
author: Andy C.

description:
I've been to a lot of taqueria joints in the city, and I have to say that this place is my absolute favorite. For awhile, I used to goto El Farlito to get tacos, but after having Taqueria Vallarta's, boy, I was hooked! Their tacos are actually cheaper than El Farlito's and taste 10x better, which should give you every reason to come here! 

This place has their own taco bar which is separate from the counter that makes the burritos. The taco bar also has your condiments ready right in front if the grill. Most taqueria places in the city put all the ingredients on your taco for you, with this place, you can put however much condiments you want, which is really nice because you can either be greedy with the salsa or really generous with it. 

Try this place!
author: Jason D.

description: Good tacos made quickly and reasonably priced. The dining area is big but untidy. The restaurant is warm and stuffy. That said, the ambiance is exactly what it should be and I'd come back for a quick taco anytime.
author: Kim K.

description: Whoa - this is our new go to spot for great Mexican food in our hood. My wife loved the tacos and I was in bliss with my enchilada combo plate. Only criticism is the place could be a little cleaner, and if the owner sees this, PLEASE provide better quality plastic utensils! The ones you have are too small and too flimsy.
author: Michael L.

description: This place is awesome - really complete menu of all kinds of Mexican stuff and a super cool taco bar in front - feels like street food but inside
author: David G.

description:
Pros
- Tripita
-al pastor
- horchata 

Just ok
- lengua 
- carnitas


Sidenote: 
- salsa is mad spicy, dark red = flaming hot
- awesome that you can add your own toppings (cilantro, onion, lemon,salsa)
author: Michelle D.

description:
Lengua super burrito? YES PLEASE! 

Taqueria Vallarta definitely makes a killer good lengua burrito. Only thing I wished they had? Pickled jalapeños and carrots! That would've made my meal complete w/ my horchata!
author: Jeanette Y.

description: I cannot even begin what to say about Vallarta's. This is by far the best taco shop in SF hands down! My boyfriend introduced me to this place. And ever since, no other tacos compare. So fresh, so cheap. Can it get any better? YES it can, they also sell elote. Not just on a cob either. In a cup!! And this place is open late. Yes it's pretty corwded at times. Yes it has bums walking in and out of here. But oh well, they're tacos are worth it! Carne Asada and al Pstor are my favorites. 2 of each and a cup of elote please!
author: Dara S.

description:
This is an awesome joint for a late night taco fix. Everything is good here. I usually go for a mix of asada and carnitas tacos. They're really efficient and the line moves quickly.

It gets crowded, but there's usually enough seating as the place is pretty big inside. I love all the murals on the walls.
author: Kenny J.

description:
I was in there last week. I came for the sesos. I mean, I picked that place over  alluhhhh the other taquerias in the area. 

The guy said that they hadn't served sesos for over a year and a half. :(

I've never tried cow brain. I might be obsessed a little. :|

I ordered 3 cabeza tacos instead. I ate two and bagged (for next-day-eats) the last one. I've never had a bad experience with cabeza, anywhere, so a 'star' is not warranted here for good meat.

I would've given 5 stars if the red salsa wasn't so salty. Like r-e-a-l-l-y salty. The green sauce was lovely and you certainly can't beat the price of $1.75/taco.

However, I'd a rather pay a bit more for killer condiments.

I'm giving the spot 3.8 stars because they offer whole wheat tortillas. My Kid got a super carne asada burrito and he was very happy with it.

I'll be back in San Francisco tomorrow. I wish that I could say that I'll be re-visiting this place but I can't... 

I'm still searching for a brain. 

Wait, I didn't try the suadero. Maybe, I'll come in for just one taco. :)

Another review might be in the works. ;)
author: Judith E.

description:
Having lived in Austin TX and having spent a fair amount of time around border towns and Northern Mexico, I think I have pretty high expectations for the taco.  Like many simple dishes of humble origins, it is theoretically easy to execute but in practice it is usually not done well.  Taqueria Vallarta meets all the checklist items for a taco place

  Small corn tortillas.  The need to be small so the resulting taco is not unwieldy and so that you can eat many tacos with a variety of fillings. 
  Many meat choices.
  Fresh condiments: Lime, onion, cilantro, multiple salsas. The only thing it lacks is pickled carrots/onion

The only thing missing from an otherwise perfect place is the charcoal vertical rotisserie for al pastor.  But hard to imagine in SF.  It would also be great if they had Topo Chico. 

There is more than just a taco bar so anyone that wants good mex can find something they like. I think they have some vegetarian items too.  If you just want tacos, order at the taco bar up front and pay there.
author: Alan B.

description:
Fellow Yelpers, I have some important news from little me to every single one of you.

Taqueria Vallarta is OPEN! 

BEST Carnitas, Tacos al Pastor, and Chorizo tacos in SF! Just like Mexico. 

DIY add ons--cilantro, onions, raddish, and sauces 

Only $1.75 each. 

Delicioso, Si! 

So like CT L. says: get your sexy butt and bmw (bart-muni-walk) down here rapido!
author: Stephanie M.

description: My son and I decided on a trip to San Francisco after taking my daughter to work in San Ramon. We walked for a while on Mission trying to decide where to eat Menudo, this place caught our attention with a sign  " vegetarian burritos".  We thought we would share a burrito and  a bowl of menudo. We ordered #4, vegetarian burrito, we didn't realize it would include rice and beans, be sure to clarify that when ordering as we didn't want beans and rice. First of all our burrito was made with a plain flour tortilla but we ordered it be made with a spinach tortilla , not what we ordered. The menudo was awful, tasteless, too many big bones, not good at all. I would not recommend this place and we will not return. Not a pleasant experience.
author: Sandy L.

description:
This is my go to burrito place, and luckily its just around the corner. 
I have been coming here for about 5 years, the quality is always consistent and the front desk people are always nice.
author: Michael C.

description:
I found this place on TV, I think it was "Check Please Bay Area". Went last night for the first time. WOW. Amazing, authentic and solid Mexican food. I loved the taco bar and the tacos are every bit as good as El Tonayense's.
For my meal I tried the carnitas dinner, which was fantastic. They have a great vegetarian burrito menu so I am looking forward to bringing my plant eater wife here. Can't wait to return.
author: Matt H.

description:
