I hail from So Cal as a tried-and-true Angeleno, so I have obnoxiously high standards when it comes to Mexican fare because come on and bitch please.  Anyway, this place is the aces.  It passed multiple litmus tests on my end - tests so personal and subjective as to be ultimately meaningless to anyone that's not me, but you should really just take my word for it.  The horchata here is rich and creamy, and aptly accented in all of the right places.  The glorious taco stand posted out front, with numerous meat offerings and accoutrements for days, offers up some of the most delicious and authentic-tasting tacos I've ever had for just $2/pop.  The cabeza (beef head) and lengua (beef tongue) both make my spirit sing!  

 The pozole is also another shining star here.  The slow braised pork shoulder is melty, fall-off-the-bone, and gnarly fatty perfection - the way that pork is intended to be consumed.  Back when I had little reason to live and got blackout drunk every other day - this was truly one of my favorite hangover cures.

However, I think one of my favorite things here (and really, not just from here - but like, of all time) is the "San Francisco Plate."  It is a real monstrosity, like a 10-pound plate of grilled white fish and prawns and football-sized oysters, all seasoned with the most delicious red chili sauce and littered with fresh orange and avocado slices.  It is absurdly priced at $12.50, and probably one of the best deals in the city should you be craving some crayzay delicious seafood.  Really, give it a try and you shan't be disappointed.
author: Anna C.

description:
Taco stand didn't look like much, you add your own cilantro, lime, chili, and onions, but OMG they were so good. I tried barbacoa and al pastor, both were bomb. Also I was seduced by the Esquites sold by the tamale lady and ordered them, and although I was overly stuffed after that my craving was satisfied. Also bought a queso tamale and ate it for breakfast the next day at work, it was really good with a  big slice of poblano tucked inside. With the meal I got the pina aguas fresca which was also housemade and really great. 

Also, they had cool  SF/Jalisco themed murals and wide open seating area which was nice. I imagine this place is good for pseudo open air seating during summer, but can't speak to that since I was here in Jan.

This place was also very affordable.
author: Lily G.

description: Damn these tacos are amazing ! Street tacos done so right ! Knowledgable staff ! Not the most friendly group but I totally  don't care! I'm impressed and I'll be back!
author: Kyle H.

description:
I was parked and used Yelp to find a good mex in the hood. Low and behold, it gave reviews for T.V. and it was right across the street. I was wowed by their Taco cart.
I ordered 3 different ones. The bbq pork was too sweet but the chicken was crazy good.
My husband loved the beef too.
author: P G.

description:
This is real Mexican Tacos!
Great meats and prepped in front of you!  Condiments do not include creams and guacamole because you don't need it!  Los tacos de Cabeza y lengua son los mejores!  Que he probado!
author: Curtis L.

description: This place was good. There are several other Mexican places around this one, I've tried them all and this place is my favorite. Very authentic tasting.  I had the cheese enchiladas plate and it came with rice and beans. If definitely go back!
author: Yisel F.

description: Tacos! The tacos are $2.25 each and they serve all kinds of meat. I ordered tender beef and al pastor then I layered it with onions, cilantro, lime juice and salsa. I've had better from a food truck and I'm totally judging by the meat quantity. I also ordered elote in a cup. It was decent and there was nothing to rave about. It's a chill spot and food always comes out fast.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
There's hardly a time when I am thinking of what I want to eat and it isn't tacos from Vallarta. They're the perfect meal! I usually start with five tacos and I tend to stick to whatever is heated in the circular grill thing because the meats have better texture than the ones steaming on the side. Aside from the lengua anyway. Super tender! 

Carne asada, pollo asada, and suadero are all solid choices as well, but my all time favorite has to be the tripita. They're chopped to 1-2 inch pieces and fried crispy. So much pork flavor!
author: Peter M.

description:
Tripita tacos, love the chewy, gamy meat combined with onions, lime and cilantro. Funky goodness in a taco. Salsa is spicy, perfect with the organ meats. Haven't tried a taco i didn't like. Fast and cheap, $2/apiece and two will do ya. 

Restaurant is dirty, but the taco cart is fresh and tasty. Try it!
author: Kelly K.

description: For me, Taqueria Vallarta has the best Taco in SF Bay Area. It has some meat that are hard to found in most other average Mexican restaurants.
author: Z L.

description:
How many places have an autentico taco cart inside the restaurant?  And that is the reason to go to Taqueria Vallarta.  

You can skip the main food line and get some amazing tacos from the cart near the front door.  The tripa was especially sabrosa.  All the condiments are there, down to the sliced radish (:-)), and salsas are all excellente.
author: Bob K.

description:
I was out in the mission district and wanted to try some Mexican Food and my friend and I stopped in to Taqueria Vallarta. when we got there no one was in line and was not very busy. I decided to try the Campechana. Wrong choice to order this. Im not sure what took so long however it took about 30 minutes to get my meal. the meal was not good at all. the campechana had a lot of sea shells from something and made it hard to eat. It did not taste fresh at all. I will not come back here again. 

I quick other note. they had a Taco cart at the entrance and it looked very popular as I was walking out. At that point they had a like out the door. if this is what they cater to the most and are successful they should take items off the menu that they cant prepare well.
author: JC L.

description:
Best place to get tacos in the Mission. Cheap, quick, authentic, open late. Colorful decor is a bonus.

Get the atole from the woman with the giant pot. Warms you up on a cold night.

Discount for paying cash.
author: Jeff C.

description:
I generally dislike Mexican food. Yes, yes, even El Farolito, I don't like. Gracias Madre? No me gusta mucho. I do not like beans, I do not like sour cream on my food, I have zero interest in guacamole, and I find it annoying to have to learn the difference between taco, quesadilla, and burrito, when, according to some comedian, they're all basically the same --- wheat dough with cheese in it (if you disagree, that's because the joke was only supposed to sound funny the first time). 

Yet this place has had me come back three times in 2 weeks! Somehow, they have found the right combo in everything they make for me. I had the super burrito w/ carne the first two times, and quesadilla deluxe (forgot the proper name, the one with tons of meat/shrimp in it) the third. The food is rich but not greasy, filling but not too heavy. Somehow...it got the balance of different ingredients, just right. Not too much of anything, but everything you want is there.

And the spicy sauce. OMG THE ORANGE SPICY SAUCE!!!!! It is spicy. Like, real spicy. Like, super addictively good spicy. It makes everything 10X more tasty. The first time I was here they ran out of the sauce, and I still liked the food enough to come back. The second time I got the sauce, and that solidified my love for this place.

And it's also obvious to say, this place is cheap. Delicious and cheap...just the way good food should be! It also opens late, another boon for me who is often hungry at 10PM after a good evening of solid rock climbing.

Next time I want to come try the breakfast burrito. The friend who brought me here in the first place swears by it. Just thinking about it makes me excited!
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Love this place! I tried a lot of things from their menu, and they were all delicious!
I'd give 5 stars if the tables were a bit more cleaner.
author: Frank C.

description: Pretty good but I would say it's a Tier 2 Mish burrito. Had the super carne asada. Pretty cheesy.  Size was good (not too big/not too small). Both the Tortilla and meat were average.
author: Tom F.

description: I've been going here for 5+ years ever since I moved to SF for college. It never disappoints and worth the trip out to the mission. Although the tacos were not as cheap as they were when I first started going, inflation is inevitable. I bring all my friends who visit and even residents that have never been and they walk away satisfied and full. I mainly go here for the tacos, but their burritos and quesadillas are yummy too.
author: Ashley P.

description:
TLDR Worth the late night trip for some authentic tacos! My favorite was the cabeza, put lots of onions/cilantro on it.

I love this place! First of all they're open super late (3:30am on weekends) so its the perfect adventure destination after finishing a problem set and we're craving some good tacos!

I pretty much only come here for the taco bar which is usually $2/taco. They have many choices of meats then you can grab some onion, cilantro, salsa and limes yourself. My favorite here was definitely the cabeza. It was so tender and flavorful, a must try! If you're squeamish then look up what it is after you've tried it, you'll definitely enjoy it. The lengua and carnitas were also really good. 

I've also gotten the elote once, it was packed with cheese and Chile's and who knows what else. It was really good, but I don't know if they have it everyday.
author: Anthony K.

description: This place has the most amazing fish tacos that I have ever tasted truly no other place can compare. Also, there is a "salsa" bar and free chips with every meal. It cannot get any better
author: Rukayatu T.

description: Tacos used to be great but now tastes dirty. No amount of freshly cut cilantro and onion can disguise the obviously  several-day-old, meat tendons that have been stewing in lard and gritty things. Crusty birds wander about as they please, and I saw a man steal the garbage can.
author: Louise L.

description:
Did a groupon here. $15 for 30. Used my first $5 for 10. Overall quite dissatisfied. First and foremost, the service I received was horrible. I am a very openminded person and don't get easily offended at restaurants. I felt the cashier person, who took my order, was rude and unprofessional. I felt like they didn't really want my business. FYI, this was before I said I had the groupon, so had nothing to do with groupon. 

Then ordered a carnitas taco. It came with literally just carnitas in a (soft) taco shell, even though it was supposed to come with all the other fixings. I never said "no" on the other fixings. The carnitas itself tasted decent, hence the "two stars" instead of just one star.

The super burrito was boring. The carne asada chewy. Couldn't find any guac/avocado even though it says it comes with it. I asked for black beans and got pinto. Don't even know if they offer black beans but they didn't say no when I ordered them and didn't get them.

The bathroom smelt semi decent, which I wasn't expecting given my overall experience. So this helped the 2 star rating. On the other hand, a drunkard walked in and left the door open while he urinated while I awaited my food. Not really complaining about this, since it can be expected given the positioning of this place where it is on Mission.

I don't really want to come back for my other two 5 for $10 coupons. If I'm in the area I'll perhaps use it. Maybe. Only if I'm there, close, and really hungry.

Again, 2 stars for the carnitas being OK and not a nasty bathroom - and one more thing, I appreciate they have a salsa bar and gave me chips without extra cost.
author: Bret G.

description: Truly unique place. Ceiling and walls with murals and added little balcony. Very diverse clientele, wildly packed on a weekend. As non Hispanics it took us some time to figure out, how the place even operates. There are two counters with short lines, we chose the back one, ordered a cactus burrito and chicken enchiladas. We were charged, got no receipt, no number would be called, got chips and salsa and upon asking were told to look for a table. We did and basically disappeared in the crowd. They did find us with no detour and served the food. I admit to limited competence on judging this kind of food, but I had absolutely no complaints and I haven't had better either. This is not your romantic candlelight dinner venue, its buzzing with real life. On other tables we saw leftovers of very sophisticated seafood servings and the board promises vast selection. But ordering seafood here demands a prerequisite of two years Spanish I would venture to guess. It's in the real non touristy original Mexican 24th St neighborhood between Mission and Potrero.
author: Mr G.

description:
One of the many taquerias along 24th, but the food here is pretty good compared to the others.

When you walk in, immediately to your right is a taco bar. It's a pretty good deal at $2 per taco. Further in is the counter where you can order other food. I usually get a burrito, and they give you plenty of options. Once in a while I get the wet burrito, which is just a regular burrito with hot sauce poured over it, or I'll get an entree (the carnitas plate is amazing). They're both pretty big and I usually can't finish either of them in one sitting so I save some for later.

The downside of this place is the cleanliness. Pigeons frequently fly in here and nothing is ever done about getting them to go back outside so you might have birds flying around you while you eat. I don't see staff wiping tables that often either. Luckily for me I usually take my food to go.
author: Allen C.

description:
Was on a mission to go to Mission to get my grub on. I was thinking something fancy but hey, the smell of tacos and horchata lured me into this charming little taqueria! 

The place is fairly clean but come on. Maybe it's just me but the messier the place, the better the tacos. Sure I don't want to see little critters running around all over the place but seriously, what do you expect from HOLE IN THE WALL restaurants? If tacos were served at fancy restaurants, I'd seriously question the taste of em.

Anyway, the two of us had a FEAST for less than $15. I'm talking about tacos galore, horchatas, and chips with salsa! Heaven. In. My. Mouth. 

I ordered al pastor and carne asada and I'll tell ya ... the meat was SO tender, I swear I could swim through them. Heck, I wanted to just take a bath in them. 

I know I'm not painting a very attractive, appetizing picture so I'll stop it right there. But I'm telling you... with all of these reviews, I'm not hyping anything up. Cute neighborhood, fantastic tacos, cool bars around the area for some BEER'IN (yes its a verb!) -- why WOULDN'T you make the trip to visit this shop?

Next time I go up north, I am getting some tacos here ASAP. And you know what? That's saying a lot because I'm taco-spoiled down here in LA. So do with that what you will! ;)
author: Stace K.

description: Below average taqueria. Their only condiment is salt. The place is dirty and the neighborhood unsafe. Horrible food!
author: Raymond F.

description: Tripa!!!!!! Great place after a wild and alcohol filled night. You can count on them loaded up with various meats on their taco bar. Best salsas in town hands down. If you can handle the heat, try the habanero orange salsa hidden away in the back of restaurant.
author: Vic A.

description: Loved it! Fresh, traditional, and delicious. We grabbed a couple of quick tacos after eating at a fancy place where the menu did not meet our standards.awesome that it's right here in the neighborhood. Nine bucks for for tacos. Will definitely go back.
author: Jackie N.

description: 5 stars for the best vegetarian burrito in the mission: their grilled veggie burrito. They also have quite the selection of other veggie burritos, I think 8 or so with different veggies. I get mine super. Pretty pricey for a mission burrito = $9.50 or so, but could last you two meals.
author: San D.

description: Got a bit of a buzz going? Check. Need a late-night snack that's not a giant bacon-wrapped hot dog? Yes. $2 street tacos? Done. These guys stack your tacos with so much meat that you can't wrap the tortilla around it. Sooo perfect and juicy. Of course, it's the perfectly moist and mildly spicy al pastor or nothing, but if you go with anything else, you can't go wrong because the comal helps all the meats soak up the juices from each other, as does the soft tortilla as it's slapped down in the middle of the comal. And, this place is open until 3:30am on weekends. Killer. This place is still bomb after so many years. I'm almost hesitant to write this update because the lines have gotten much longer in the past couple of years, but Yelp is for sharing.
author: Danny C.

description:
This is an amazing taqueria. They have a separate taco bar so you don't have to stand in the general line. The tacos are delicious! Plus they are pretty cheap so its a win-win situation.They also have an order section in the back where you can order burritos, quesadillas, etc.  I've also had their quesadilla and it was really good as well :)

Overall, the food and the prices were amazing. So, this place definitely deserves the 5 stars.
author: Kate G.

description:
dirty restaurant and dirty bathroom without soap...

came with a groupon and they would not honor it. they gave us a hard time trying to use it.  they said it was expired when in fact it was on the day it was expiring, it was not expired yet. they were not very welcoming or friendly once they knew we had a groupon. if you don't want groupons they don't have one.

ug, so frustrating... thanks for nothing...
author: Elaine Y.

description: Yummy tacos from the taco bar. They have like 10 types of meat you can choose from! At $2.50 a taco, it's perfect for a quick, cheap meal. The place is kind of dingy, but the food definitely makes up for it.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
The tacos are still fantastic. Why anyone would order anything different here is beyond me. I mean, you're watching them get made right in front of you!

Still, my dearest gal pal came here with me a while back and ordered a burrito. A burrito! Can you believe it?! The balls on that woman! 

Anyway, she said she liked it but I maintain that it is the tacos that reign supreme here.
author: Loli L.

description:
This place serves pretty authentic tacos. These are the kind that Mexican families have at their parties. This place does not have fish, sour cream, lettuce, tomato, rice, beans in their tacos. Feel free to top your taco with cilantro, lemon/lime, chile, onions, and radish. It really helps bring out the flavors

I recommend carne asada, lengua (beef tongue), and tripita. Minus one star for the dining area's filthiness.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Some friends introduced me to this hidden gem awhile back. And this place is now my  go to joint when I need my taco fix.  

Menu: Tripas (tripe), pork cheek, pork head, chicken, chorizo, beef, carnitas, you name it, they got it! 

Put your own topping and sauce and chow down! Chips and Salsa not included. 

My favorite will have to be Tripas, must try and Crazy delicious!
author: Christina W.

description: Anything you get from the taco stand is going to be legit. Special shout out to the al pastor.
author: Alex S.

description: solid veggie tacos love the black beans, great agua fresca on a hot day. Men love the meat bar tacos ;-)
author: Coco J.

description: Most authentic Mexican style tacos in SF!  Felt like I was in Mexico at a taco street vendor!  Yum!!!
author: Dave C.

description: A decent taco bar to rock out some cheap 4th meal late on a Saturday night.  We had two al pastor and two carne asada tacos, and they were pretty tasty.  The place is well lit, which is nice considering most of the clientele is most of the way hammered by 11pm.  One guy was just dancing up a storm...okay, more like drunkenly swaying around...to whatever music was playing in the background, so +1 for the entertainment factor.  If you love people watching, this place doesn't disappoint.
author: Kevin K.

description:
Best authentic tacos in SF. Usually I have to travel outside the city to get a full range of my favorite off-cut meats: buche, tripas, cabeza. Vallarta has them all. 

The charm of the grill up front can't be understated. It also makes the tacos come out fast since they're not bottled up behind a burrito line. 

The salsas are tasty but it was only after a tip from a friend that I noticed that the salsas by the tacos and those in the back near the main line are quite different. Definitely try them all.
author: Sam P.

description: Coming from LA this spot is the closest to home. It's cheap, fast and so good. The best in the bay in my opinion. I haven't had anything else other then their tacos but i would definitely go back and try their burritos.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Stopped by here after our bread-making class in the mission looking for a quick bite. Tastes just like the fresh tacos in Mexico! Fresh onions, cilantro, salsa with just cooked carne asada and carnitas on corn tortillas!
author: Marisa L.

description: I ordered a shrimp burrito and my boyfriend got four tacos and a horchata, then I asked for a horchata too. We paid. I asked the drink girl for a horchata. She told me to wait. She seemed quite rude. Another couple asked for one as well. They added more ice and condensed milk and mixed. When they were done, the girl gave the other couple their drink first, although I asked first... When it was my turn, she asked me for money for the drink, but I told her I already paid, so she handed me the drink. I don't know what I did, but she rolled her eyes at me. The horchata tastes way too grainy, I ended up drinking water instead. One of the people I was with ordered a chorizo burrito and they some how didn't get the chorizo in there...
author: Judy T.

description: I used to really like this place but was so disappointed when I went this weekend. The service was fast but the woman cashier was rude. I tried to over look this but my friend who lives nearby agreed. The burrito was good but not worth the 8.65 plus the unpleasant service.
author: Tami N.

description:
This is my go to spot for late night Mexican food in SF. If you just want tacos, stand in line at the doorway. But if you want everything else, just bypass the line and head straight to the register to order.

The 24th St location is much better than the Mission locations in my opinion (which probably explains why they seem to usually have more people eating there than the others).
author: Benjamin B.

description: Great tacos, the taco bar is cool where u can choose to put onions, radishes, and your choice of salsa. Also very cheap!!
author: Kenjo H.

description:
Quite a experience unlike other any other Taqueria in town. El Faro Lito usually hits the spot for me, but decided to venture out to try a new place -- Taqueria Vallarta, turned out to be a new, tasty, and adventurous experience!

Here are the 4 types of $1.50 tacos that I've tried -
-Carne Asada - 3/5, was a little tough for my taste
-Pollo - 5/5, hit the spot just right
-Carnitas - 5/5, great balance between other types of meat options
-Al Pastor  -  3/5, like the carne asada, this was a bit tough to chew

I'll be back to try all of the other varieties that they offer here! See you another day Taqueria Vallarta!
author: Ming S.

description:
Taco bar!!! Tacos cooked to order-- everything from carne asada to barbacoa, carnitas... everything you could ask for. Seriously, if you want to get tacos in the mission, come here. The suadero taco is out of this world, and all of the salsas are delicious. And at 2 dollars a taco, I leave with my wallet not too much lighter and my stomach stuffed and happy. I love this place.

It's a dive, don't expect much in that way -- but this is my go to taco place.
author: Erica W.

description:
Super good & cheap tacos! (Price slowly going up, though!)

Also really good Super Burrito (get black beans for extra goodness).

Really nice workers!
author: Jack K.

description:
My dear friend brought me here coz she knows I like tacos!  
We didn't go to the main place, we just went to the guy serving strictly tacos.  We got tacos!!!  Lamb! yummmmm
So reminds me of Mexico.  

I love the diversity of people who come here.  Must come here!
author: Claire J.

description: Dissapointed.  Lengua (tongue) is NOT supposed to be chewy and cut into little squares as if it were tofu.  Meat itself had no flavor.  Granted, Mexican food when it's greasy can be yummy, but if they managed to make the meat more flavorful mines the grease, then it would be much better.  We were VERY surprised his place had such high reviews.
author: Rosa G.

description:
I love their tacos! They were so meaty and scrumptious! They were very generous with the carne asada. It was a little tough but it was definitely flavorful!

I'm a huge fan of rice but I didn't really care for theirs nor their beans. Both of them were kind of bland!

At the time we went, we didn't have any problems with parking or a place to sit. Other times, I know this place can get packed!
author: Monica R.

description:
How do you beat cheap, cheap tacos?  Well, you can't really...you just eat them!  Stopped in during my trip to Humphry Slocombe around the corner, and the first thing that jumps out about the place is their taco bar...mainly because the line of people getting tacos blocks the door.  Since the taco bar sits literally next to the front door, you have to pass up the smell of grilled meats to get inside, and obviously the people in front of us just couldn't do it.  And neither did I.

At $1.50 a pop for "street tacos", these babies are definitely some budget friendly bites.  They have about a half dozen meats to choose from, and I went with a carne asada (a true test of tacos for me) and a chorizo taco to mix it up a bit.  The meat is flavorful and seasoned well, so you're not going to have to worry about some bland meat.  I was more impressed by the chorizo than the carne asada though - the beef was tasty but didn't stand out as much as the chorizo did compared to what I've had in the past.  Being street tacos, you literally get just the meat and the tortilla taco skins, but they have an assortment of sauces to drizzle on the meat as well as some other condiments.

Now, I have no idea how any of their other items are (I saw a couple of families chowing down on some burritos), but it may not even matter for the future for me...I'll just stick with the tacos.
author: Mike L.

description: I go to this restaurant often because I work on 23rd so I am at pretty close to this restaurant. I must agree with most of the reviews I have seen, this place is somehow expensive, especially for the type of food they serve.  However, I must also say that they do have the best tacos.  The sauces they have are by far the best ones, it's as good as other Mexican restaurants that are known due to their sauces, not only they are juicy and fresh, they are also unique and delicious.  One of the things that I also like about this place is that even though they are always busy most of the times they still figure out how to get the food within minutes of taking the order, usually not more than 5 minutes, so there is no need to wait much time.  I appreciate this restaurant and the staff members, when I am in a mood for mex food I do not think about it even for a minute and I go to this restaurant.
author: Serge B.

description:
GROSS. 

I have lived in San Francisco since I was born at Saint Luke's, and I take immense pride in our mexican food, from the wonderful street corner mexican trucks (ask them to mix their 2 salsas) to places with a nation wide reputation like Farolito on 24th and mission (try their breakfast burrito before 6pm, its easily the best mexican food made in this country) , I enjoy it all, so when a friend recommended this place I had to give it a shot. 

HUGE MISTAKE. 

I got a quesadilla, something that is very challenging to fail, i mean up until then i had never had a bad quesadilla before, but that was about to change. 

I honestly wish they would've just spit in my face, I would have been slightly less offended. 

There was barely any cheese at all, the meat was chewy and unbearably tasteless, and the whole thing was fit between two small, burnt tortillas that were just about too crunchy to qualify as corn tortilla chips. It was like they charged 7 dollars for meat unfit for a dog to be added to the salsa and corn chips that a restaurant would have normally offered for free. The server was rude too, so maybe i did something to offend her, but i made no insulting comments, or really any comments towards her at all. 

It takes a lot to offend me, and this was it. I have been in this city for 23 years, and this is the only restaurant to give me something so vile. 

I wish I could give it zero stars.
author: Alex N.

description:
this place is pretty good. I come here for the street style taco bar. the plates are also quite tasty for a good price..

Its not that $8 quesadilla you get at off the grid from a roach coach that charges half that on the construction site.
author: forrest l.

description:
Say it with me now...

SwahhhhDehhhRohh!

In the midst of all the super burritos and all of the taquerias the Mission has to offer, I was fortunate enough to find tacos at Taqueria Vallarta. The first time I went I looked at the meat choices and thought to myself "what in the hell is suadero???"

There was a description at the front door that said "tender beef" and while that might usually be a good enough explanation for me, I was still curious. 

Wikipedia describes it as a "thin cut of beef from the meat that hangs from the breast bone on a cow." Another website describes it as "the intermediate part between the belly and the leg." Another website simply said it's "hip."

Yo, whatever cut it is... it's damn good! And that's all you need to know.

They got a little taco stand right in front ready to slang out tacos in a hurry. My usual order(s) are suadero, carnitas, pollo asada, barbacoa. I tend to stay away from chicken (at least when I'm trying to enjoy my food) because it can be less tasty as... I don't know... some braised pork butt! but the pollo asada is exceptional here. They also offer every other body part you can think of...

cabeza (head)
lengua (beef tongue)
tripa (beef stomach aka tripe)
cachete (cheek)
buche (pork neck)

... as well as your standard taqueria offerings...

enchiladas
super burritos
quesadillas
tortas
etc...

But i recommend the tacos. It's the best street taco I've had and at $1.75 a pop, the dollar doesn't get much stronger. Do yourself a favor and hit this place up. If you don't like it then you can punch me in the face... but something tells me you'll want to find me and give me a high five... or a hug, I'll accept either.
author: Brian L.

description: I went here for a late night snack boy it was good!! Go here for the tacos only $2.25 each. I had the pollo asado and added from the taco bar area the dark burgundy salsa which most likely was chipotle salsa but it was so good!! I just could not get enough of it! I say go here for the tacos plus open till 3:30 on a Saturday night that is a miracle in San Francisco. Sadly since the good late night eating joints have been disappearing
author: Nadia N.

description:
$1.75 street tacos, with all the other cuts of meat: suadero, buche, tripitas, lengua, cabeza, etc. 

You specify the meat and the lady heats up your tortillas. The toppings are DIY in front of the indoor cart.

I went overboard and had 6 tacos of the selections above plus an al pastor. Everything was tasty and well seasoned. Will be back for sure.
author: Derrick V.

description: Glorious taco bar, I work at a taco and burrito restaurant and will spend every work day for the rest of my time there trying to recreate these awesome traditional tacos...I left wishing I could fit 3 more tacos in
author: Christyn K.

description:
The chairs here are way too big. It's really hard to come here with a big group when you can't fit at the table. 

Other than that, I do like the food here. But you already knew that -- after all, this place has ~400 reviews. I'm just giving you the inside scoop: the chairs.
author: Huey K.

description:
Amazing tacos, I think they've topped the taco trucks (sorry tonayase) -- why? because their tacos are huuuuge, they're not stingy with the meat, and the salsa/condiments are self serve, so its really awesome. you can load up on whatever you like, or not. good chicken and carnitas. $1.50 each, can't get better than that.

if I come here often enough, maybe I'll master the art of eating an (on the verge of) exploding taco with grace and control of the fillings, one day. until then, I'll happily enjoy them with salsa dripping all over my hands and things falling out all over... don't expect me to be ladylike here. 

and try the champarrado too, a mexican cinnamon-ish hot chocolate-like drink. the lady in the back room serves it!
author: Jennie L.

description:
I hear the tacos are good, but this review is mostly for the vegetarian burrito I get pretty much every time I walk in (nothing special, just their plain veggie burrito). It absolutely hits the spot-- nicely flavored, especially with their paler green salsa, and has some avocado tucked in. Vallarta's open really late and really early, so it's great for lunch, dinner, drunken late-night snacking, or early-morning hangovers.

The tamale lady who is usually parked in the other entrance also has delicious vegetarian queso tamales with a chile stuffed inside. I take them home and put some Sriracha on them-- you can't make better Latino-Asian-American fusion. Only the Tamale Lady at Zeitgeist has better veggie tamales, but $5? Compared to $1.50 at Vallarta? There isn't even a contest here.
author: Bianca C.

description:
One of my favorite taco spots in the Mission! $1.75 a taco is a great deal, and the fact that I can still get it at 2 in the morning closes it.

There's lots of seating in a very open and spacious interior. They serve a lot of things, but I go here for the tacos. You just tell whoever's by the taco bar how many tacos you want and what kind of meat--super quick and simple. I'm a fan of the carnitas and carne asada--basic but delicious-- though you can try a bunch of other things from barbacoa to tripita.

You then pay by the cashier, and a plus here is that they take credit card and even American Express--rare in the Mission but great if its 2 in the morning and you're lost, drunk and cashless.
author: Phong Q.

description:
The perfect place for getting a full meal for under $5.  Get the tacos.

The burritos aren't bad.  The quesadillas aren't my favorite.  The tacos are what's up!!! 

This place is almost always packed, and has customers til they close at 2 am.  Definitely worth a visit!
author: Carolyn N.

description: $2 per taco is a good deal. You select the tacos that you want and add your own onion, cilantro, and salsa. It's super fast and good. I especially love their tongue taco here. It's very tender flavorful. Gotta get that here!
author: LZ T.

description:
Surprisingly not too busy on Cinco De Mayo. 

$1.75 tacos is where it's at from the little stand at the front. Service is really fast and I like that you add the cilantro, onions, lime, and salsas yourself. I went with my usual choice of meats: al pastor and carnitas. Both were really well seasoned, but for some reason the carnitas just came from a little metal bucket on the side of grill rather than fresh off the grill like the other meats, so it wasn't as piping hot.  I also tried the buche, which a friend suggested, and even though it wasn't exactly my cup of tea, it was still very tender with a nice chewy texture. 

Overall solid taqueria, too bad it's not as cheap as the $1.25 Oakland tacos... When you eat 6-7 for dinner, the difference adds up over time.
author: Tim W.

description:
Sorry about that confusion a few minutes ago.  That review update was strictly meant for this beautiful, dive-y, authentic, delicious establishment.  
I'll repeat what I said, and stand by it.  BEST STREET TACOS outside of Baja CA.  Thankfully since they reopened, they found a way to keep the friendly pigeons outside, where they belong, and where they can be fed by people who don't understand the reasons behind why we don't feed pigeons.

Back to Tacos.  Can you find me a better taco for under $2?  People have taken me all over the Bay, claiming their favorite place has the "like the best ones evarr."
Nay.  Taqueria Vallarta will shame you, and disrespect your recipe, in a smart and delicious fashion.  I beg you tell me where there are better tacos, in La Mission or not.

To the reader: Keep in mind, this review is based on TACOS alone. (price, quality, execution, flavor, aftertaste and later delicious burp-age are taken into effect when giving out stars.)
author: Joshua K.

description: Fresh food & just perfect . Hit the spot. Neighborhood Hotspot. Get there before 10:00 pm There might be a line out the door.
author: Angela G.

description:
So the way this places works is... you've got a stand for tacos and only tacos, then a stand for all else in the back and in between, you've got your corn/tamales lady. 

I've been here 2-3 times in 10 days.. and this place leaves me CRAVING! I've had their tacos particularly: carne asada, al pastor, and buche. The buche was good, although it could be seasoned a little more. The pastor wasn't like the pastor I've had at other places. The meat was extremely tender. Many other places I've been to had chunks of meat. ..But the clear winner was the carne asada. It is seasoned perfectly. It's the best I've had yet--both in NorCal and SoCal. I SO appreciate good, seasoned carne asada. Thank you Taqueria Vallarta for doin it right! When you've gotten your plate of tacos, the garnishes and such are right in front for you to pile on: limes, slice radish, onions (LOTS!), cilantro and three types of salsa. The only downside is that the tacos are $2. Pretty steep to me just because I'm used to paying for REALLY good tacos for 85 cents, but I don't mind the price enough to avoid eating here.

I also tried their chicken tamale. That was good, not the best, but good. The masa is moist and blended together perfect so that you don't get the grainy aftertaste. The chicken could've been seasoned more, but that's nothing a little salsa couldn't fix. I want to go back and try their pork tamale though. I'm salivating just thinking about it.

The horchata was perfect blend of creaminess and cinnamon--a definite must-have.

If you have card, you have to pay at the back counter. ...And how awesome is it that they take card!?

What I didn't like is that tortilla chips are a hit or miss. Some days with some ladies you'll get it for free.. Other days you'll get charged $1. It's not much, but I dislike the inconsistency. 

Their salsa is refreshing with the perfect amount of kick.

I'll be coming back every time I'm back up there. Thoughts of this place leaves me smiling. It's THAT good.
author: Zo T.

description:
Best taqueria in the mission for sure. The short chubby guy that works the taco cart a lot is funny. He doesn't give a sh@t about you.

They have really junky Chilaquiles that are excellent too, get them with the green sauce. It's great on Sunday morning when everyone else is waiting for ten years to eat at Bugaloo's.
author: Miles G.

description: This place does not only have one of the best salsa bars, they actually have some of the best tacos in sf.  It's like walking into the outside when you see the taco stand inside up front.  The only problem with this place is I can never make it past that delicious taco stand and order off the main menu in the back.  i think i would actually have to eat here 3 times in a day to get over my craving for those amazing tacos and finally order off the main menu.  until that day comes I can only give this place 4 stars, as i haven't been able to yet give the menu full enough scrutinity to award the coveted 5 stars.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Perfect taqueria. As in taco-store. Exclusively. Don't even worry about the other menu items, you're wasting your time.

I'm sure the burritos are fine, but why taste good when you could have glory? Thats like going to the movies, waiting in line and then leaving after the previews, or visiting San Francisco and wasting your time in Daly City. 

To be candid, I haven't given the other menu items multiple tries. Once I discovered the tacos I developed blinders. I see no reason to seek a chimerical sacred fruit when I've already discovered taco heaven.
author: Brandon C.

description: Ordered super burrito with steak. Just okay. Nothing special. Spicy with chunks of avocado. Inside has 3 stations, one is for tacos, the other is for tamales and corn and the main one is where you order the rest in the menu. Disorganized but whatever if you know your can learn the way around the restaurant then you should be fine. I won't order burrito again here.
author: J C.

description:
You cant go wrong with anything on this menu. Especially the lengua! but eveything is just amazing.  The salsas are all spicy enough for me which is rare since I have high tolerance for heat and usually find what others call spicy to be rather bland. Not here! perfect amount of spice to dress up your tasty morsels.  The lengua is superb.
cant wait to get back here.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Taco Bar!  Their Taco Bar is so good!!!!!
My Carne Asada Plate was just average.  Meat was tough and dry.  Everything else was good on my plate.  It came with many tortillas, rice, salad and refried beans.  Tried it because of the Groupon deal.  Next time, I'll skip the plates and go straight to the Taco bar!!!!!
author: Aban E.

description:
I had read great things but found the tacos average at best.  Maybe I need to try more on the menu?

The fact that they had a taco bar was pretty cool in itself though.
author: Kurosh H.

description:
You literally can't go wrong here. The taco bar is incredible, make sure you get try out a few and find your favorite. Pollo, Buche and Carne Asada are perfection. Choose the type of salsa to top it off (fun to mix and match to find the perfect combo) and chow down.

The burritos are also fantastic. The wet burrito is huge. Make two meals out of it of just shovel it in and call it a night. 

Make sure to get the chips and salsa. Their homemade chips are perfectly thin and crispy. 

No bells and whistles, just delicious food.
author: Daniel K.

description: The Yelp reviews looked good, so I went here.  SF health dept had it closed for two days.  Not sure if I want to go here now.
author: Abigail J. M. M.

description: I love this spot, which is just across the street from Alley Cat Books. I've been with large groups, with many newbies, and everyone loves the food. I always order from the grill near the door, where you get small soft taco shells and choose your meat; then you add lettuce, onions, lime, and different salsas as you like. I recommend the carne asada with lots of lime and the green salsa - so good! Some friends have ordered from the larger menu, which includes burritos and quesadillas, but those orders take much longer. I only wish the restrooms were a tad tidier, but of course I'm not there for the bathroom facilities. If you're in the area, check out this taqueria!
author: Kacy C.

description: The place is really big. I didn't like how the taco line was set up because it was split... half of us was inside and half of us was outside... so it didn't make sense. definitely get the carnita taco.. it's way better than the one that said tender beef... You'll thanks me later. Other than that, it was pretty cheap 2.25 a taco and they had the world series on.
author: Kenneth C.

description:
Best Tacos Ever, Nuff said. 

I have never tried anything else because I can't walk past the tacos without throwing my wallet at the poor soul serving them up as I scream "TAKE ALL OF MY MONEY!!!!!"
author: Danny S.

description: Taco bar! Very hot sauces. Great carne asado taco. The place is a bit basic and you seat yourself but it's an experience.
author: May C.

description: The Agua Frescas are amazing. Had the cantaloupe and it was awesome. Chicken tacos were amazing and fresh. I had a veg burrito with avocado so good and great prices
author: Maryam T.

description: I'm a taco fanatic and have lived in Mexico for a while. I was looking for authentic tacos in SF. The taco stand inside this place is amazing - the real deal. The Barbacoa tacos were delicious and very fairly priced at $2 per taco.
author: Thorben S.

description: Some seriously tasty carne asada action is served up here. Arriba!
author: D. R.

description: Do not purchase a Groupon for this place. They will not honor it. Just had the rudest most absurd experience there and I do not plan on ever going back again.
author: Crystal J.

description:
Initially I was completely lost  as to the setup of the taco stand and the order/cashier area.  I went up to the cashier to ask for tacos, she pointed me to the taco stand, I was confused....  I stood there, and there I got 5 soft tacos.. Still lost and confused, I eventually walked over to pay for it.  I could had walked out with them... Why would they put that taco stand near the entrance?  Where people can take them and leave....? Oh well, The taco was good, juicy and you get to put as much onions, cilantro, and sauce you want.

The next week I went back for a Shrimp burrito, I was set this time I knew where to go and etc.  but this time, the cashier was confused?  I ordered, she didn't accept my cash yet, I waited then she handed me the food and that's it... I said, "I haven't paid, yet."  She replied, oh, $7.50....  Again, I could had walked out again!  I don't know how they monitor this stuff.  Oh well, the burrito was extremely juicy with a lot of good stuff but the burrito was super small though, I wasn't filled up or anything.
author: Samson K.

description: The taco bar here is great! Relatively inexpensive, tasty, and fresh. Staff is friendly too. The lines can get long around lunchtime but that's my only complaint! I'll be back for sure.
author: Diana G.

description:
Holy shit this a delicious burrito. For the past few years I've been working periodically in SF. Almost every night after work my friend would slip out of our hotel, saying he was going to the Mission to get a burrito. We were staying 20-25 minutes away from the Mission by bus, so I figured he was actually going to see a girl or something. This past August my curiousity finally got the better of me and I hungrily rode the 20 minute bus ride with him, followed by a ten minute walk, but at the end of the trail was the finest carnitas burrito I have ever tasted. Perfectly seasoned pork, crispy edges yet tender, perfect rice : beans : meat ratio. I ended up going back almost every night for the rest of the week.
Delicious tacos are served a la carte at a separate counter. Salsa options were not terrific, but my burrito was perfect as served, so I didn't need to spruce it up with salsa anyway.
author: Joe L.

description: Taqueria Vallarta is the closest I've come to finding something comparable to the amazing $1 tacos you get in the shadiest/best taquerias in Mexico (best taco I've had was in Cozumel) and this place brought me back! Came here for drunchies and was so pleasantly surprised at the taco bar! They grill all the different meats in a legit sizzling stone wheel and as soon as you place a taco order they toast up your tortillas too. Love the freshly chopped onions and cilantro you can pile on top, and their cilantro salsa is delicious. Lime wedges and radishes make the whole thing complete.
author: Tiffany F.

description: The taco al pastor at the side taco bar is addicting, in that serotonin moving way...also $2, street drug
author: Jack M.

description:
Greasiest breakfast burrito I've ever seen.  Fat and cooking oil was so thick that it seeped through the tortilla and the tortilla would fall apart whenever I unwrapped a bit more from the foil (and I didn't unwrap more than a little foil at a time since too much grease would drip otherwise).

Loud tejano music blasting the place at 11am on a Tuesday.  I would have left to avoid the ear-splitting oompahs, but the burrito was falling apart.

The neighborhood has many options in the same style, but with better execution.
author: Alex H.

description:
Yeah yeah...another late night taqueria like all the others. No my friends. This is not just another Taqueria Cancun or El Farolito. This one is special. This one is a little deeper in the Mission and away from the drunken foolish masses of 16th street. So there's a taco cart right at the front entrance. Only $1.50. But if you're not in a taco mood then proceed past the taco cart and to the main area where you can order from a plethora of choices - burritos, quesadillas, chimichangas, etc...

I got a chimichanga last night and it was the best chimichanga I've ever had. I will be coming back here drunk or sober....for sure.
author: David C.

description:
I got a wet burrito at first and it was super difficult to eat because all they have is flopped plastic silverware. It was mildly tasty, but too much of a hassle. The chips and queso I ordered were awful. The staff also was pretty rude and ignored us while we stood at the counter for a while. We got some tacos on the way out and the BBQ pork was AMAZING! I would definitely recommend stopping by to get some tacos, but anything that requires a fork and knife I would avoid.

EDIT: I had to change my review from three to five stars after it has been a few weeks now and I have been craving their tacos CONSTANTLY. Why was I ordering anything else in the first place?? Dealing with the bad service is a negligible part of the experience. In fact, if the service is the only thing keeping me from giving it six stars. If you live in or are visiting San Francisco and are not eating at this place at least every once in a while, shame on you, and I hate you. I want some chorizo tacos right now!!! Addicting, beware.
author: Trey F.

description: Solid.  No, better than solid.  I'm a fan.  Try the habanero salsa on everything.  It's "give-yourself-stomach-ulcers-and-love-it" good.  The only reason I docked them a star is that their Al Pastor doesn't have enough sweet (pineapple) in it.
author: Drew T.

description: Yup doo this is the best taqueria in the mission still,   the taco bar is now serving LAMB TACOS  "OMG" lamb are you serious bro, the taco guy said its prepared Morelos styles steamed and marinated all night so the taste is amazing, 3 lamb tacos and a mexican coke 8.50 i was stoked with a bomb lunch for under 10 bucks,, you got to try it..
author: Signs San Francisco Wholesale M.

description:
5 stars for the taco bar.

Best tacos I've had in S.F. Super satisfying. This is my new spot.

Street style, nice 'n greasy for $1.75 a pop. Open till 1 A.M.? Done.

Must Eats:
Suadero: Tender juicy goodness
Barbacoa: Slightly funky enough braised & shredded lamb

also:
Carnitas: Soft version. Juicy and tons of flavor
Carne Asada: Charred sufficiently, seasoned well
Al Pastor: No spit but tasty marinade does the trick

Salsas are on point as well.
author: Anthony R.

description:
I loved this place! Amazing quality and great location, great price. I got chicken and beef tacos.

This would be my go-to for late night tacos but they are good enough to be had on their own for a quick and easy dinner. Also, their salsas are amazing and something about their sautéed onions they give you with the meat makes me think they're the best onions ever. Cool little joint.
author: Lauren C.

description: Some of the most delicious tacos I've ever had. Easy and quick to order. Authentic feel.
author: Kyle K.

description: So there's a counter here with a big-ass backlit menu where you can order the big flautas plates, combos and quesadillas... or you can step to your right and get a street taco by the door for $1.75.  A man stands behind a grill with tons of cuts of meat and piles of tortillas.  You can ask for grilled onions from the grill (though you may have to ask twice), and there are salsas and other condiments  such as limes, radishes, raw onions, cilantro you can use to top the taco yourself.  Delicious, authentic cuts of meat like lengua, cabeza, buche, suadero... definitely go for the cheap street taco on a paper plate!
author: Christina G.

description:
Trying to find the name of this specific taqueria in Mission (I just walked in with a group of friends and didn't remember the name) was like trying to find a specific hipster in Dolores Park-- they all look alike, sound alike, and are a little rundown. 

But I finally found it!! And it was worth it!! I usually find most taquerias to be too similar to determine which is better than the other (in other words, I'm usually drunk and can't tell the difference) . However, this place serves some of THE BEST tacos. Their other items don't seem that great, but their tacos pack a lot of punch. I recommend the carne asada and carnitas. The carnitas tacos have the perfect texture-- crispy on the outside, soft and tender on the inside. Make sure you ask for the grilled red onions!!! It's also a pleasant treat that the tacos are served with tortilla chips as well as access to the all-you-can-eat salsa bar (don't get too excited; there are only like four types of salsa). Top it all off with a horchata or cantaloupe agua fresca, and you've got yourself an authentic Mexican meal that doesn't break the bank and is actually worth the calories!
author: Jan C.

description:
My buddy Damon found this place while doing some construction work in the area.  I think tacos were only $1.25 at that time.  Now it's $1.75.  Still the best  taco's for that price I can think of.  

The place is a bit grimy.  Haven't decided if it adds or takes away from  the experience.

Also, it should be noted that they have more "exotic" meats on  the menu.  My wife will also get the tongue, brain, face., etc.  Not for me, but she's a fan.
author: Sam T.

description: These are the best tacos in San Francisco. Period. Full stop. I've eaten at dozens of different taco spots, and while there are many that are great, none are quite as great as Vallarta.
author: Edward M.

description: This place is back alive from its remodel. Gotta love that taco bar. 4 different salsas, cilantro, onion, radishes, lime.
author: Ray C.

description: They have lots of seating to dine in and great food so i take it to go. When i'm feeling sick the caldo de res does the trick. tacos are easy to order, fast and so good. meat is always moist and full of flavor. one of my favorites in the city!
author: Selma R.

description:
Check out this viedo review of this restaurant!

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C7GtbPcGOSE&feature=youtu.be
author: Kayla J.

description:
One of the best Mission burrito places in the home of Mission burritos. They have a large variety of vegetarian burrito options, an excellent Taco bar, and many different burrito varieties. Consistently excellent, I prefer a super burrito al pastor with a whole-wheat tortilla.

Their horchata is also great. Their chips are average.

The biggest disadvantage is that it's sort of a pain to walk it from the BART station, since it's sort of far from Mission.

Note: Don't confuse this with the other location near 16th and Mission BART. Though the location is better and the menu is the same, the quality is not as good.
author: Ned D.

description:
I was getting a little tired of the same old spot in the Mission. So I said to me-self, 

"Miguel, which ever hole in the wall, dive taqueria with motorcycle parking in front you will eat there!"

And like the parting of the Red Sea, actual motorcycle parking appeared. Motorcycle parking with meters!  What what?  A burrito dive too.  All this plus ethnic street art!

I slide my bad-ass moto into one of the three motorcycle spots and walked mere five steps into the restaurant. I couldn't believe what I was seeing.  What looked like a small place from the outside was a huge dining hall/art Halley.  Murals of the 49'rs, the Golden Gate Bridge, Gavin Newsom?  

The burrito was delicious.  And the salsa is f'n hot!  The chips were good but basically the same stuff you get in any of the Mish-Mex joints of the neighborhood.  Not much more to say other then the food was good and filling.  

But the restaurant was clean (for the Mission)  entertaining and the moto parking reigns supreme.
author: Miguel C.

description: My new favorite place to get burritos. Though I usually get the super burritos, I like that they have the taco stand inside and on weekends they have tamales. There's something about the al pastor thats marinated with pine apple that makes it stand out.
author: Dang T.

description: Awesome menu selection, LOTS of seating inside, really good Mexican food. They even have Mexican corn which I def need to get next time. Their horchata is just okay. Bonus: it's across from Humphrey's so you can have your hipster & legit Mexican food all in the same meal.
author: Diana Y.

description:
I went here with a group of friends. Most of them had tacos. Two of us had shrimp quesadillas. This place has the typical taco stand within the restaurant. You just go there and choose out your ingredients and watch your taco being made.

The quesadillas were great. They are the common quesadilla that you find here in the bay, folded almost like a buritto with no top and bottom. The ingredients were all fresh and well prepared.

This place is just a solid taqueria. You can't do wrong by going here.
author: Arun V.

description: Shot over here to knock it off my bucket list. The ambiance is large and open, with lots of seating. The salsa bar is a turn off next to the bathroom and the register is small with no real line order. But fuck it, it's a taqueria. I came for the carne asada burrito which was big, hearty, and had a shit ton of protein in it. So if I'm ever in the area again, I would come back.
author: Christopher K.

description:
do you have $10? then you have 5 tacos. 

as usual, ed u. is right! the headliner at taqueria vallarta is the hubcap turned grilltop; its halo of grilled meats surrounding sizzling tortillas in the middle. the taco maker has fast hands and a fascinating formula: grab tortillas, dip in oil, use 'em to spread oil on the grill, lay 'em down, flip 'em over, repeat. grab, dip, spread, lay, flip, repeat. he is a master of his craft. 

the $1.75 tacos are filled with steaming al pastor, barbacoa, carnitas, chicken; whatever your pleasure. my favorite, to my own surprise, was not pork, but the juicy and flavorful carne asada. there are also more adventurous choices like beef tongue and brain and cheek. but these are real tacos, my friends. nary a shred of cheese nor dollop of sour cream will be seen at this taco bar; only cilantro, onions, and fresh salsas. you won't miss the other toppings though - all the flavor you need is in the meat and the salsas. 

i'd like to be ladylike and say i only had three tacos, but the truth is i ate the first three, got two as takeout, and promptly consumed those two as soon as my stomach had space. with this review marking four mexican restaurants in one month, i shall dub this month as "march mexican madness," and crown taqueria vallarta the best tasting of the bunch.
author: Kris G.

description:
Groupons can make men do funny things...go to places far out of their way...order way too much food...the list could go on. Having bought a 10 dollar Groupon to Taqueria Vallarta I found myself ordering a taco, and a burrito, and a horchata, because if I'm using a Groupon, I want to get my money's worth...Goddamnit!

The taco ($2) was outstanding. Being the sort of man who enjoys exotic meats, I ordered the cabeza (although I was disapointed to see that they didn't offer sesos, its been on my list of things to try for a couple of years now),  which was simply seasoned (pretty much only salt, as far as I could tell), warm off the grill and superbly tender, although a little on the fatty side. I now completely understand why cheeks are one of the most desirable cuts of meat for cannibals. Despite my newfound love of cabeza the highlight of this course was grilled onions that came as a side, vaguely translucent, they had a well carmalized, almost beefy flavor (no doubt from being on the same grill as some carne asada) while still having a snap that complimented the superbly grilled corn tortillas. Salsas were tasty, and the freeform style of the whole operation allowed for a ton of personalization. I'll definitely be coming back for more at some point in the near future.

My Zapata burrito ($7.25), on the other hand was unremarkable. Despite that the well sauced and tangy al Pastor (including tiny chunks of pineapple which added a welcome sweetness and balance to an otherwise salty meal) , other elements lagged hard. Sour cream was applied liberally (bringing slabwide temperatures down), avocado was minimal, and an otherwise outstanding vegetable compliment, anchored by some mighty fine marinated onions, was sabotaged by the inclusion of iceberg lettuce, the scourge of any decent slab. Cheese was well melted, and the whole pinto beans and rice were both good,although they never appeared in the same bite together. The tortilla was politely grilled, but not to the point where it could withstand a second half saucy onslaught leading me to use a few more napkins then I would have liked.  While the burritomaker in back didn't heed my request for extra-spicy with jalapenos, a liberal slathering of habenero mango salsa brought things up to speed, although I'd watch out for an overly liberal application, lest your forced to check your pallate into the burn ward at General. 

Ambiance includes a disturbingly charming mural of members of the 49ers frolicking in the waves, yellow and blue tables, a jukebox that apparently only plays Banda, and a bowling-alley-style claw machine filled with lonely and abused stuffed animals. You may end up sharing your meal with pigeons if you aren't careful.

Overall: Go for the superb meats and outstanding tacos. While my burrito was certainly tasty, there were simply too many flaws for me to order another. 3.5 stars (rounded down to three because of the boneheaded inclusion of lettuce in my burrito [don't hate, I'm just a curmudgeon]) although subsequent visits may find me upgrading the rating to four solid stars as I work my way through their selection of dead animals wrapped in corn tortillas.

P.S. Humphery Slocumbs is right around the corner. I definitely got a double scoop afterwards, although at the moment I sort of wish I hadn't (time to hit the gym!).
author: Casey U.

description: This place would always be packed with patrons whenever I walked by going towards the BART Station. Good music, and the TV would be turned on to Latino News, or a Soccer (futbol) game. I finally tried it out, and I must say, though the prices are little steep, the food is excellent, and the portions are great. I've only ordered the dinner plates and tacos, since the only place I get burritos is at El Farolito. I thoroughly enjoyed the Seafood Platters (including the shrimp, crab legs, and the fried fish). For me, the Fried Fish would have to be my favorite, which is why it was always disappointing whenever they ran out (which was often). The staff is friendly, and the decor is very "interesting". Highly Recommended!
author: Ron Z.

description:
$2/taco, and it's really everything you'd want in a taco.  fast, hot, good, and cheap.  i suppose that's a bad combo for women, but a great combo for tacos.

a win in my book.  I've never gotten any of the food beyond the taco cart at the door.  I'm sure the food at the counter is good, if i ever make it past the door.
author: Jason J.

description: I like how they have a lot of options. Food is cheap and quality of meats is good. Like a true hole in the wall. Lol this is a good place to try some exotic cutting that you normally don't get at an American restaurant. Like beef tongue or beef cheeks and intestine lol.
author: Michael Q.

description: 2 a.m. tacos? Sold! Sure, the service isn't the best but the meaty goodness makes up for it. They even have Mucho Mango to wash it all down.
author: Abby S.

description:
What's it got going for them? cheap food

But, we all know that doesn't cut it with Mexican food, especially since all the other taquerias are cheap as well.

The nachos were not too bad. Enough melted cheese, refried beans and carne asada...

The tacos: meat was too salty

Burrito: not juicy enough, meat was fatty, and rice was dry

Salsa: looks deceiving, does not have the right kick to it
author: Jo M.

description:
Tacos for carnivores. Slabs for vegetarians.

To your right as you walk in is a taco stand. The guy is simultaneously grilling six, seven maybe eight meats at once. Incredible. I was on a burrito mission, so I passed, but I'm coming back.

Also incredible. The extensive veggie burrito selection. Not one, two or even three varieties. Try six. Each with an assortment of onions, peppers, squash, spinach, cauliflower, tomatoes and plenty of others.

Mine featured pretty much everything above. Wheat tortilla. Black beans. Very impressed and quite a slab for $6.

Also impressed with how much better this location is than the one in the Excelsior: http://www.yelp.com/biz/taqueria-vallarta-san-francisco-3#hrid:Mvlgpmj6X1hquJKI8D3dnw

Wouldn't be surprised if they had different owners.

Will never return to the one in the Excelsior. Will out of my way to return to the one in the Mission for tacos.
author: Jason B.

description:
- Good tacos (and they have fish tacos)
- Cheap & cheerful
- Good salsas

...not sure what other compliment could serve a taqueria well. 

- Tamales = not too good
- "Hot" sauce for tacos = not tasty
- Tortilla chips = very oily
author: Vandana N.

description:
Ate here today for the first time. 5/13/2011

+Good Taco's
+Cheap Prices
-Watered Down Everything
-DISGUSTING BURRITOS!
-Same Chips you get from Chili's or Chevy's

This place was such a disappointment. Right in the heart of 24th street and serving disgusting food? UNACCEPTABLE! 

My fiance & I entered this place with high hopes seeing the reviews on yelp. My fiance being full blooded Mexican he's a sucker for authentic Mexican food. We ordered 3 carnitas tacos, 2 carne asada tacos, 1 carnitas burrito, 1 carne asada burrito & a large horchata. After ordering that's when things start going down hill for this palce.....

The chips the lady behind the counter gave us are the EXACT same chips you get at Chili's or Chevy's. UNACCEPTABLE for a place in the MISSION! Then when I was about to scoop salsa verde into the little plastic cups they provide the lady behind the counter sways me away so she can ADD WATER TO THE ALREADY WATERED DOWN SALSA. After watching her do this I quickly got a couple scoops of another type and as soon as I was done I WATCHED HER ADD WATER TO THE OTHER 3 TYPES OF SALSA THEY OFFERED. talk about stretching your buck i guess. SMDH! The horchata was ok, watered down as well with little flavor. A TREND WE'LL FIND IS A VERY COMMON FACT AT THIS JOINT.... I can say this though, the taco's are pretty tasty, probably because all we added to them was onion, celantro & lime juice.

The BURRITOS though are a completely different story. NASTY! Beans weren't drained properly, Sour Cream was "WATERED DOWN", Tomatoes inside tasted funny, not a lot of meat, & it dripped all over you hand when you were eating it. 

We paid $22 for all that food, which is really cheap compared to other places we go to. Sadly it's true what they say. You get what you pay for. NEVER COMING BACK HERE. & I mean NEVER!
author: Dessa S.

description:
This place is amazing! The five stars are for the tacos. I originally thought of giving it four stars, but I thought five stars with a caveat was well deserved.

The tacos were delicious and fresh, and my friends told me the caldo de res was delicious as well. I had three tacos: suadero, carnitas, and chorizo. They were all delicious, though I'd recommend having only one of chorizo because eating too many could ruin it for you since the flavor is so intense. Definitely put the cooked/grilled onion that they serve on your plate in your taco! I used the green hot sauce and squeezed lime juice on top, and it was great. 

The only disappointing part of the meal was the horchata, which was not the best I've ever tasted, and horchata is one of my favorite things about taquerias. However, the canteloupe juice was refreshing and a great complement to the tacos.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Call me a heathen! I've found a place I prefer over Taqueria Cancun and El Farolito. I only wish it wasn't so far from me. Seeing how I live half a block away from Cancun, it's hard to get away.

When you get to the taco stand, the meats are all bubbling and crisping away on a traditional comal (round griddle). You get em dirty: tortillas, meat, and some grilled onions. They are on a thin paper plate. Be careful because you can burn yourself! You can also help yourself to as much onions/cilantro, salsa (3 types), and radishes as you like.

I had the suadero, lengua, and buche. They were all extremely delicious and flavorful without being dry. I need to go back and have a burrito to confirm my suspicions that this is my choice for best burrito in Mission, but I'll report back soon.

For now, best tacos in the Mission for me!
author: Charles L.

description:
I was introduced here by Julia C., and I love her for it.
Legit street tacos available late at night for $1.50. 
I've been here twice and love the carnitas and carne asada tacos with fresh horchata. Put your order in with the guy behind the grill and garnish your tacos with salsa, cilantro, and limes with the bar in front.
Cheap, fast, goood Mexican food.
author: Jen T.

description:
Came here on a recommendation from a friend - and I'm glad I followed Nathan C's advice!

Super fast and simple - just pick what kind of meat do you want.  In and out in 3 minutes.  All $1.75 each.  Each corn taco is small - about 3" in diameter, so you could easily have 3-6 for a meal, depending on your appetite. Comes on a paper plate, but I was driving home so the lady covered it in foil for me.

I got 2 carne asada, 2 chicken, 2 pork carnitas (to share with MLP, although I'm so moo I probably couldn't eaten them all myself), and they were all super good. I think my fave was the carnitas. I slathered my taco's with a bit of everything - cilantro, red sauce, green sauce and lime.  DELISH!

Taq Vallarta - I'll be back!
author: Karen S.

description:
$1.75 tacos right inside by the door! My favorites are the Lugera (Beef Tongue) and Suadero (Tender Beef)! The price is cheap and the food is amazing! They have ample amount of add-ons like cilantro, onions, and many different kinds of salsa. 

There is plenty of seating space, but the place does get crowded! Located in the Mission district. Not too far from BART or SFGH!
author: Yumi H.

description:
This has been my go-to taqueria for years. It's also the one place I always insist on taking out-of-town guests (for the authentic Mexican food experience as well as the alley murals right around the corner). 

I'll admit, I haven't tried many things on the menu, but that's because I love the few things I order at Taqueria Vallarta so much that I can never bring myself to branch out. Favorite Menu Item: Quesadilla Castillito.

Think of this as a quesadilla cum burrito -- it's packed full of more ingredients than any quesadilla you've ever seen (hence the burrito reference), but it's grilled like a quesadilla and all of the fillings melt into one another like a beautiful symphony: cheese, sour cream, avocado, carne asada, jalapenos ... ahhh! I used to tailor make my quesadilla castillito to make it a bit more diet friendly, but take my advice and let this be your indulgence for the week. In any form the quesadilla still rocks, but the mastery of these flavor combinations should be respected and enjoyed as they were intended.

They've toned down the juke box decibal which used to be unbearable, so eating in is much more likeable than in the past; however, cleanliness could be better. Doesn't stop me from traveling to Vallarta whenever I want to treat myself, though!
author: Amanda L.

description:
This place is a bit of a dive, but they make the best tacos in town. When you factor in value, at $1.75 each, they win hands-down.

They make the tacos on this little cart. The meats are already sizzling on their grill when you get there. So far, all of the meats have been good except for the tripas, although I haven't tried their chicken yet. They dip the tortillas in lard or some other kind of goodness before they warm them. After the guy serves em up, add cilantro, onions, lime and salsa to taste. The green salsa's the best of the three. Also, sometimes the guy gives you grilled onions which are a nice bonus.

In the evenings, a lady sells tamales and corn in the other corner of the store. I tried her corn-on-the-cob last night, and it wasn't bad. She slathers mayo (I think) on it and then sprinkles on queso and paprika. It looked kinda nasty and unhealthy when she was prepping it, but it actually tasted alright. I haven't tried her tamales yet, but both tamales and corn-on-the-cob are $2.

My friend got a burrito here once. I think it was alright. But if you come here, get the tacos. They're the bomb. The cart's right by the entrance, so you can't miss it.
author: Nathan C.

description: We had a quesidilla and a super burrito el pastor. The meat of the quesidilla was OK but the dish in general was not fantastic. The super burrito was rather small and the sauces werd not inspiring.
author: Kaat D.

description: I love love love this place. The tacos are to die for and the quesadillas omg. This place is the best Mexican food I've had ever. This makes living in the City a treat. If you're in the mission you must stop here to eat. Highly recommended.
author: Krishna V.

description: Since you can both load up on a burrito or plato, OR nosh at the taco bar--or both!--I say yay! for this place. The taco bar man is always nice, and their food hits the spot.
author: Suzanne C.

description: This location is the one to go to. They do a great job with the meats, especially the carnitas with the grilled crispy golden edges. Not a big fan of reheating the beans and rice via microwave but all in all it was a solid meal for $9. Grab some of the tacos too for a quick snack.
author: Ed L.

description: Ay dios mio, these tacos are delicious!! The barbacoa is slow cooked which makes it incredibly tender, juicy, and richly flavorful. I like that you can customize your own tacos with your favorite sauce and however much cilantro and onion you desire. I hear they raised the prices from 1.50 to 1.75, but for a quarter Tacqueria Vallarta is still my top choice for getting my taco fix.
author: Clarice W.

description:
Best tacos!

Best taco bar I have ever had. I came with my girlfriend and ordered a wet carnitas burrito and a carne asada burrito with my tacos. They were cheap which made me quite happy. 

I ate the tacos while I waited for the burritos to be made and they blew my mind. So freakin good. I don't know if the burritos were good because my mind was so blown by the tacos... just kidding! The wet burrito was good but I am not that big of a fan of red sauce so I probably should have just gone for a normal burrito. The carne asada was ridiculously good.
author: Stephen S.

description:
Talk about oversight. I didn't know about this place until an acquaintance decided to have his unofficial farewell dinner here. I'm not really a taco girl to begin with (I prefer burritos and tortas when it comes to Mexican food), but as a native Mission kid, that's just embarrassing. 

The carne asada tacos were just as succulent and perfect as they were when I first had 'em in December. I keep mine pretty simple, topping them only with sliced radishes and the milder orange sauce. 

I'm not a fan of their agua de fresa though. It's too watery and too sweet like Kool-Aid. I could feel the drink aggravating my cavity, which is getting filled later this month, by the way. 

Oh, and about the mural! I'm kind of a stickler when it comes to grammar. Wait, that's a lie. I'm not just "kind of" a stickler; I AM a stickler! Reading the history of San Francisco that's painted on the smaller wall was like hearing nails screech down a chalkboard. Gawwwd... why didn't anyone think about proofreading before making the story a part of the decor?
author: Iris V.

description:
The taco stand is a regular favorite of friends, but I'm a burrito girl. One night, I decided to switch it up a little from El Metate and try something new. Something drew me to Taqueria Vallarta and I ordered a super shrimp burrito. Carrying it proudly back to friends, we all raved about it - marvelling at the juicy and well cooked Shrimp - I was excited about giving it an easy 4 stars......

...it's just as well that that review was put on hold.....

one late night, starving, and stressed about some personal issues I decided that Taqueria Vallarta was the answer. I ordered a Shrimp burrito and sat patiently to wait. A good 20 minutes had gone by, and I noticed that people behind  me, were getting their food before me. I asked the woman at the counter about my burrito. She just nodded, so I sat back down. It was getting late and I wanted to get home to avoid walking around too late at night, so after about 30 minutes of waiting for a simple burrito - I asked them again. I felt stupid just waiting for nearly a good half hour for a burrito. This would  never have happened at El-Metate. I mean I can eat a whole burrito in 5 minutes!

 One of the cooks chuckled in the background, and I knew they'd forgotten my order. They didn't even apologize, but just hurriedly said it was coming.  So I finally got my burrito 40 minutes later after I had ordered it. No apology - no nothing, and I'd even tipped pretty  well beforehand.  It was a horrible night altogether: so stressed, tired and hungry - I took my burrito home - only to take one big bite of my burrito and spit it out. It was shrimp (fishy tasting at that) mixed with beef, and other random things that had been on the grill, when they were cooking my food. I threw it away quickly. Yes, Vallarta is open late, yes their taco truck may be something else....but I know I won't be stopping by their inside eating area anytime soon.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Thank you, Yelp iPhone app.  We gave up on the Humphrey Slocombe ice cream line around the corner and decided on Yelp-approved tacos.  Savory always wins over sweet for me!

Delicious, authentic, cheap ($1.50/ea).  The end.
author: Melanie C.

description:
My drunken Yelp pals & I made a dash to this place after an extended Happy Hour session at Dalva. We jumped the BART train at 16th St. & exited moments later at 24th & Mission.
