"GUYS! FAROLITO TAQUERIA! MY FAVORITE. IT'S RIGHT HERE...WAH WAH WAH I'M HUNGRY. NO?!? WTF! WHERE ARE WE GOING? OHHH WAH WAH WAH THIS PLACE BETTER BE GOOD."

And it was. It's now my favorite drunken Mission Taqueria. 

Everything is cooked fresh and made to order right there in front of you, and you even get pointed at by the ever-so-efficient cook master when it's your turn (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/y00vIJzvt1Fveq_Um_9egw?select=Bw8ik3J4gDrHqwKuTUVvTw )...this dude doesn't mess around.

At a buck fifty per taco (you choose what meat you want) & next time I may have 5. If it's payday, I will buy 10 of them and snack on them for days to come. What can I say? I like a yummy taco.

It's about as close as I can get to a taco from my days in San Diego...

Props to Senor Karl L. for the recommendation on this one--that Brit knows his Mission taquerias!
author: matt m.

description:
Best tacos I've had in the Bay thus far. For me tacos is the ultimate street food. So when I get charged 3-6 dollars for a taco...there better be some foie gras on it. If there's nothing fancy, then it better be 1-2 dollar tops!

Get the weird stuff, trust me it's whats really good. And you owe it yourself to live a little! =). 

The cheek (Cachete), hip (Saudero), Head (Cabeza), pork neck (Buche) and tongue (Lengua) were really good, with the Buche and the Cachete being my favorite. Don't get the chicken...really why would you ever get a chicken taco?....it was dry. The only thing I thought was disgusting was brain (Sesos), guess its an accquired taste^_^.

They also sell tamales in back of the dining area of the resturant. That's what is inside the tall pot. Tamales are $1.50. There was nothing left but chicken when we got there. But the chicken was tender and flavorful. The cornmeal part was dry, but that could be because we got it one of the last ones of the night. I'll have to try again earlier.
author: Cindy C.

description: When I go to any taqueria's, my target is burritoes. I seldom eat tacos. When I worked around that neighborhood, There are taqueria in every block. But this taqueria is unique. It has a cart in front of the restaurant where they make tacos in your face. When I worked graveyard, I would eat 2 tacos to start my graveyard shift. It was my breakfast to jumpstart my shift and a favorite.
author: Matt G.

description: Amazing Tacos, grilled chicken, chorizo, Al pastor and carnitas, as authentic as it gets, true gem in the mission !
author: Vish E.

description: Delish tacos! Good torta! Love that they are open late. Ive gone twice with coworkers after work around 1am
author: Brenda A.

description: I live a few blocks away and have my pick of great taquerias in the Mission. While I sometimes mix it up, this is usually my "go to" spot where I find myself 90% of the time I want a burrito. They have several different veggie options (probably more than is necessary, really...). My favorites are the Grill and the Nopales burritos, both delicious. They have a nice selection of tasty salsas salsas, and my meat eating friends all seem to really enjoy the taco stand. I also have a little place in my heart for the mural on the wall with the 49ers frolicking with dolphins under the Golden Gate. The people who work here are super nice as well.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I am an avid fan of Mexican food and have eaten it all over California. SoCal is known for better Mexican food but only because the people that say that have not had Vallarta. They have fresh ingredients, you can customize your burrito with any tortilla and go all veggies or all meat and everything on the menu is great! I first fell in love with their nachos but then went on to love their super burrito grill. One day
I added shrimp to that super burrito grill (fresh carrots, bell pepper, onions, zucchini grilled up plus beans and rice) and since then I've never gone back. I now call that the Kassandra special and have multiple people try it and love it. Yum!!
author: Kassandra Z.

description: All you need to know: try the al pastor taco! I would give this place all five stars if they made an effort to keep it a little more clean. Other than that, the food is amazing.
author: Jerry S.

description:
If I'm going to Vallarta, I am having tacos. Carne asada tacos, vegetarian tacos, really good. REALLY GOOD. I can't bring myself to have a burrito, their tacos are that good.

If you're just going to have meat tacos, order them from the cart thing just inside the door since that's where they'll direct you anyway. Self serve chopped onion, cilantro, and lime make it easy to customize how you want yo' tacos -- carne asada gets you some grilled onions, YUM.
author: Vicki L.

description: Tacos are $2 now. While the taco cart at the entrance was a neat sight to behold, I found all of my taco meats were kinda over cooked. Props for having very authentic meat choices to choose from. Lengua, cabeza, suadero, y buche were all good.
author: John H.

description:
The wife and I came here for lunch and I have to say that I haven't had a cheap Mexican meal this good since our last trip to Mexico.

I'm guessing that if we came at night, we'd probably hear drunk Tejano dudes yelling "AYYYYY, HAHAHAAAAAA!!!!" as they rip through a case of Pacificos accompanied by the 4 or 5 menu items you never even knew existed.  (Tacos are for gringos, after all.)

And really, isn't that the kind of place you want to get your grub on?

+2 for amazing food (caldo de pollo for me, enchiladas for swmbo)
+0 for slow moving line
+1 for friendly staff
+1 for RANDOM decor and good vibe
author: Patrick C.

description: My favorite taqueria in the Mission! The taco bar has some of the most flavorable meat imaginable. The buritos are MASSIVE (they have quite the variety of veggie options too). And the dinner plates are so tasty and filling you could likely feed two people with one. Overall, one of the best Mexican places I've ever eaten at.
author: Ben G.

description:
Just had 2 smallish but Perfect, luscious, tacos around 4pm. They only had a taco area set up, and in front of you were all the fixin's. Really incredible meats and marinations. 
Anthony Bourdain material. Seriously.
author: Ken H.

description: Idk about the rest of the food. But where ever I go I'm in search for some good mariscos. Worst mariscos ever! Especially the ceviche
author: Nana M.

description:
Did I take a train and land in Mexico?? Tacos were so yummy (cabeza- head- was my fav), and their lamb barbacoa was soooo worth $8.50. Came with a garbanzo bean, rice and innards soup, tortillas, and the succulent braised melt-in-your-mouth meat. Add a little lime/avocado salsa, some onions and cilantro, and you've got happiness in the belly.

And then afterwards, head a block up to El Delfin for atole (warm pecan milk drink) to go.
author: Lauren C.

description: Just discovered the Taco Bar on a quick trip to SF. Wow. Brought back memories of amazing street side Tacos in Merida. Awesome selection of meats and as much cilantro, fresh lime and salsa as you want to pile on top. I could eat here every day!
author: David L.

description:
If you are looking for some juicy carne asada tacos you found the right spot.

They throw together your taco right on the spot. Load up on some cilantro, onions, salsa, and lemon. Take it to the register, order a big 'ol horchata and that's a wrap!

Definitely gotta come back. It smashes on a lot of spots I've been to.
author: Alex F.

description:
My new place to come back and try more dishes.

They had me at the smell of grilled meat. Right near the doorway, there is a taco area where flavor-packed grilled meats await your arrival. 

T. Vallarta offers a 'street style' version of the taco.  Pick your choice of meat ~ carne asada (beef), carnitas (pork), pastor (marinated pork), pollo (chicken) cabeza (head), lengua (tongue) and chorizo (Mexican sausage) ~ and they put it on top of a fresh corn tortilla. DIY toppings ~ cilantro, lime, onions, and choice of 3 salsas. Heaven.

Don't forget to walk over to the register. There is open space in between the taco order/assembly area and the main area ~ it's easy to be mesmerized by the aforementioned and nearly forget to pay.

At the register, look up. They have a runway full of other mouthwatering choices ~ burritos, nachos, tortas, quesadillas, enchiladas, flautas, frajitas, chilaquiles (scrambled eggs with chips, salsa and onions), they also serve breakfast.

Other noteworthies:

- colorful murals
- 'the claw' game machine ~ for those who want a stuffed buddy
- benches & tables
- during the day, be sure to walk down the adjacent Balmy Alley - lots of cool artwork on painted fences and doors.
- accepts credit cards
author: Cathy K.

description:
The only reason that Taqueria Vallarta has earned a star is because the tacos are considered the best in the city.  However, this place as a whole leaves a lot to be desired, especially insofar as customer service.  While I've experienced worse treatment by food servers before, the people who work at Vallarta are definitely in need of some training on how to better treat their customers.  When my friend asked for a carnitas burrito one time, the woman at the register brusquely told him they were out of carnitas and then attempted to forcibly ring him up for a carne asada burrito without even asking him if that's what he wanted instead! Then there's the tamale vendor out front who, while has treated me decently, I have observed being pretty rude to other customers. 

As far as the food itself; while the tacos are good for the most part, their al pastor meat isn't the best quality. Most of the pork in the tacos al pastor that I ordered consisted of blubbery fat, not appetizing at all.  When I made the mistake of ordering chicken enchiladas one time, even worse: instead of filling the enchiladas with actual chicken meat, they had used the worst chicken parts imaginable.  My enchiladas literally had such disgusting parts as pieces of skin and cartilage-looking things that seemed to be leg joints!  And don't even get me started on the pozole; it consisted of mostly bones, a couple of large chunks of cartilage or something, and a few pieces of actual pork meat.  Without a doubt, the worst pozole I've ever had bar none! 

If you decide to eat at Vallarta, stick to the carne asada tacos, which is one of the few good entrees at this place.  Another redeeming quality here is that the green salsa that's kept in the stone molcajete is without a doubt the best salsa in the Mission. The horchata is good, but then again the horchata is good at most Mexican restaurants.  All in all, Vallarta is a pretty unsatisfactory taqueria.
author: Tito The Incognito ..

description: Perfect quick meal on my walk home from BART. $2 tacos. It's a done deal. Delicious and fast.
author: K R.

description: I'm convinced they put crack in the al pastor. If you ever daydream about tacos, these will be the ones you dream of.
author: Cat R.

description:
Pretty darn good tacos.

$1.50 each and made to order (by both you, the customer, and the gentleman at the door behind the cart with warming tortillas and assorted meats).  By made to order, I mean, you'll need to communicate which meats you'd like and the quantity of tacos you'd like corresponding the meat.  You'll then be given a thin paper plate (be careful --while dressing my tacos I nearly flipped the plate over) with the tortillas and meat.  It's your job to dress your tacos with one of three kinds of sauce, cillantro, radishes, onions, and lime.  Payment is a few steps away and then you can bite into very tasty morsels that leave you wanting just one more (why is it so good? tons of msg? who cares... the meat is so well seasoned, you'll just want another without questioning much else).

# Chorizo 
# Carnitas *** highly recommended ***
# Al Pastor  

Going to be back for more yumminess, particularly the carnitas and the "add your own toppings" taco experience.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Dirty street taco style!  The lamb is pretty good.... hardly ever see lamb on tacos.  Although we got a huge chunk of gristle, the meat was still break apart tender.  Carnitas is bomb... lengua... meh.  

Love that you can help yourself to onions, cilantro, radish, and all you can have salsa!  Get the green and orange one... the deep red one is smoky weird.

This place is so not clean with pigeons frequently flying in to peck at whatever is on the ground, but I really really really enjoyed my tacos here.  Skip the quesadilla though... not too fond of cheddar cheese in quesadillas.
author: Chris T.

description: This place never disappoints. The tacos are always delicious as well as the elotes, champurrado, tamales, caldos, enchiladas and aguas frescas. This place reminds me a lot of the taquerias in Mexico.
author: Griselda E.

description: Went with a buddy because he had a Groupon.  As mentioned by other Yelpers, I thought it was only us but the lady at the cashier is horrendous.  Super rude, mean looks, attitude.  Its like she's bipolar or something.  One minute she's smiling, the next minute she's giving you dirty looks.  I asked for a sprite and she gave me a 7-up.  The taco guy isn't any better.  I noticed he gave more protein to the hispanics than the non-hispanics.  He also gives attitude and dirty looks. Maybe he and the cashier are related?  Go figure.  This place could be great but they choose to run it run down.  The prices on the to-go menu are different from the restaurant menu.  The prices in store are a bit higher.  They even got my order wrong.  I got a super burrito and it was missing the guac and sour cream.  The salsas here are very down grade and they use a lot of preservatives.  Eat at your own risk.  I would not recommend this place to anyone.  My first and last time.  Below grade service and very divey.  Someone from the health dept. should inspect this place.  There's a notice on the window that they can't sell alcohol.  A guy sitting next to me says they used to sell to minors and fights used to break out because of it.  This place is a has been!  I'll stick to Pancho Villa and Faralito's.  Next place would be La Taqueria who just got voted best burrtio in the nation!  Just saying!
author: Chris S.

description: lengua and buche tacos! bomb! Especially after a night of drinking!
author: isaias J.

description:
i would've never tried this place had it not been for craving mexican comida after going to a nearby ice cream place (Hymphry Slocombe) but i'm glad i did.  it was fate that brought me here.  I was meant to find the true meaning of "el tacorismo" aka the taco.

i knew it was gonna be good when token mexican dude was leaving the restaurant, tripped, stayed on the floor and started snoring.  i was going to help him up, but i knew he was having the time of his life chasing the magical purple unicorn (by the way, did you hear they found an asian unicorn? http://tinyurl.com/24w8obd) so i let him be and i walked in with the crew.

it's a big place, lots of seating, regular taqueria fare but what i completely missed was that i missed the other entrance to the restaurant which is where i found taco heaven! one dude on the mic and another on the turntables...i mean one dude behind a small taco cart on the corner of the restaurant and another dude standing closeby collecting dinero for said tacos.  bunch of meats to try and it's all cooked right in front of you.  you ask for meat, senor puts meat in tortilla, you have a veritable salad bar in front of you in which to dress up said taco, then you eat.  and eat.  and eat. and eat.  for $1.50 a pop, i had carne asada, carnitas, pollo asado, and i forgot the name but right next to it in parenthesis it said "tender beef".  i loaded each and every one of those suckers up with onions, cilantro, some squirts of limon and i finished each and every one...all by myself! 

i wanted to get more but i didn't want to buy out the whole taco stand.  i had a nice little surprise walking out when i saw another table being setup and when i asked what it was they were serving they told me "tamale" i was like dammit i wanna stay but i have to go...i'll be back though...with a vengeance.
author: Ray R.

description: Great tacos good carne .good plates try them out also the best langua tacos hands down
author: Sal L.

description:
HMMMmmmm, how to review my favorite burrito...?
The super carnitas or super shrimp are basically the best in class, from the wide range I've tried in the mission.  
The basis for me, which of course is quite controversial for everyone, is not based on decor, service, or healthy ingredients.  
A true mission burrito, in my humble opinion, is dauntingly heavy, overflowing with whichever meat you choose, oozing with guacamole, crema, queso, while beans and rice soak up the goodness of the others.  
Vallarta gives me all of those, but their shrimp or carnitas are bursting with flavor, likely since they're cooked in plenty of LARD... again, health is not a concern when eating a burrito.  You just need the discipline to split it into 2 meals.  

I've been there over a dozen times for lunch, and a handful for dinner, and only once have i had a noticeably substandard burrito.  The salsa bar is minimal, but the 3 types offer a decent range, and the chips are fresh and warm every time I'm there.  

And this review doesn't even address the taco stand, which most agree is better than the burritos.  

One other point; they make seafood items, if you are brave, and the payoff is pretty good.  The tostada de ceviche is good for a modest charge, and they offer more authentic dishes like soups and full dinner plates.
author: Christian W.

description:
Oh my. It's like heaven in my mouth. MEXICAN heaven. I really like the atmosphere too it's hella Mexican, lol. 

Boy the food is cheap. Is the place clean? Lol, I don't give a fuck the food is good enough for me!
author: Colleen J.

description: Place conveniently open late night....tacos were good?..couldn't tell because the place was terribly dirty i couldn't eat in peace...the place was some what empty yet the workers dint clean....two ladies by the taco stand free but did nothing....not coming back.... coudent fing anywhere clean to sit...husband had to wipe table for ourselves
author: Edith G.

description: This place is as Mexican as it gets in SF! I'm from San Diego and I know good street tacos living 10min from TJ, this place gots it down for sure. I also tried the massive burritos and  caldo de camaron which was a perfect hangover cure. There are tons of Mexican food places in the MIssion but this one stands out from the rest.
author: Danny M.

description:
After dim sum at Hong Kong Lounge and ice cream from Humphrey Slocomb, I really didn't want to eat any more. I had a flight to catch back to LA in a few hours but somehow I got convinced I had to try tacos in SF.

Okay, fine, give me four tacos. This a duty I took seriously. 

I wanted to know what pansita was but they were out of it. I wasn't clear on what pansita was other than it was lamb. I ended up getting carnitas, pastor, lengua and buche.

The tacos were fine, I've had better street tacos in LA.  But these were cheap and very filling. I liked the vibe more and can easily see myself doing the tacos and ice cream thing if I was in the area.
author: Min T.

description:
Homeboy took me to Vallarta

I ordered the Chile Relleno

$8 and five minutes later

My comfort food arrived

Refried beans, avocados, sour cream

The plate was messy

And fatty

But suited my PMS self just fine
author: Sara J.

description:
It's this wildly overpriced city, all I need in this life of sin is a good taco and a $1.75. The whole weekend I spent in the Bay, I was attempting to overcome sticker shock at just how expensive everything is. And I'm coming from NYC so....yeah. 

It's unfortunate I didn't venture to the Mission until the last day of my trip and to make up for it I decided to go on a solo-dolo taco tour. I started here and should have ended here, right at the doorstep. The taco bar soon as you enter is the best bang for your (two) bucks ever in life. It's straight to the point, quick and soooooo awesome-sauce good. You can swing up to the counter to get a 50cent bag of fresh tortilla chips and (I would stick to a small, diabetes ain't cute) cup of overly sweet  fresh cantaloupe juice. 

I had the al pastor and barbacoa taco. Just lovely. I should have ordered 6, instead I stuck to two and ate them waaaay too fast. I don't remember if I got salsa....I think I did. But salsas don't make the taco. So I wasn't too hung up on experiencing the different ways you can spice up a tomato. Taco Vallarta almost made me forget that the Bay doesn't have enough beautiful people to excuse it's straight disrespectful cost of living. Almost.
author: Jasi B.

description:
I am disappointed folks.

I am disappointed that it took me this long to finally try this spot!!!! I was out this past Friday with people that know the city pretty well, so it was pretty awesome to try the food here with several "thumbs up", going into this spot. After a night out, a girl needs to GRUB! 

I am a HUGE fan of street tacos and was so delighted to be there with a friend that has a pretty adventurous palette such as myself, and so I decided to give it a shot and try from their selection of various meats.
 
PROS:
variety of meats to choose from
quick/friendly service
CHEAP $1,50 each.
clean 
opens till late
DIY  cliantro, onions (toppings) 

CONS: 
Honestly can't think of any. This place has earned its 5 stars of awesomeness.

Cant wait to come back!
author: Christina D.

description: Probably you will spend the same amount of money here than in a $$ place. Everything is very spicy, prepare more than one glass of water!
author: Santiago G.

description: At $1.50 per taco, you can't complain and my wallet certainly didn't. This might be my new favorite late night spot to pick up some food if I'm around the Inner Mission.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
I had a veggie burrito here. It was 2am, I was starving, it was cheap, and pretty good. I can't complain.  Well, actually, I think they forgot the sour cream, which was pretty sad.

My friends are obsessed with the tacos here... that's probably the way to go. I'll stick to El Farolito for my late night burrito cravings.
author: Richa A.

description: Extremely authentic $2 tacos until the wee hours of the morning. They have every meat you could want, but they also have some amazing vegetarian burrito options. The shrimp burrito is delicious! The tortas are not very flavorful, so opt for tacos or burritos instead. This is a very popular place for the folks who have been out drinking all night, so also not the cleanest place.. in fact tonight I saw the woman working the cash register also handling food (chips) without washing her hands. Oh well, not like it doesn't happen elsewhere.
author: P U.

description: I went there hungry and came out - NOT! The burrito I ordered was enormous and absolutely bursting with flavor. I am on a diet now but remembering that burrito is causing me to salivate... all that cheese... I can't go on ;) Also the service was fast and the murals and environment were beautiful.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
This place has local flava and a lotta flavor!  If you walk past the taco grill right at the front door and don't order one or more of those delectable $1.50 tacos immediately... you're seriously Doing It Wrong.

Taqueria Vallarta has -- bar none -- the best tacos in the entire city. Yeah. Sup.

You want extra onions, cilantro, and slices of radish?  Help your damn self!  And come on... those carne asada tacos are tasty as all get-out, but they're making you look so gringo, mang.  Go for the al pastor, chorizo, or lengua, silly silly.  Stare at the loopy murals while washing all that crazy taco madness down with a horchata... there! Now you're Doing It Right.
author: Adam E.

description: We had carnitas tacos and a barbacoa taco. I was worried about how they'd be, given that these two meats seemed to come out of little side containers, and I wasn't sure if they'd even be warm, let alone well prepared. Well, they were both great - very flavorful and tender. The carnitas lacked the crispy bits of which I am so fond, but were nonetheless outstanding. The refried beans were nicely seasoned and a little salty, but the rice was overly greasy without being flavorful. I'd go back for the tacos for sure.
author: Lisa K.

description:
After a beautiful rainy day of nonstop grubbing -- we started with thick n creamy coffee at Philz then a huge breakfast at St. Francis Fountain --  topped off our night with tacos here and it couldn't have been any more perfect!

Everything about this place rules. From the simplicity to the authenticity, I loved it. Mmm, I am craving it right now! Me gustaría un taco de carne asada, por favor! The al pastor was also amazeballs.
author: Anita A.

description:
Three.  Little.  Words.

TACOS AL VAPOR

Better than on the streets of Mexico.  For reals.  They have 10 or so meats cooking simultaneously, and you get to mix and match tacos for $1.50 apiece.  And apply your own toppings and salsas.  Their roasted/chipotle salsa was the best I've ever had.
author: Eric S.

description:
This taco place is good if you are on the hunt for some cheap, quick and easy Mexican food. It's not insanely clean which always creates an odd feeling when you are choosing to eat at a new place. It was a bit hectic in there from the ordering station to the seats but that is to be expected during dinner time. 

All in at the end of the day if you aren't picky about ingredients and want a tasty cheap Mexican deal this place is definitely a perfect stop.
author: Josh G.

description:
Hands down the best F'in tacos in the city. 

The cart just inside the door is where you'll get your meat tacos (beef, pork, bbq, tongue, head..all of it). Go to the counter and order a shrimp taco and the ceviche tostado. To the left of the register is a large stone bowl full of some pretty amazing salsa.

They're open late and the murals in the room to the side are worth the visit alone. Late at night they play mexican soap operas that are full of guns, screaming and boobs.
author: Mark R.

description:
Best tacos in the city.  Brought 9 people there, and had 34 tacos, 2 quesadillas and a  burrito.  Excellent pollo and carne asada and carnitas. 

Not many people there a lunch time and a few blocks from Mission make this an attractive spot for a quick tasty lunch.
author: Jay K.

description:
Hey gueros, it's just about the tacos, ok? Just tacos... best on 24th St. 

You want a burrito and some nachos? Go pretty much anywhere else within a five block radius.

G'won.
author: Prattle P.

description: Pretty damn good quesadilla and burritos.  Try a shrimp and chicken burrito.  Awesome. I usually avoid seafood at most restaurant this place knows how to cook shrimp  -- it's fresh and they don't overcook it.
author: Michael C.

description: I have very much enjoyed my visits to Taqueria Vallarta.  I live in the neighborhood and their tacos are very tasty and inexpensive and their employees rock.  I enjoy the bizarre array of mural choices spanning from topless Carnival dancers to Christopher Columbus the Opressor to a floating holy man glowing lightly just above the golden gate bridge and above the word "Taqueria".    The ambience cannot be beat, nor can the prices.  Best of all, pigeons will sit next to you and assist you with eating your leftovers.
author: Gwen P.

description: Get the barbacoa taco (or 3) if you love juicy meat that just melts in your mouth!   I also love how you can add your own toppings.  People rave about these $1.50 tacos for a reason!!
author: Beatrice W.

description:
Taqueria Vallarta has a legit set-up with its taco cart out front. I love that I get to self-serve garnishes and salsa (all of which are fresh and tasty). Don't forget that there's an additional bar by the register, where you can get your pickled condiments -- BF found this out too late, much to his sadness.

To be frank, the tacos weren't as good as I'd expected. I was excited about trying real barbacoa meat.. but I was a little hesitant when I saw it being pulled out from the chafing dishes on the side (vs the skillet). Some might say the meat was tender, but I thought it was mushy and bland. The real dealbreaker was the globs of fat throughout the meat.. I almost lost my appetite when I bit into a huge chunk of soggy fat. Al pastor was redeeming but still not knock-my-socks-off. Too bad!
author: Julie D.

description:
Yup.

Tacos. NOT burritos. Sometimes nachos.


The best Al Pastor in town.  I have tried every one of their meats and pastor is the winner.

BYOB + $1.50 Al Pastor tacos = a great start/end to the night.
author: Phil P.

description:
$1.50 Tacos:  Carne Asada, Pollo, Carnitas, ahhh soo many to choose from.  Don't forget to ask for the girlled onions.  Just get one of each and pile up on the extras:  Cilantro, Radishes, Salsas, the works.

Best tacos for the price around.  This is what a STREET TACO is ALL about.  Don't complain about how dirty the restaurant is, who's standing in line while you're standing in line, or that you don't have cash....you can still use your card inside the restaurant!  While you're at it, read the story line on the mural.  It'll give you a good giggle.
author: Char C. B.

description:
Taqueria Vallarta: Never judge a book by its cover. Or a tamale by its husk?

I walk by Vallarta almost every day and almost invariably every day am dissuaded by the state of the storefront and even more so by the dimly lit interior and barren interior. Let's be honest: Vallarta looks like a dump.

But, after reading rave reviews about their tacos, I bucked up and dropped in for a feast. By hell, high water, or food poisoning, I would have a verdict on this place. I ordered the chicken enchilada and shrimp plate with a side order of two tacos. I chose chicken and shrimp because those are real gauges of a cook's abilities: cooked too long and both are stringy and tough, cooked too short and both are down right inedible. When the plate arrived with all of its goodness, the shrimp looked slightly burnt and the chicken enchilada looked stale. I was disappointed. That is, until my first bite. Damn my expectations and my prejudices, because the food was amazing. I was blown back at how supple and succulent everything tasted. The shrimp was just right so that it had a nice bite and was seasoned just well enough to keep the flavors together. The chicken enchilada was superb as well; the chicken was moist and the sauce was just balanced between the sweetness and bitterness that you should be getting. My only complaint was the fatty vein through the chicken, but I had no problem picking it out. Anyways, props to you, Vallarta, for converting me and making me a believer. I will definitely be back for more.

As for the tacos, well, all of us Yelpers can't be wrong, right? Vallarta has perfected the street taco so no need to sing more praise. If anything, just come in here for some tacos.
author: Frank Y.

description:
Decided to have dessert after grabbing ice cream at Humphry Slocombe's and stumbled into Taqueria Vallarta. I instantly fell in love when I saw they had a taco station separate from the usual order area. 

I felt like I took a trip to Tijuana or something cause it was taco served street food style. I got my self an al pastor and a lengua taco with a guava Jarritos to wash it down and it was mmmmmm good! Wish I could've ordered stuff of their regular menu too because there was a lot good stuff on there. Also got jealous of an old man munching on a whole corn with queso fresco. I will definitely be coming back here for dessert after another run to Humphry Slocombe.
author: Rommel N.

description:
recommended by a friend and backed by all the yelp reviews... i've tried a few other taquerias in the area but vallarta remains my go-to joint. 

there is a separate taco bar to order your tacos. top with onions, cilantro, & salsa to your hearts desire at the self-serve station, then walk over to the register to pay for your goodies.

if i need my fix of street tacos i just pop in to devour a few carne asada tacos and walk out a few minutes later, completely satisfied.
author: Christine K.

description: Good taco meat selection but the burritos aren't nothing special.  The lady that works the day time registere is rude.  Wanted to exchange a side on a plate and gave me the stare down.
author: Julio G.

description:
BEST most authentic tacos at a mere $1.50 each! Try the cabeza and al pastor...although I'm sure they're all amazing!

Munch away alongside many happy pigeons strutting about the room eating your fallen bits of meat and salsa! They didn't jump on the tables and I didn't see any pigeon poop, so I wasn't bothered. Que autentico!
author: Jeannie C.

description:
Best Hole in the Wall Taco spot! (so far)

A+ for carne asada, lengua, buche, y carnitas tacos!

Fast, friendly server.

Great fixings = lemon, chopped onion, cilantro, 3 sauces. (i prefer the green)

never had the chicken but my friend wouldn't suggest it.
author: Ben T.

description:
My girlfriend says that these tacos are like the ones you'll find in Puerto Vallerta except that the guy behind the taco stand uses tongs instead of bare hands.  So I added a star. 

Overall I say that I'm impressed by the tacos, but I haven't had anything else. The tripita (tripe) tacos were so tasty and full of flavor.  I don't even like Mexican food that much and I have to admit these were good tacos.

Definitely try the tacos. They're worth the visit.
author: V L.

description:
We started off looking for a restaurant called Soul Groove I found on yelp and it just went downhill from there.  Since we were hungry & already in the Mission, I remembered hearing about this place from a client.  I've been going to El Farolito forever but was told this place was better.  Uh...NO!  This is by far the WORSE Mexican food I've ever had

My husband ordered a super burrito with carne asada, he rated it a 2 on a scale of 10

My son ordered a super burrito with chicken, asked for no onions and there was cilantro (which he doesn't eat) AND onions.  When I took it to the counter & told them, the girl at the register says it's suppose to have cilantro in it and that there was no onions.  This would be I brought it from home & placed it his burrito, right?  It took awhile to have a new one made.

I ordered a fish filet with diablo sauce.  I asked what kind of fish it was and the cook said salmon, white salmon called catfish.  omfg!  I wanted fish so I ordered it.  I started this rating by saying it was the WORSE Mexican food, well, this was the WORSE fish so it has won 2 ribbons tonight.  The food was so salty, I'm sure the cook must've had an accident & spilled 1/2 the container on my food.  I just want to know who taught these people how to cook and why were there people in there that obviously has eaten there before.

I'm not Mexican but I bet you I can make better Mexican food than this place.  If you're yelping for somewhere to go, do not come here!!!  Go down the street to El Farolito.  It's on the other side of the street a block down (away from Mission).

People who gave this place anything more than 1 star obviously don't know good food.  Warning!  Run!  Don't come here! 

I have never wanted to stick my finger down my throat as bad as now, to get that shit our of my system. ugh!
author: May G.

description:
Never had a bad experience here, been about 25 times or so. Great taco stand in the entrance with a large meat selection and $1.50 tacos.

Great prices, most Taquerias in the Mission have Super Burrittos for $7-8 or more. Vallarta has them for $5! Delicious Carne Asada, nice amount of flavor without being over-seasoned. 

Big fan of Cilantro, which they use a lot of and it really makes their food stand out for me. 

Great ratio of ingredients, never had too much sour cream, guacomole,  rice, or salsa. Decent sized Burritto's as well, not HUGE, but very filling, about 9" long. Especially good for $5.

Consistent quality of food, clean colorful wide-open dining area, GREAT prices, and almost always very friendly service. A+!
author: Chris G.

description:
I used to LOVE this place for their ultra-tasty $1.50 tacos.

Then, I spent two days puking and otherwise ejecting my insides.  I couldn't even hold down water.  I literally considered going to the hospital to get a saline drip, I was that dehydrated.

Of course, I did try all the interesting meats, like tongue, brain, stomach, etc., in addition to my usual pork.

Basically, nosh at your own risk.
author: Dmytro A.

description: Late night tacos in the mission...YUM!!! You don't come to Taqueria Vallarta for the standard Carnitas, Carne Asada, Chorizo, Al Pastor, or Pollo Asado (yawn) - you can get those anywhere else. You come to Taqueria Vallarta for Cabeza, Lengua, Tripita, and Buche - the good stuff.
author: MyGirl L.

description:
$1.50 for tacos, and that's a steal. You get unlimited onions, cilantro, and  omg, wow muy delicioso.

I'm definitely coming back here again.
Another positive is the flat screen in the adjacent sitting room. 
Muy excellente
author: Cerina C.

description:
Best DOLLAR FIFTY tacos anywhere.

I'm especially fond of the BBQ pork tacos. Piles of fresh radishes, lemons, onions, a variety of sauces, all for $1.50 each.

The meats are tender, delicious, and fresh. I'm extremely impressed with the barbacoa (goat) which has been braised and cooked to eliminate even a hint of gaminess.

Also, the chips are thin, crisp, and freshly fried. The salsas are super yum.

LOVE LOVE LOVE.
author: SisterMable S.

description: Tacos were really really good first thing i had when i got to sanfran cant beat cali mexican food
author: Eddie E.

description:
This place is just past Folsom St. on 24th.
It's cheap and exceptionally delicious. Beyond the $1.50 tacos, they do have great burritos, quesadillas, nachos and combo plates too. All are reasonably priced and there are huge portions. This is hands down my favorite taqueria in the neighborhood. It's really, really tasty.

Things that set this place apart: 

I love this place because its super low key with tons of seating and always uncrowded.  The 49er/history of SF mural in the main eating area is epic. It's a little off the beaten path, so you aren't standing in line eying a table or hovering for a place to sit like every other taqueria in the Mission on a weekend. I like that local Mexican families actually eat here and it's a relatively hipster-free zone. yay!

You can also use a credit card which is awesome! I doubt you can use it to purchase the little tacos, but the rest of the menu is fair game.
author: Merrill S.

description: Taco bar Hands down goodness, the area is really sketchy but that doesn't stop me from coming here!
author: Jay K.

description:
YES! A taqueria that makes a decent VEGGIE GRILL BURRITO. I'm not even a vegetarian and the few times I've been here, I always get the veggie grill. I haven't even tried the SUPER VEGGIE GRILL because I am just that boring and satisfied with Vallarta's delicioso version. 

Funny, I think the reason why the veggie grill tastes so good is because it was grilled on the same surface as the other meats. Meat burritos also bother me a bit since I've been to places where it's a "chicken" burrito but it's just full of fat and gristle. So veggie burrito, not quite vegetarian, but soooo good. You have been warned. 

Oh, and my BF loveeees their lengua tacos. Late night spot for munchies. Nom nom.
author: Jean L.

description:
Tried Taqeria Vallarta after reading Yelp reviews for a trip to eat my way through the Mission... I found that they have great carne asada tacos! 

I ordered 2 tacos from the man with a taco set up by the door. He made them by using a heated black cook surface that cooked the tortilla in the middle and the meats on the side. Lickity split I had two fresh tacos, and I was paying for my meal at the back counter. 

I seated myself in the adjoining space- at the wooden themed tables- and ate my flavorful, tender, and fresh- but greasy- tacos in delight... it only took a few minutes... 

FYI's~ 
* Easy to find
* Typical taco stand prices 
* They like you to use cash... small bills... anything slightly large gets you dirty looks 
* The space is split into two seating areas 
* The taco station is by the door- go and get them 
* The menu is above the counter station and kitchen in the back 
* Sell combos, taco, burritos, & most anything typically found at a Taqueria 
* Lots of tables and seating 
* Order- receive- sit- eat
author: Natalie W.

description: Good cheap tacos.  who can ask for anything better?!  Although, I did see a homeless dude try to start a fit with the manager.  Swearing and racism do not go as well with tacos as I thought.  Al Pastor, Chicken and Barbacoa were awesome and so are the grilled onions they have for them!
author: Jordan S.

description:
Great taco stand -- tacos only 1.50! Also the enchiladas are really good, but try to avoid the beans, they're too salty. 

The restaurant itself is pretty cool and the people are really nice.
author: Tapan P.

description: The tacos are amazing!!!! Every time I bring a friend from my home town they fall in love but....don't get their coctel de camaron because they never have it prepared so they have to cook the shrimp and then you have a warm coctel and it should always be served chilled.
author: Lisa B.

description: This is how Mexican food is supposed to taste. Not like all the hipsters and foodies think Mexican food is.Yes, not glamorous inside but this isn't a fine dining Mexican restaurant. So the review is based off of the food only. And for the one review I read that the burrito was greasy.... HA HA. That's like saying no grease please in my Philly cheese steak. Forget about it.
author: Derek S.

description: This was my first visit here and I had the enchiladas plate. The enchiladas were okay, nothing to go crazy over. Oh and what I was really looking forward to was a nice cold corona. But they DIDN'T have ANY BEER ! I was pretty bummed out about that.
author: Taku K.

description:
I ate here on a whim one day while leaving my friends house down the street. They have the BEST tacos I've had in the bay area. The selection of meats, the soaked onion, it reminds me of the food carts back home (Los Angeles). The beans are also fantastic as is the menudo.

EDIT: After visiting what seems like EVERY mexican place in the MIssion (is that even possible?), I've come to the conclusion that this is my favorite Mexican; YUM.
author: Audrey A.

description: Where do you eat lunch on Christmas Day after visiting a friend recuperating from an accident at SF General?  Taqueria Vallarta!  We headed down 24th Street just hoping to find something open, and there it was.  We knew nothing about the place, but hospital visits always make me ravenous, so we stopped.  Two carne asada dinner plates and two cane-sugar Cokes later, we were very satisfied.  The beef was dry, like thin jerky, but with a nice tang and topped with full-sized grilled green onions.  The rice and beans mixed very nicely with the bit of salad topped with sour cream.  Add chips, tortillas, friendly service and exit happy.  Feliz Navidad!
author: Michael C.

description: My friend got a burrito and said it was really good and great price, just over $5, they finished it and wanted another one even though they were full! I get the tacos when I go here, they are $1.75 each and are really good and quick. You get 2 mini tortillas and a pile of meat then you can put onions, cilantro, salsa or radishes on top. The grilled chicken is my fav. the carne asada is a little hit and miss, one time it was under seasoned and another time it was over seasoned. The carnitas is standard, the barbacoa is really tender and pulled which is yummy but it gets stuck in your teeth. My husband liked the lengua. They have several other meats to choose too. My complaint is there is only one guy doing tacos with a really small surface to warm tortillas so it can take a little longer than necessary esp if there is a line. During certain times, there is a lady on the other side of the restaurant selling Mexican style corn on the cob with cotija and chile. I have yet to try that but I really want to. I think she might sell Atol de elote too over there. So when Casa Sanchez is really busy or you don't feel like spending much, grab a few tacos here. Oh, one other downside is they charge $.50 for chips and they are usually too done (a little burnt and bitter) and the salsa is just ok. If you want a chips and salsa orgasm go to Pancho Villa on 16th.
author: Emma H.

description: Anyone who gives this place less than 5 stars must hate good tacos. Taqueria Vallarta makes and serves tacos the way they should be. None of that $4+ crap tacos you find in the Marina...
author: Sarah Z.

description: Turned on to this place by a friend. Awesome tacos. I've never tried anything else here cuz the tacos are soo bomb!!  You barely have to wait in line. The service is quick. I suggest the carne asada and the al pastor (BBQ pork). Top it off with a bottle of Coke and you are in heaven. Believe me, you will be craving these tacos at all hours of the day an night. Oh and bring change for the meter!
author: David B.

description:
2 Words: Taco Bar....

4 more: Cows and Pigs, RUN!

OK 6 more: Woohoo! As good as it gets!

and for $1.50 each!?!? Alright, Im done!
author: Nick V.

description:
Best tacos in the city, hands down. It's authentic, open late, cheap as hell, and delicious. What more could you ask for?!

They also have a huge drink selection with my favorite Mexican sodas and drinks. Try the sangria soda if you haven't yet.

I come here often whenever I need my taco fix. :)
author: Tay R.

description: Arrived from NYC and headed straight to La Taqueria, my long time face place in town.  But it was closed for th holiday stretch.  Somoeone recommended  Vallarta, and it was a score!  The taco bar makes it easy and quick to order, and the meats were prepped to perfection.  No post-eating indigestion here.  And if you like horchata, this is your place.  Enjoy.
author: David A.

description:
Still think their tacos are the most delicious and most authentic in San Francisco.  Their tacos are not for everyone, just the ones who want the REAL DEAL!!!! Their tacos are like the ones you find in Mexico!!!

Here' s my tribute video...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zdTGLVYox-M
author: Demanding T.

description: shut down by the health department!!! what the hell?? too many hands in the cilantro?  I'm disappointed. don't know why, but maybe its better if I never know. weak.
author: Brian R.

description: This place is really good! We just got the burrito's, both "all meat" and they were very good. Not the largest, but they were only roughly $6 each! I got the carnitas, mmmmm, and she got the Pastor which she thoroughly enjoyed as well. Eat there if you can and enjoy the various salsa's with your chips.
author: Larry B.

description: As a mexican, these are the best tacos in San Francisco. I love the choice of meats they have. I always bring guests out of town here and never go wrong!
author: Alejandro M.

description: I could smell the place from down the block and followed my nose like Toucan Sam...My nose did not let me down. The tacos were just as delicious as they smelled. The bummer was that there were chunks of fat in my Assad taco. I KNOW that's what made them taste so delicious. So, so, so delicious. My favorite part was that the soft tacos had crispy edges - it was a very nice touch - and grilled onions to boot. AND you can add whichever sauces you like to custom your taco. The art on the walls just added to the great, authentic character of the joint. That and a Tamarindo. It was a perfect end to a long, long , LONG day.
author: Chia C.

description:
Seriously good $1.50 tacos in the Mission.  I was taken here by my girlfriend's brother on a beer and tacos bike tour of the Mission.  I ordered 4 Al Pastors and could easily have eaten 4 more, all washed down with a long neck Orange Fanta.  It was pretty much the best meal of my 4 days in SFO.  

We got there at a pretty decent time but the line fluctuated up to 15 deep at some points.  Fantastic murals all over there walls and some nonsense about the 49ers having the strength of the Buffalo, the speed of a puma....and I forget the rest, but awesome nonetheless.  This place wouldn't stick out from the street more than any other place but I thought they did a fantastic job, some of the best "cheap" tacos I've ever had.
author: Christopher T.

description:
OK, here's the scoop.  Beautifully delicious, overflowing tacos, your choice of about a dozen meats, cooked on a grill in front of the door, a buck fifty a piece.  Look, I'd pay a helluva lot more for those tacos.  Two of them makes a huge plate of food.  They aren't just plentiful, but they are succulent, delicious and exciting!

I've tried the other dishes, too, and they're all seriously respectable dishes.

But those tacos.  Those f*'ing tacos!  They are some of the best I've ever had, here or even in Mexico. 

5 tacos for two people and two sodas, $10  ---and VERY full tummies.  I cannot find a single complaint about Vallarta.
author: Amy A.

description:
parking is difficult sometimes...well, early in the day its easy...afternoon to evening somewhat difficult.  late evening, none around.

if you're craving an authentic taco like they sell on one of those taco trucks...this place has them.  1.75 lots of choices of meat, with grilled onions.  add cilantro and fresh onions and your choice of mild sauce or medium or hot sauce.

its right by the door if you only want a taco or two or more.

if you want a burrito, chimchanga(deep friend burrito0, or a wet burrito, go into the restaurant and its right there.  HUGE selection of Veggie Burritos, or Grilled Burritos that have grilled carrot and mushroom.

They have tomato, spinach, whole wheat, or regular tortillas for your burrito.

what can i say?  its a very good place and you shouldn't be disappointed.  Its tastes so good.  The burrito isn't huge therefore the 4 stars instead of 5...but the taste keeps it at a four.

if you don't speak spanish...sometimes you might be misunderstood...or vice versa.  The lady was only asking me if i was paying in cash or???  I felt sad that my 3 years of spanish in high school wasn't worth a damn...my fault i'd assume.
author: Bing D.

description: It may look doubtful but you miss out if you don't try the tender beef at least and try the salsa, sauces-for 1.75 a taco how can you miss? Meats were moist, flavorful!
author: M M.

description:
Good lawd what 2 1/2 years of bad Mexican food will do to a brotha!  After searching high and low for authentic tacos in Australia, I really came to miss the Mission taquerías I love so much. . . Now having said that, one night recently I could not decide which of my tried and true to hit up.  My lil bro's girlfriend just came in from work and I asked her opinion.  She directed me to Taquería Vallarta, making mention of some special contraption and taco man serving to you en vivo.  I was pleased to arrive minutes later and discover that the prices weren't bad either.

The line of 5-6 people out the door may have been enough to scare off the less hungry skeptics. It was refreshing to see so many Latinos at one time and ordering their food in Spanish (give me a break I still can't get the Aussie accent outta my head). I settled for four tacos al pastor (pork) and felt my mouth prepare itself as I slathered them with salsa, onions and cilantro.  My friends those four tacos were GONE in four minutes! I had to leap out of my chair to get a good spot back in line for four more! Yes, I have been gone too long.

What I can tell you about the flavor is that the meat was spiced gorgeously, the tortillas sufficiently warmed and salsa recipe was incredible. It melted in my mouth and I did not care that it warmed my belly a bit too. I had an horchata, as you do, to assist in the cooling of this symptom. I'll defo be back for more tacos here mate!

PS I think the taco man only cooks in his "olla" on the weekends.
author: Sammy R.

description:
Ay dios mio!  If heaven were taqueria, this would be it.  Although I'm a native New Englander who's exposure to tacos is Chipotle and Anna's Taqueria, I know a good taco when I have one.   This place is off the hizook.  $1.50 tacos and the real shiznit for fillings, lengua and cabeza (head) which is extremely hard to find in MA.  The ceviche tostada was amazing too.  And to top that, the tortilla chips and salsa are all free!!
I'm gonna be depressed when I have mexican food back in MA.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Two words: TACO BAR.

I pass this place all the time, but once I found out you can get a taco for $1.50 complete with your choice of meat (which is heaping) and then you have complete freedom to make the fixings, well. Shit was over.

We each got two/three tacos apiece, and then split a bowl of posole - stuffing three kids full of food love and for $16 is what I'm talking about. The posole was super hot when it came out for us and we all burned our tongues, but after we let it cool down we noshed hardcore. It had tender meat falling off the bones as we chipped away with our tortillas and the broth was flavorful and thick.

Obviously this place is popular with the late night crowd since beer and tacos were married in a previous life, but the taco bar alone in the front makes a visit to Vallarta worth your while.
author: Jenz y.

description: OMG by far the best tacos I've had.. they have so many options for meat too!!! They close at 4am so imma have to come after the club
author: Donovan R.

description: Really cheap $1.75 tacos for the meat eaters, but a really good variety of veggie burritos with nopales and squash in them. I split a San Francisco Plate with a friend last time: 4 large oysters, 6 prawns and a large fillet of tilapia. It was garlicky amazing goodness. NOM! I would go back because the price is right, was $13.00 for the large plate which included rice and refried beans. It's a bit dirty on the inside but fairly authentic and good meals can be had without the stomach upset. Oh and they are open very late, which is a MAJOR plus for night owls who need a quick taco fix after leaving the bar.
author: Gina R.

description:
I never give 5 stars, just a rule because no restaurant is perfect.  I limit my meat to just fish, but I know a good lengua o cabeza taco when I smell and see one.  The fish taco gets a D, yeah for Delicious.   If I were to complain it would be that the meat, on the tacos, is so juicy you need a million napkins.  

Also, try the ceveche tostada.  Actually can everyone just stay away or limit yourselves to once a month I want to keep this my little secret.
author: michael h.

description:
This place used to be only minutes away from my old spot. While I'm sure that other Taqueria Vallarta patrons have seen be in various stages of sobriety depending on when I'd be grabbing tacos (late night tacos, definitely where it's at), I can confidently say that I have been a happy and satisfied customer each & every time. Sure, the burritos here aren't the best in the mission or even on 24th st, they still do the job and are good enough. 

The TACOS though. That's why you go here, we all know this by now. Not only do they have a separate taco bar at the front of the restaurant (with lines out the door during busy times), but their selection of meats is is stellar: excellent executed standards (al pastor, carnitas, chicken, etc.) and enticing for the adventurous eater. 

On Saturday I got a taco trio of suadero, lengua, and tripa. Big ups to the grilled onions they have soaked up the juices of the meat on the taco meat grill too. Complemented by all the cilantro, onions, lime, radish, and salas you need too. All delicious, and only around $6 for everything. 

Was nice to be back, Vallarta. Will see you soon, sober or not!
author: George C.

description:
I could have sworn I wrote a review for this place ages ago but I guess not so here it goes:

I used to be obsessed with this place when my boyfriend lived down the street. We would eat here bi-weekly. The tacos are delicious, authentic, affordable and delicious. Yes, I said it twice.

Then something bad happened. One night after gorging on tacos, I had a rumbly in my tumbly. Not the cute kind. I had wicked bad food poisoning. Hey, it happens.

Were approaching almost 2 years since this event, and I can say as I write this review I am totally craving a taco right now. The next time I'm in the mission, Vallarta is getting another chance.
author: Britney K.

description: not familiar with San Fran and after long search and trying to find parking we found this place. My daughter had the taco bar- 3 carne asada tacos, she said they were the best she has tasted..I had the Vegeterian burrito (nopales) it was very flavorful and for the price you can't beat it. - 12$ was my bill- awesome!
author: Debbie D D.

description:
Wheel of meat, wheel of meat, wheel of friggin' meat! I had brain, stomach, and steak tacos. I wanted cheek but they were out. Each cooked animal part is sectioned off and together create a circle around a small saute hub/pan. You pick the desired meat from the magical wheel and the man whips you up a taco. For a $1.50 a taco, you can't beat it. The horchata is also 1.50 and damn good spicy rice water it is. This IS the late night fatty's wheel of fortune, just don't land bankrupt on the mixed innards/liver.  

The tortillas could be slightly fresher.  -the dark red sauce is great, spicy and smokey.
author: Jake H.

description:
The next time you crave for tacos or carne asada burritos, 
BMW (Bike, Motor, Walk) your butt here.

Noisy as a high school cafeteria
Swarming like paparazzi on Chris Brown

but

Affordable as a McD Happy Meal
Quick like a squirrel, climbing up a tree.
author: CT L.

description: $1.75 tacos, with something like 8 different types of meats.  You put your own toppings and sauce.  I'll definitely be back to try the other meats.  Another plus is there's a nice ice cream place around the corner, Humphry Slocombe.
author: Matthew P.

description:
1.75 cabeza tacos late night? this place is legit.

go for the crazy stuff like cabeza or lengua... you seriously don't know what you're missing. You just gotta get over it. The cabeza and lengua are so tender and flavorful... you'd probably forget about carne asada and chicken. They give a ton of meat per taco... though I would say the only thing missing is an option to pay a little more to jazz it up with cheese, avocado, and sour cream (if you're into making it into a mini burrito).

I also got a carne asada burrito mojado, which was OK and caused me to dock it 1 star.

Pro-Tip... read the story on the wall... either drunk or sober... for maximum entertainment. Also... stick with the tacos... everything else is OK, but the tacos are such a great value and are way more delicious than their other foods.
author: Marc T.

description:
This place really surprised the shit out of me. So.........I was looking for phat philly on 24th st. in which Genevieve y. told me of this place. I must have walked 7 blocks looking for phat philly and gave up. So............we walked into Taqueria Vallarta. 

I ordered the pescado with rice, refried beans, lettuce, avocados, fresh limes and salsa. It was fantastic. The tortillas was a little too crispy for me. My friend had the chicken flatas.............it was also very good. I asked him since he is of Latino decent.............if it was good. He goes..........it is surprisingly good. 

The location of this place is in an up and coming area. It's still a little rough but the food is awesome. It reminds me of a typical Mexican restaurant in Mexico. They had the wooded benches and the porcelain table tops. They had a separate food stand in the restaurant selling 1.50 tacos. I thought that was kinda cool. 

Don B...............you are absolutely right about this place.
author: jason g.

description: It's a good food and place. The only thing I didn't like is that if you pay with a credit card they charge "$1.50" fee...Hmm! I think that's ridiculous and abusive...
author: Beto L.

description:
I love so much: it's the real deal. Everyone who runs this place is so awesome: they have fed me so well for so long, I feel I have to give back. 

Yes, the late-night taco bar is amazing (only thing many people seem to experience). But veggie-lovers should not miss the "Burrito Grill" (super or regular: it's not on the menu anymore, you have to ask for it) which is awwwwesome. Also, on the weekends when every breakfast place in town has a ridiculous line, this spot offers the cheapest, best desayuno going. The only coffee is instant, but Philz is just a block away, so you'll make do. 

And this place functions in Spanish, so please speak all the Spanish you can, keep yourself low-key, and let's keep this place legit and not let it suffer the same terrible fate (of becoming trendy then sucking) as the Cancuns and Farolitos of the world! :-)
author: Luke F.

description: This place is really good.  I had the super shrimp (camerones) burrito.  It was amazing.  The shrimp could of used  a little more seasoning but it was still amazing because they were cooked perfectly.  The pico de gallo is amazing as well.  By far best pico i have had in awhile. I highly recommend this place.  They also have a little taco bar that looked really good, didnt try it though.  All in all  Id tear this place up on a drunken night, just sayin..
author: Sabrina H.

description:
This is the best place I've stumbled upon so far in SF.
It's my place to go to, to satisfy my taco cravings. From the ones I've tried there so far, my favorite is pork. 

Just looking at the taco cart makes my mouth water. And I love how I get to put on as much cilantro and onions and salsa as I want! And best thing about the place is the price! And the business hours (open late!). And easy access (lots of seating, no lines)! 

Oh! And at night there is also a tamale table sitting there in the next room..  staring at you with yummy tamale eyes and corn on the cob nose.. just asking you to eat more... 

.. I can't resist. I crave this place day and night. Maybe finding this place wasn't the best thing for me...
author: Nhi T.

description: You can probably toss a tortilla 20 feet in any direction in the Mission and find a good taqueria, but Taqueria Vallarta has a vibe unlike any other. Best as I can tell, the people that run it know about food, care about quality, and care about freshness -- and it shows. All the details were spot on, including a couple of actual, fresh avocado slices on my included salad, a tomato slice that tasted and looked like an actual, ripe tomato, excellent salsa, and sour cream that wasn't diluted with (we hope just) water. We didn't try the $2 taco bar, but that looked awesome, too. The dining area has a dozen or so wooden tables with a hard wooden bench on either side, and some great hand-painted folk murals on the wall. Keep in mind this isn't really a restaurant, it's a very inexpensive taqueria, so it's informal, a little messy, and a little rough around the edges. Don't go here for a romantic evening, don't go here if that was your lowered CLS550 parked a few doors down, but do go here for some of the best food of its type I've had in San Francisco. No liquor license yet, but they're working on it.
author: Richard A.

description:
4.5 stars. 

Great tacos. Love places that push the edge and aren't afraid to serve all cuts of meat. Cheap, too, at $1.50. You can also have all the free chips and salsa you want with it.

Mmmm....brain.
author: Mark A.

description: I don't spend a lot of time out on 24th Street seeing as how I live downtown but every month or so I head out for a content meeting with Asterisk SF Magazine. We get some coffee at Haus, throw some ideas around and hang out for a couple hours.By the time we're done we're all starving. Last night, we headed over to Taqueria Vallarta. I started longingly at all the pictures on their menu and settled on the carnitas. They looked amazing so I ordered that and while I was at it I threw in some fajita-style peppers and onions. It tasted as good as it looked except the portions were HUGE. I felt like I was wasting a lot of food (we were getting a drink afterwards so I couldn't tote it around). The only downside to this joint is that it has a lot of open doors on to the street. It was FRIGID inside which can be annoying when you're trying to enjoy your food; teeth chattering can get in the way.
author: Julia N.

description: Best taqueria in SF, love the carne asada, carnitas, and lengua.
author: Misha C.

description:
The tacos are really amazing. I haven't seen tacos made this way outside of mexico.

 And the menu items at the counter are actually pretty good as well. But the five stars are for the tacos.
author: Stephen W.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite tacquerias in San Francisco. It's open late, has more style than the other tacquerias, and offers up at least average Mexican food. There' s something about this place--maybe it's the blue exterior. There's also a giant mural in the main room (of 2 rooms) to gawk at when ur drunk early in the morning.

I got a super shrimp burrito here, and have gotten some tacos at their taco bar. The tacos are super cheap, and you can get chicken, beef, and pork among other meats.
author: Epicurean _.

description: My absolute fav Mexican taco place in the mission.  Everyone needs to try their tacos!  I always get the buche (pork neck) and lengua (beef tongue).  If you're an adventurous eater, you won't be disappointed witht these tacos!
author: Elaine N.

description:
The taco stand at the door is freaking AWESOME! I've never seen meat and corn tortilla cooked on a surface like that. The tacos are $1.50 each. The beef tongue...yummy! Gotta have it if you like chicken gizzard and things like pig kidney. It's got a semi-chewy consistency and seasoned well.

I got a fantastic carnitas wet burrito. It was HUGE! It easily could've been two meals (for under $7) but I was damn hungry. The carnitas was cooked to perfection: tender, shreds apart easily and still succulent. And that red sauce on top...I can't even put into words. 

I was going to try a tamale but there just wasn't any room in my stomach for it. I was still full when I woke up the next morning.

There were two things: NO BEER and the foosball table looked like it was out of commission...otherwise, I'd give it 5 stars.
author: Cat T.

description:
Love their $1.50 tacos!

Having lengua available at a taqueria is essential! The lengua is cooked well but not so much on the flavoring side. Topping with a heaping amount of hot sauce and salsa is crucial.

Can't go wrong with the carne asada either!
author: Susie L.

description: They were closed for a bit for cough cough involuntary renovation, but they're back...Tacos are now a whopping $1.75.
author: Darren K.

description: Best Tacos in the city hands down! Vegetarians, hipsters, and pretentious white people STAY AWAY!! Go to your stupid, overpriced, white washed , non-authentic Mexicali spot. That is were you belong and everyone else that truly loves a real authentic Mexican taco spot this is where U belong! The rotating wheel of death and carnage is serving it up till 3 AM!
author: Ethan S.

description:
It was fine. I love the style of taco--2 layered thin corn tortillas slightly grilled and filled with any meat you want. The chorizo didn't have enough of a chewy texture and the carne asada was just ok. I did enjoy the carnitas and my husband liked the pollo. The sauces were great.


For this style of taco I prefer Los Compadres Taco Truck. 

The plates looked interesting so I might come back for those.
author: Thanya S.

description:
We went here for a birthday dinner this Thursday evening.  The ambiance was authentic, and the ceiling in the back room had one hell of a cool murial of San Francisco culture (a must see as it cannot be described).  The food was out of this world.  I got a Super Burrito Carne.. It had all the right fixins -  My only downside was that the veggies/salsa weren't mixed in too well with my meat.  As a result, one half of my burrito was warm, and the other was pretty cold.  Beyond that, I thought the burrito was pretty dang good.

The price was definitely affordable, and there was enough space for our entire party of 8.
author: Bryan H.

description:
Sorry Karl, but all I could think as we drunkenly walked and walked and walked and walked (okay, it probably wasn't that far, but when you are taking one step forward, one to the side and two back with 10 other people it SEEMS far) was what the hell are we doing?

What can this British dude teach my Southern Californian friend and I about a good taqueria? Look, Karl, we just passed one that is decent and we are HUNGRY! Look Karl, there's another equally acceptable place....where are we going!!!??

Plus, these bottles of booze in my bag that I bought on the street corner from that guy (for a REALLY good deal) are getting heavy. This better be worth it, and I know its not going to be. You are British, after all, and I have been to England and the food there sucks, with the exception of the Indian food, but we are not going to an Indian place. We are getting Mexican food. I am fucked. 

Then we finally arrived. This place was good! And they even had a taco stand near the front and the regular counter near the back, making it feel more authentic than most of the taquerias here in Northern California. There was plenty of room to sit and salsa that was actually hot and flavorful. The carnitas was not overcooked, but not soggy (this is HUGE). 

I am sorry Karl. I suck. I am sorry I doubted you and stereotyped the English and I will wear flats next time we drink together and refrain from making street deals on booze so we can walk as far as you want. I owe you a burrito or a few tacos or something......I will even eat English food if it is recommended by you!
author: Drue C.

description:
This was a pretty typical SF taqueria in my book.  Decently friendly service. Decently clean.  Plus points for the quirky details like murals of the Golden Gate Bridge and the 49ers and a stuffed animal claw machine. Minus points for the "borracho" (drunk guy) who wandered around and hit on every woman in the joint and got WAY too close for comfort.

It gets four stars because I happen to always order a vegetarian burrito every time I go to a taqueria and this was among the best! wonderful proportions of rice, beans and cheese, and the avocado and sour cream were just right. Mmm mmm.  

Also in wonderfully close proximity to world famous Balmy Alley. So grab a burrito and a bottle of jarritos, walk around the corner to view some murals on a sunny day... sounds like heaven to me.
author: Laura P.

description: Hands down best tacos in the city! Try the barbacoa! dear lord, AMAZING!
author: Nick D.

description:
I love this place. I love the $1.50 taco cart full of cabeza, lengue, & weird 'parts'. 

For some reason I had an urge to cab it to 24th street last night, and my friend was hungry, so of course I said we have to find the taco cart taqueria. Its my favorite little spot to go to in the area for cheap eats that are tasty. 

It's definitely a little crusty, but its part of the charm, I think.
author: Best M.

description:
The most authentically Mexican street in the city and I still haven't been to an actual taqueria here?  Shame on me.

I'm a follower of the "fight heat with heat" school, and Saturday was yet another warm one, so I went with the camarones diablo and sure enough, the piles of fiery, greasy redness I scooped into the little corn tortillas got me sweating, although the cooling effect is a lot shorter-lived than your burning tongue.  Can't complain quality-wise, but other than that it's a pretty standard, big-bright-&-muraled taqueria.  The separate taco station just inside the front door (a relic of their taco-cart origins, I'm told) is a neat touch, but I didn't try it--tacos are so fragile and ephemeral, you know?

The real question is how this place stacks up to Taqueria SF down the street--more on that later.
author: Wes M.

description: We walked in on a weekday afternoon with high expectations, due to all the positive Yelp reviews. The first thing I noticed was how empty and dirty this place was. The tables were sticky and still had salsa remnants stuck to it. It's not like they were so swamped with customers that one of the workers couldn't give the tables a quick wipe down. I had to grab a stack of napkins to clean off the table before sitting down. My carne asada burrito was big but the flavors were nothing special. The chips were oily and the salsa was watery. My friend had a quesadilla and said it was nothing to write home about. We should have just ordered tacos since that seems to be the fan favorite. Overall, sticky tables and average food. "Meh. I've experienced better", especially in the Mission.
author: Danielle W.

description:
Came here this weekend with some friends who recommended the tacos.  I got 3, al pastor, carne asada and the chicken.  The meat was quite flavorful, the tortillas were well grilled and i loved the self serve onions cilantro and hot sauce.  The pastor was the best out of the three.  I think it was some of the best pastor I've had.  At $1.50 a taco, it was a great deal.  

Overall, Taqueria Vallarta has great tasting, cheap tacos.  These would be perfect a late night meal on the way home after a night out.
author: steve w.

description:
Had the tacos many times, delicious! and the guy making them is super nice, friendly and attentive. 

Delicious tacos, cheap, and again delicious.
author: Geena T.

description: This place calls my name every time I'm in the area.  The food just hits the spot when I'm strollin around in the Mission the the weekend.  It's so simple and the food always tastes fresh.  Those vegetarian tacos and burritos are yum.  It's a slam dunk every time.
author: Angella S.

description:
Some people are probably thinking FIVE STARS.... whats this guy thinking ? Growing up in San Diego, and eating Tacos in Tijuana all my life, I missed the tacos when I moved up here.  Taqueria Vallarta is the closest thing to a TJ Taco in San Francisco that I have found so far.  Its open super late, the tacos are only a buck fifty, and you can dress them in good salsa, cilantro, onions, and lime. You have the choice of street dining, or you can go inside and order from the regular menu.  

Vallarta offers a good choice of meats... Carne Asada, Suadero, Cachete, Cabeza, Sesos... and inside you got your chicken and pork.  While some people think that eating cow brains might sound gross, I LOVE them, and think that carne asada is for rookies.

Taqueria Vallarta is a diamond in the rough, and its the perfect stop when walking back and forth from bar to bar in the mission.

DRINK ON SUCKAS!
author: Bone D.

description: Going again and again for the street food style taco cart!
author: Sans S.

description:
This is the consistently best Taqueria in SF.  Yeah I know we all like El Farolito, but they screw up all the time and serve gross, cold, mushy bean things instead of burritos.

Vallarata is always good, always hot and always served with a smile.  I love the Burrito Grill as a new veggie twist on the classic burrito with fire roasted squash, carrots and zucchini.  They also have a taco bar that my boyfriend freaks out for every time we go.  Yum yum yum
author: Dana M.

description:
there's a taco tent  just inside the shop exclusively for tacos. everything else you go inside.i.e burritos, torta, drinks, etc.

this taco stand has all the sauces, limes, radishes, onions  in front of it. so you help yourself to what  you want. my al pastor tacos (1.50) seem kind of smallish, portion wise. the meat was tender but i didn't taste any meat taste. it was smothered by the sauce. guess i'll have to try other items to test the quality of the food.
author: Victor G.

description:
I have had to wait a couple weeks to write this review.  I ate here 2 weeks ago.  I wasn't that hungry and was about to go to a party close by but I am a sucker for carnitas.  So, I opted for the carnitas quesadilla.  It was cheap and quick and REALLY greasy.  My stomach felt a bit of dis-ease right after I finished eating it.

At the party I nursed a beer for what seemed to be hours.  Still not feeling hot, we hoofed it to the 24th Street BART station.  The crisp night air felt refreshing on my face.  As soon as we descended into the BART station things took a turn for the worse.  The smell, sight of a woman eating a large sandwich, and extremely long 11 minute wait for our train resulted in my loosing the entire contents of my stomach in the BART station just as our train pulled up.

I spent the entire ride pleading with my head and stomach not to wretch again on the packed Friday night train.  I barely made it to Lake Merritt.  I lost it again on the short car ride home, in a bag this time.  I spent my entire Saturday in bed and on the couch with a fever of over 100 degrees.  My health slowly returned to normal over the next week.

NEVER again Vallarta, NEVER again!
author: Tracy A.

description:
this place is a little more than a shack.   except the taqueria maestros here dish up insanely tasty examples of the type. 

lean, mean, down to business.
author: Tyler C.

description: If its a late night coming out the club or bar... great place to end up is this place 24th street in the mission ....might have a big line but it moves quick ....Food is great cafeteria seating style sit where you may the TACOS are off the hook carne asada suadero, buche, tripitas, lengua, cabeza....they got it all....Burritos whatever mexican food you want....F*CK JACK in the CRACK go here.
author: Gerry G.

description:
UPDATE (6/12/07): I'm a bit late on this but it's back. I think it's the same folks although the sign hung out front says it'll be a different name. What really matters is the taco stand is back. They keep it inside (which is noticably cleaner) now but they're still greasy and a delicious late night snack. Hopefully, the health inspector stays away (or they keep it clean-ish)

It's a bit dirty, a little rough around the edges, most likely unsanitary and damn good. One not need go beyond the sidewalk here. The tacos are what you're there for.  Simple meat on tortillas and choose your condiments: 3 types of salsa, lime, cilantro and raw onion. They'll even throw in some hunks of "grilled" onion if you want. You may not feel good about yourself in the morning but that's probably from the hangover.
author: Sig N.

description:
Me loves me some Taqueria Vallarta.  Me loves pretty much everything about Taqueria Vallarta.  They've got everything a great taqueria needs.  Guaraches?  YES!  Only them and the place that sells fried cow eyes have guaraches!  That deep fried American invention, the Chimichanga?  YES!!  I don't care if it ain't authentic, nothing says lovin' like a DEEP FRIED BURRITO, okay?  And that wierd green peppery salsa they have in the big stone salsa vat-thing. THE BEST, oh man that salsa is SOOOO GOOOD.  Open until 3am?  YES!!  Shit, i could go get one of them guaraches and that good salsa RIGHT NOW!
