Giant TV's tuned to mexican wrestling/soccer/soap operas?  OF COURSE!  I even love their sign.  It's actually one of my favorite things in San Francisco.  It looks something like this:

T V
A A
Q L
U L
E A
R R
IA TA

Why they couldn't/didn't get that 8th panel to spell out the name fully, we'll never know.  But it's so charming and I guess just totally not planned out, but it's this huge vertically pannelled sign with each letter on it's own panel... how could they not plan it out?!?  Just don't even walk by at like 3:30 when they have the trap door to the basement open and they're cleaning out the floor mats, etc.  Trust me, just don't.  And whatever you do, DO NOT look down into that basement where they presumably store the food, or smell any of the air.  Nope, not unless you want to develop a big repressed memory in order to keep eating there.  Which, of course, I've done, because I love Taqueria Vallarta!

UPDATE:  They are, like, closed down... Major Bummer.
author: Ben V.

description:
Taqueria Vallarta
 

Cheapassfood is in San Francisco and on a mission to eat the most Mexican food in the Misson, my first stop is Taqueria Vallarta. I love this place when I am stumbling out of Phone Both (bar) or Pop's (local dive/biker bar), Taqerica Vallarta is always there to comfort me with some smoking hot tacos for cheap. All tacos are $1.50, and options are el pastor, beef, chorizo, chicken and carnitas, sorry my vegan & veggies friends nothing for ya. Not that you would want your veggies mingling with the badass greasy grilled meats. 
Open till the wee hours, the donut-shaped grill is always dependable when I come out of last call at 2 am, I know SF lacks the nightlife, but at least they have amazing Taqueria. 
So this time around I am not drunk, but am very hungry and can't wait eats me some tacos, went for the carnitas and el pastor, comes with a side of greasy sweet and slightly card caramelized onions. These little gems are to die for they are cooked with the oils from the meats. All tacos are made to order, the barboca dude dips about a third the corn tortillas in oil, and then toasts them on the giant donut pan. The tortilla come out hot, toasty and very supple in the meantime, the meats simmering around the edge of the pan juices, making them brilliantly fatty and savory. Once the little tacos were handed to me I had the option to pile on fresh onion, cilantro, and salsa.   
What more could I ask for I was in heaven, noting beats a $1.50 tacos that fills my belly to rim, it is nice to be back The Foggy City for a little bit of RR.
author: nyc c.

description: This is my go to taqueria. I live right around the corner and eat there at least once a week. They have great food at great prices. Plus they have esquites.
author: B A.

description:
This place is right out of a Wes Anderson movie.  I've so many mixed feelings about Taqueria Vallarta.  Most of them are positive.  Kind of like the feelings one harbors about a retarded puppy.

The first thing I noticed when walking in, besides the line around the corner during the evenings, was that pigeons were expediently cleaning anything that fell on the floor.  They were being polite and human-like!  I'm not sure how I feel about a place that is comfortable with the perpetual and ominous presence of pigeons within the establishment.  Its actually kind of awesome.  My friends and I affectionately call this place "The Pigeon Palace" as a result.

Next up, the food and pricing are ridiculous.  Great food.  $1.50 tacos.  I mean, c'mon.  A man who will make little to no eye contact with you will season and prepare tacos for you all night for less than what you can purchase at fast food joints.  I tried the carne asada, carnitas, beef tips, and my favorite - el pollo asado, and it was all amazing.  Greasy, sure.  But awesome.  There's a giant menu in the back of the store with all kinds of stuff and a soup lady, but why even bother?  The tacos are amazing enough.  Still, a filling meal requires about 3-4 tacos.  When you do the math it works out, but grease-per-value-per-inch you can probably eat better at Metate or Farolito.  

Pro tip:  Ask for a Mexican Coca Cola with your meal.  They bottle it without High Fructose Corn Syrup -- it tastes completely different.  Drink it under the virgin mary statue in the center of the restaurant then lean back and stuff your face while reading the wall-to-ceiling murals about the history of San Francisco as it pertains to the Mexican people.
author: niero g.

description:
This place gets the 5th star simply because it is the BEST TAQUERIA that I have found in SF. 

My review is only for the taco stand in the front of the restaurant.

GOOD:
- Cheap! $1.50 per taco. 
- Plenty of toppings (cilantro, radish, salsas, lime) to add on like any other respectable taqueria. There is a guacamole-like sauce in the back past the register.
- Very authentic and plenty of meats to choose from (lots of Mexican families eat tacos here so that is a good sign).
- My favs are the buche (pork stomach) and the al pastor but everything is pretty good (even the cabeza). The meats are full of flavor here.

BAD:
- Like most taquerias, this place is a divey hole in the wall so don't take your first date here unless she is totally chill with the zero ambiance.
- The taco stand can get overrun sometimes so sometimes there is a good 15-20 minute wait.
- Parking can be a pain in the butt around here after 6PM but there are plenty of metered spots during the day.
- The tacos are super greasy because they grill the meats in their own juices. Many other places just stew/boil their meats, which is less greasy but also less flavorful. A small price to pay for the best tacos around.
- No fish taco option (not that I remember anyway).

CONCLUSION: One of the best taquerias in SF, and the best one I have found thus far. Their tacos are cheaper more authentic, and more flavorful than most other places in the Mission.
author: Alex P.

description:
5 stars for hospitality - they served the 17 people in my class (all on one check) from USF with hardly a hint of tension in their smiles. 

Awesome place to get a burrito after checking out the sweet murals on Balmy Alley right next door. I got the carnitas super burrito (avocado, beans, rice, salsa, lettuce) and it was shockingly great. The pork was a little bit fatty for my taste but it was $5.40, huge, and tasted amazing. It's a quirky place, with murals covering the walls and ceiling, some old arcade games pushed into the corner gathering dust, one of those clawing for little fuzzy animal games, an internet juke box, and a little taco cart that I hear gets pushed outside late at night to serve outdoors. All around, this place was great, and definitely didn't skimp on anything. It had a lot of character and the employees were very friendly and gracious. New mission favorite!
author: Ali W.

description:
Although Taqueria Vallarta is open until 1am, I was inclined to visit this place when there was daylight still outside.  There is a taco bar by the entrance, but since there was a line I opted for the burrito counter in back.  They also sell something else at the other entrance (aka the "walk-by window"), but I didn't stop to ask.

Food:  4 stars.  I went for the super burrito al pastor (marinated pork), which comes with avocado, cheese, hot salsa (mild is not an option), and onions.  It's not as large as other super burritos I've seen, but the right size for all you body-conscious people out there.  The flavors were good, but I wish the avocado and cheese were more evenly distributed throughout the whole burrito.  Came here on another visit to try the taco bar.  At $1.50 a taco, it's a pretty good deal.  It's essentially your choice of meat on two corn tortillas with a couple of grilled onions on the side.  You can also add your own amount of cilantro, diced onions, and salsa.  I also tried an horchata and loved it.

Service:  3 stars.  I stood at the counter for about five minutes before someone came over to take my order.  At least they were quick with the food preparation and tolerated my valiant but sad attempt to order in Spanish.  

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  The place if full of beautiful murals and sketchy people - come here in the daytime.  The murals are of San Francisco landmarks, including the Pyramid, the two bridges, Alcatraz and Lombard Street.  There are also murals of 49ers playing in the ocean (???).  

Hits:   Marinated pork, carne asada taco, cheap prices.

Misses:  Not a place for people who enjoy large portions.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  El Farolito, La Taqueria.
author: Keith C.

description: If you're in the Mission you can't get more authentico than Taqueria Vallarta. They have two locations as far as I know but the taco bar is the same. "Al Vapor" which apparently means "really good" in Espanol. Just pick your meat (from carne asada, lengua, cabeza, pollo, carnitas, pastor, etc...) and the taco guy or gal will do the rest. It's amazing! Ask for "cebollas" (grilled onions). They're dripping in meat juice and super tasty. I can't say enough. Excellent.
author: Glen T.

description:
took me years to figure out the real name to this place. 

I just called it  Meat Wheel.

Hands down my favorite place to get tacos in SF.
author: Morgan H.

description:
I like the vibe of this place - "roots." Separate lively taco stand portion put what you want on 'em as soon as you walk in and main burritos/dinners/platos register cash portion further on.

Veg. & poyo burrito good, -huge-, if a tad salty. Fresh squeezed who go de naranja. No guac on burrito as requested but avocado brought in little salsa cup. 

Amateur but colorful art on walls (and ceiling, where rather than the predictable hey seuss and maria you can glimpse some of the story of of central america including the fact of Spanish catholic fascists destroying the indigenous. Hooray for the surprising, seemingly heretical exhibition of the tragic truth.

Would like to return and try their fish plate.

YES they serve burritos here.
author: Mark G.

description: if tacos are what you want, this is the place you go to...they open late or should I say they close late...lol...too bad they don't have coronas...hmmm....:)
author: Malou C.

description:
Omgod, I love your tacos.  YUM YUM YUM! Plain with stuff you can put on yourself, I love it!!!

And for some reason, every time I come here, I'm able to find parking easily.  Thank goodness, must mean that we're meant to be. Haha.
author: Tina L.

description:
When it comes to late night eats, I don't think there's a better choice than this.

If you're looking for a "super" taco with cheese, guacamole and sour cream, this aint the place. That's why the tacos are only $1.50, basic but good. Make sure your Spanish game is on point because that's the only way to order. Scoop a heaping of chipotle and onions on each and you're good to go. These are some of the juiciest tacos I've ever had.
author: O'Shea J.

description:
3 stars for the food, 2 stars for the murals depicting the history of Spanish and later Mexican SF!  History majors love that kinda stuff!

I feel like that's the only reason I come here, but it's not.  Last time I got tacos and they were good and cheap.  I probably won't get a burrito again only because I don't remember how it was last time, thus making it forgettable.  Then again, maybe the murals distracted me too much.
author: T. O.

description:
Tacos, tacos, tacos! Hot off the donut-shaped grill! 

If it wasn't clear, I recommend you try the tacos. At least three to be objective. A squeeze of lime, some salsa and you're there. Also delicious, the tamales they sometimes sell to the left of the grill. Even more delicious, the ginormous cobs of corn they serve with chile and salt. If you're thirsty grab a splash of beer or a glass bottle of coke.

Once, a friend and I were walking up 24th St., having just left a vegan BBQ. She gasped as she saw the impressive Vallarta grill out on the sidewalk across the street. "What?", I asked her. "Do you want to get some tacos to counteract all the tofu we just ate?", said she. Let's face it, a bit of a crush.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
After an evening out in the Mission getting our drank on one Saturday night, J and I found ourselves rather tired and hungry for some tacos.  Trying to get out of the area before the mad rush of hungry drunks, we hurriedly hailed a cab and got dropped off right before the Taqueria Vallarta.  

The restaurant features an interesting set up where it's like a taco truck, but you know, without the truck.  There's a guy behind a plastic sneeze guard manning a grill, which features a full view of a bunch of different meats and tortillas cooking away.  I ultimately decided on one carne asada and one lengua taco.  While the asada was alright, the lengua was fantastic.  Tender, succulent, and plentiful, the lengua was probably the best I've had yet.  So if you're into that kind of stuff, DO indulge.  And at 1.50 a taco, talk about a deal.  

Another honorable mention goes to the selection of beverages.  The horchata was on point, not gritty or too sweet.  Also, it was served to me in a red plastic Solo cup, which allowed me to keep the party going.  J got an apple soda in a glass bottle, and that was extra fizzy and  delightfully refreshing.

I finished off my two tacos quickly and swiftly, and was already pretty full.  Yet, I longed for another lengua anyway.  Being the awesome friend that she is, J encouraged me to have another and eventually got up to get one for me.  I disappointed myself by not being able to finish the whole thing, leaving a single bite left, but I still made Mama J proud.  She won't touch that shit even though she's a brown sister herself.
author: Karen T.

description:
I'm down with this place and this place is down with me.  I really like coming here.  I don't know why exactly but I always feel very welcome here.  

I like the stand right in side the door.  It's like, I'm so hungry I don't even have time to walk to the back of the room, I need food the second I get inside.  

I also like getting a super burrito and then eating it there, or walking down the street to Sugarlump or L's to dine.
author: Levi B.

description:
Never allow me to say that I dislike Mexican food again. It was indeed the case before, but never again...at least not at Taqueria Vallarta!

So far removed from the chain restaurant Mexican that I grew up eating (and hating), the tacos here are flavorful, fresh, and memorable. And this is before you even get to the salsa, which are good enough to pack up and bring home for later. $1.50 per taco makes a very happy wallet. For the price of my morning coffee, I could enjoy an entire meal here.

The burritos are superb as well...and this is coming from someone who doesn't really like massive amounts of rice or cheese. One of my biggest complaints about burritos previously was that they cannot be eaten the next day since the tortilla turns rock hard. But again, most of my burrito-eating experiences came from places called Moe's or Willy's, chains that did not an ounce of justice to their fellow amigos. The texture of the burritos here is just right, and yes, they are still good for reheating later (just be sure to remove the aluminum foil before microwaving).

In terms of decor, I like the wall murals quite a lot--especially since it tells a meaningful story. For a place to have their entire set of walls and ceilings painted this way, it shows that they put some serious thought into this. Also well-lit and spacious, which removes some level of suspicion about restaurants who turn down the light to mask the grime. I'm not saying it's completely pest-free. I'm just saying it makes me wonder a bit less.

I can't take a Mexico vacation on a whim, but I can get a taste of it at 24th and Treat any day of the week. Now that's a trip I can afford to take time off for.
author: Rona J.

description: I usually get the tacos or the posole here, and it's always amazing! By far one of my favorite places for Mexican food in the Mission.
author: Julia W.

description: Tacos.  Seriously fantastic.  Al pastor, carnitas, cabeza, every taco is $1.50.  It's calming to know you're experiencing the heart of Mexico in the comfort of our very own country.  A tall glass of pineapple agua fresca (light, refreshing, not too sweet) to wash down the juicy chunks of dripping meat.  Slurping sounds required. :)
author: Tracy L.

description:
Stopped by here during Sunday Streets on July 19 and this place was packed.  I have to take a star off because the place was full of flies and the all of the tables were dirty.

Nachos with Chicken
The nachos were very good.  They were loaded with moist chunks of chicken, salsa, avocado, sour cream, and cheese.  Tasty, just get it to go.
author: Rob L.

description: One word, two syllables: Dee-lish! Mmm, mmm goodness is all this place is. From their burritos to their quesadillas to their buck fifty tacos- made to order from a little lady with big tongs once you enter this colorful and vibrant place. I mean, it doesn't get any better then those tacos with various meats to choose from and the salsa toppings (ask for grilled onions to add extra umph! to your tacos). This is a must see, must try place that I highly recommend for those of you who like good cheap eats. It's a little on the dirty gritty side (even better!) and a bit better than a taco truck because there are seats for you so you can at least take a break after your 50th taco. My appetite is insatiable whenever I go there.
author: Laurel P.

description: Best taco's in SF. If you want a burrito go to la taqueria, but Vallarta has the most perfect meats and no frills tortillas and sauces.
author: Matt M.

description:
Taqueria Vallarta is one of the best, if not the best, in the Mission. Some of you might remember years ago when it was El Castillito (not to be confused with the one in the Castro).

The burritos rock. The tacos rock.  The barbacoa cart is the best stumbling drunk food outside of Farolito.

My only complaint: the avocado salsa is watery compared with Cancun and some others in the hood.
author: Erica W.

description: I used to miss good and affordable Mexican food until B took me to Vallarta. At $1.50 a taco, that is all I ever get. I used to be afraid that the tacos were only delicious because I was drunk, but these tacos are just as bomb sober. It's the perfect place to grab a bite after some late night revelry in the city. Ka-pow.
author: Julia C.

description:
Late night burritos... some of the best I've had in my 12 years living in the Mission.

If you are looking for ambience or a place with no flies, then you shouldn't be going to a taqueria deep in the Mission to begin with.  The food and prices are amazing, which is the reason these places exist.

The burritos are a stronger pick than the tacos.
author: Drew P.

description: I come here for the super-cheap tacos. (Who doesn't?) In addition to the usual suspects like carne asada and al pastor, they have tripe, head (cabeza), and tongue (lengua). The cabeza and lengua can be a little fatty, but the flavor is good so give them a try. I don't think I've ever had a taco here I didn't like. It isn't vegetarian friendly, however. The horchata is decent, but I've had better. Enjoy the murals.
author: Diana O.

description:
Un taco de suadero + un de buche + un de al pastor + un tamal de rajas + una Coca mexicana en botella = desayuno de los campeones!

Happy Cinco! Be safe!
author: Nathan W.

description:
This place is a bit off the beaten path of Mission street, but it's not the destination, it's the journey.

Rolling with the crew you get to check out the scenery, have some thrilling conversation, and when you get there it isn't ask packed as El Faro. Now this does not determine the prowess of Vallarta as this place is authentic in both decor and taste. A bonus is the taco station at the front door. Their protein is flavorful, large quantities, and El Faro Prices

A new spot to hit up if you want a change from the usual spots.
author: Po L.

description: For the bargain basement price, this place is bomb. I had 3 DELICIOUS tacos with 3 DELICIOUS salsas: $1.50 a taco. My favorite taco was the barbacoa. This place is located in the "real" non-hipster Mission. Balmy Street, which is mural Heaven, is right next door.
author: Andrew K.

description:
It is with a heavy heart that I type these words. My review of Taqueria Vallarta would be effusive about the deliciousness of the burritos and the salsas, and my deep appreciation of the taco stand which reminds me of LA in a good way. That's why what I'm about to say only demotes them to 2 stars and not 1.

However, alas, I must report that I can't eat there any more. I've had repeated bad experiences with sanitation at Vallarta that only leave me wondering what further horrors of hygiene I'm not witnessing. One time I saw a rat. Another time I saw an employee sneeze into her hand and resume handling my food. Most recently, I saw an employee put cuts of raw beef with his bare hands on the same counter they use to assemble the burritos, and then move to continue cooking without cleaning the counter or his hands.

There are other taquerias that are just as good and cheap and down home, and don't make me feel like I'm risking exposure to ebola every time I eat there.
author: Nato G.

description: The best tacos in the mission. Also the cheapest! If you're in the mission stop by here and get the tripitas tacos and carnitas. I also highly recommend the tamales and the corn in the cup from the lady on the otherwise of the restaurant. It's cash only with her but I'm sure shell cut you some slack and run it through with your ATM at the other end of the restaurant
author: Slo C.

description: Authentic tacos for $2. Can't be beat. Holds me over until our next trip to Puerto Vallarta, which will be years out now that I'm getting my fix here.
author: F S.

description: This is a night for the history book of my life in SF. Seriously. I have only loved one Mexican food place in the Mission (El Tonayense, just a few blocks up on 24th) and they were closed tonight. I am a vegetarian/pescetarian so a restaurant's ability to make a vegetarian burrito taste interesting, is quite a task. Until last night El Tonayense was the only place that could do it for me. Starving, in search of food, I drove down 24th and have now found a rival, in fact perhaps a replacement for my favorite....I ordered the grilled vegetable super burrito with shrimp and almost started crying when I took the first bite. Literally. I knew that I would have an alternative when my other place was closed, in fact I realized I would probably alternate between my two favorite places from now on.
author: Marisa T.

description:
Five star rating just for the tacos.  These are authentic Mexico style tacos cooked off a hot plate.  Many different kinds of meat, some exotic, all very well seasoned.  They dip the tortilla in the fat and toast it on the plate.  Then they top it off with meat of choice and garnish yourself with onion, cilantro, and hot sauces.  That's all you want to truly taste the meats.  

Very few places have suedera, barbacoa, tripa, etc.  Great stuff.  

I've never ordered anything from the kitchen I so have no idea what there food is like.  Five star rating definitely does not take into account ambiance.
author: Johnny W.

description: Came here because of my Groupon. Yah the tacos where cheap but not necessarily the best I've had. We also ordered the nachos and the lettuce looked old and didn't taste so great. Glad I only bought one groupon. Will not be coming back here.
author: arleen r.

description:
A decent veggie burrito.  Great salsa verde.  Chips are the perfect thickness and have just the right amount of grease.

Doesn't break the top five, but it's probably somewhere in the heights of my top ten taquerias in the Mission.

An extra star for the dining room mural that features the 49ers throwing passes in the ocean below the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Megan D.

description: By far the best place to chow down on some amazing tacos at a great price. My favorite tacos to get here are the al pastor and the cabesa tacos.  Yes I said brains, don't knock it til you try it. ;) Along with some grilled onions, radish, cilantro, lime and salsa verde and you got yourself some great post drinking delights! And gotta complete the meal without a tamarind soda. Can never get enough of this place.
author: Yvonne T.

description:
I'm updating this to 5 stars because out of all the burrito/taco joints I've been to in the mission that I regular..

(farolito, papalote, metate, cancun, tonyanese, guadalaraja) 

Taqueria Vallarta is my number 1 (make it so).  Their lengua, suadero, and al pastor meats are amazing.  I never find myself ordering carne asada anymore.

Excellent salsas, and their 1.50 taco stand is phenomenal.

Also note: they have homemade tamales by the second entrance.
author: Adam C.

description:
Yes, La Taqueria is excellent and yes you can't throw a cigarette butt in the Mission without hitting a decent taco spot-- but after a year living in this neighborhood, my best Mexican taco experiences have been here at Taqueria Vallarta. 

I've only had the barbacoa tacos, and it's hard to imagine ordering anything else. They are fantastic: full-flavored, fresh, and affordable ($1.50). They dip about a third of the corn tortillas in oil, and then toast them on the giant barbacoa pan. The result is an piping hot tortilla. Meanwhile, the meats simmering around the edge of the pan --carnitas, beef, chicken, and chorizo-- are soaking in their own (and probably each others) juices, making them wonderfully oily and flavorful. Sweet roasted onions are also provided along with each taco. The server will combine these ingredients for you on a plate. On top of this tremendous combination you get to pile on fresh onion, cilantro, and salsa to your heart's content.... Fantastic. Don't forget the radish to clear your pallette, or just for something to crunch on.

As already mentioned, this place is open pretty late, so bring your friends on the weekend during a night out. It makes an impression, but not on the wallet. 

And yes, the sign is awesome. I took a photo of it.
author: Jordan B.

description:
It was 8 p.m. on a Sunday evening. I was in a car with some friends, cruising down 24th street trying to pick up a fine piece of...but, wait. What is this line for?

I yell to the driver (OK, my friend), stop the car. I see a line. I must know why people are on it.

Out of the car I go, finding the guy with beautiful silver teeth and so i asked, Whatcha doing?

Tacos, he said, with the biggest taco-eating grin I've ever seen.

Tacos, I said. And got back into the car.

A few days later, I ventured down to 24th street, trying to remember where I had been on Sunday. As soon as I hit Taqueria Vallarta, with the stall in the street showing off various chopped meats, I stopped, ordered tongue tacos and stood leaning against a parking meter chomping happily away.

I like the ambience (parking meters have held me up on many a night), but can't really give it tons of stars for that. Plus, hard to communicate depending on who is on the grill if you don't know the Spanish words for some of the meats. 

Still, this is the only place I go for tacos.
author: Brer R.

description:
I consider myself somewhat of a burrito/taco connoisseur. When I moved to 25th and Harrison a year and a half ago, I did the requisite pilgrimage up and down 24th street to find the ultimate burrito. Vallarta was my dream come true.

Don't mess around with veggie or chicken at this place (admittedly not their strong suit). It's all about al pastor. As has been said, the outside stand was regularly open until 3:30: the perfect end to a drunken stumble home. Unless there's a Tonayense truck in front of your house, I believe that having Vallarta a block and a half away is the best possible living situation you could hope to find yourself in (taco-wise that is).

Probably my favorite memory of Vallarta was watching the Mexico World Cup game when they played Argentina. The place was packed with everyone from bums to urban pioneering yuppies to the latino regulars to self conscious hipsters, all drinking beer and enjoying the game together. Tell me that that would ever happen at Cancun, and I'll agree that it's the best taqueria in the city. The experience was emblematic of why I like living in this neighborhood. Despite the ebb and flow of gentrification, the occasional flares of gang violence, and other problems that make the place unlivable for certain segments of the population, this is a remarkably integrated area, definitely compared to the rest of the nation, but even by San Francisco standards.

Unfortunately Vallarta has been closed for months due to public health code violations:( A quick search online brought up the list of violations, which were extensive. In the time since they closed, 24th street has opened a new set of lofts, 3 (yes 3!) new coffee shops, and a Vallarta look-a-like in the former location of Mr. Pizza Man (24th and Folsom). This new place serves a good taco, had very friendly staff, and some nice murals, but I couldn't help but feel that this is what Vallarta would be if it were in Disneyland.

I think that the rats at Taqueria Vallarta #3 were the only thing keeping gentrification at bay here. There goes the neighborhood...
author: eliah g.

description:
this place should be the #1 cheap eats place in San Francisco.
Granted, I did need my mexican buddy (yes, I also have a gay, asian and black friend as well - not one person) to help me understand the various animal parts which fill up the corn tortillas frying up in a nice pool of butter.

I still can't recite the meat options but I recall that the suadero (sp?) was a personal favorite.  They are all good so you win any way you go.

Give this place a shot; in addition to the taco stand there is a burrito/quesadilla joint in the back but my recommendation would be to stick with the tacos.
author: Joshua J.

description:
i stumbled in here one day when farolito was lookin' dicey and I wanted to try something new. You can't go wrong if there's a crowd around the taco cart outside, right?

So I went inside and ordered up. The staff talks real fast, so make sure you check your order before it goes to the kitchen in the back. I speak a little spanish so I was able to discuss the finer points of my husband's dietary concerns with the staff, and they were willing to help out.

Yes it's kinda seedy inside, but when you're feenin' for some good stuff, be sure to stop in and line up at the taco cart for the goods or go inside for full plates. You'll be surrounded by locals, so expect a tourist-free environment!
author: Charlene L.

description:
I'm giving this place 4 stars because of the service, atmosphere and the prices. 

I came in with a class of 17 and the servers were very patient and courteous with us. Considering how large our group was, they were able to serve us our food rather promptly. I didn't have to wait more than 5 minutes for my burrito.

The atmosphere was awesome--just what I was looking for in the Mission. It was bright, colorful and had awesome murals depicting the history of California.

The prices were unbeatable. I had a humongous shrimp burrito for less than $6. I think you can even get tacos for $1.50. Great cheap food.

The only thing that made me a little uncomfortable was this drunken old man who kept wandering over to our table and incoherently kept trying to make conversation. I think he's a local/regular because the staff seemed to know him. He wasn't violent or outwardly hostile, but he got up too close in the faces of some of the girls I was with. I know this wasn't the restaurant's fault. They tried to usher him out, but he just kept coming back in.

Other than that though, I would definitely recommend this place for some good cheap eats.
author: Teresa G.

description: Not the cleanest place, but the food is good.  One of the few spots in the Mission I know of that has suadero regularly.
author: Aalok P.

description:
My mouth is watering just thinking about this place.

I swear that this place just rocks so hard if it was a band it would be Led Zeppelin in the early 1970s. It would wear tight jeans, have long hair, make love to many women and snort cocaine by the truckload.

Of course it's just a restaurant. Still, it's durned good. 

Walking up to the cart parked in front of the restaurant and ordering a few tacos is one of the pleasures of San Francisco. It always brings a large smile to my face. Plus, it's so cheap. You can't beat that.

It's little off the beaten path in regards to the Mission, but worth looking for.
author: Mark G.

description: Fantastic burrito, prob the best I've had in SF since i've been here.  Originally came for the tacos, but completely missed the taco cart at the entrance.
author: Phil J.

description: I literally CRAVE their al pastor tacos. the cheapest and one of the best dinners in the city. just add a glass of horchata and you're set.
author: Megha A.

description: I would've never looked twice at this place but we decided to check it out and absolutely LOVED it!! The little TACOS are sooo freakin good!! YUMMY!!! Not to mention, I love how the inside has plenty of tables and lots of open space...  Its defnitely a SF vibe in here with all the variety of people!! Love it!!!
author: Michelle G.

description:
Delicious beyond the "I'm drunk so anything I eat, especially greasy Mexican food, is delicious." $1.50 tacos made by a very friendly man at the front and $1.50 tamales handed out by a less friendly woman in the adjoining room. Both lip smackingly good regardless. All for $4.50? Reee-diculously cheap, even for the Mission. 

Bonus points for the mural on the wall for being so inconceivable (49ers playing in the Bay, and by playing in the Bay i mean literally tossing a football underneath the Golden Gate Bridge) and riddled with language so grammatically incorrect I just have to assume it was painted by someone who's first language was not English. Go read it for yourself and see what I mean. Not that there's anything wrong with that, its a good read as your devouring your meal.
author: sholeh m.

description:
I've don't write things frequently on Yelp for a few reasons.  1.  What I have to say is usually already said, and in more detail by others who write extensively on this site.  2.  I can't say it as cleverly as those people.  But most importantly, 3.  I don't want to tell people where I like to go because then it gets infiltrated.  

But, I do have to share this, because it took me a while to decide which is my favorite taco place in my hood, and it's Cinco de Mayo.  Vallarta wins!  I love their steak and I'm usually a chicken person (the chicken's great, too).  I think it's so flavorful because they cook all the meats next to each other on a circular grill (like cheek, brain, etc) and they grill the onions.  They also have fantastic salsas.  They are cheap too, $1.50. 

The only annoying thing is you don't pay at the taco stand, you have to pay the other person behind the counter, which is a bit weird but oh well at least only one person is handling dirty money.
author: Ann C.

description:
These are tacos I dream about. The secret is the casuela. The translucent onions in the center flavoring the meats on the edges-- its really the comingling of the onions and the meats that lend superb juiciness and flavor to the taco. This is a taco's taco. Just meat & onions. It's all a good taco needs.

Sometimes they sell corn on the cob and tamales in the front. Look for the huge silver stock pot. Get the corn on the cob with everything on it- a coating of mayonnaise, dusting of cheese, chili powder and lime. Mmm.
author: Sita B.

description: If you're craving for Mexican food, this is the place to go to. Their tacos are bomb. Their super shrimp burrito is also delicious as well. And for drinks, get the Horchata . The only downside to this place is the cashier. She gives customers attitude for no reason. So be prepared .
author: Jewels Y.

description: My friend and I were strolling the street and decided to come here for a quick snack... and boy, are we lucky we came here! The workers are very nice and the tacos are so good! I had the cabeza, which was very tender, and my friend had the carne asada, which was a flavor blast in your mouth. Not even the salty kind of flavor blast; it was just pure amazing on the taste buds! Would definitely go there again.
author: Hannah L.

description:
before you reach the door you can already smell the aroma of sizzling meat and spices as you peek in and find a short little man cooking your next taco. just like the streets of mexico the carne asada or whatever other kind of meat you want is cooked fresh right there. most people wait in line for the tacos but i chose a carne asada super burrito and it was one huge brick of goodness in my tummy. the meat was seasoned perfectly and it was so very tasty. 

though san francisco has tons of great mexican eats, this has got  to be one of the tops. the cheesy murals on the wall let you know that you are in an authentic mexican spot. they even have some huge shady looking pots cooking whatever-it-is almost right outside their doors and some corn sitting in a tub of water for who-knows-what. grimy and awesome.
author: Regina C.

description: Groupon got me to go in here. Food is good and fresh. I loved the shrimp quesadilla and the shrimp salad. Plenty of salsa choices. However, the counter staff was not friendly - even though we went three days in a row. I think she was annoyed that we were using coupons, but hard to tell. There are so many wonderful taqueria's in the Bay Area that, even though we loved the food, the poor service means we won't be back.
author: jessica M.

description:
3 1/2 stars ... sober and hungry as hell both times I've been here.

I've been to Mexico and Hell-A a many of times to witness the truth of their tacos. The taco stand and free standing condiments are inviting to anyone walking by. Had the carne, pastor, and chorizo so far. I love good food that's bad for you as much as the next cat but this is a bit greasy. The oil forms some type of force field preventing my saliva enzymes to break down the food and fully tasting the goodness. Otherwise it's a good and cheap fix.



.
author: Steve H.

description: $1.50 tacos you say... and I don't have to drive to Mexico?!?!? I came here last night on a walk though the Mission after Angelo F. had insisted I try these delictable tacos.  I had 2 Carne Asada, which yes were very oily, but come on it's practically street meat, that's how I stay healthy and keep my stomach resistant to all negative vibes ;)  Check it out for sure, and try to speak in Spanish only, they appreciated even my broken sentences!
author: Megan L.

description:
Yes, yes, and more yes!  This is what I think of when I think tacos!

Usually the front is left wide open so the whole place feels like an open air experience...and by experience I mean awesome tacos for next to nothing in an authentic taqueria.

I love going here after a long night drinking - ha ha...long night...last call is at 1:30...what's wrong with you California?

WARNING I went here after a drinking way too much - how much did I drink? - I didn't remember going here till the next morning when I vomited chorizo.  No fault to Taqueria Vallarta, none.  The vomiting was all me and induced by shots, beer, and champagne.  I'm just saying, spicy chorizo is a hell of  awake up call when you don't remember consuming it.  I will say this, I was impressed with how spicy and flavorful it was on the way up.
author: Ryan G.

description: Good, cheap, and authentic. If you're up for it, get the lengua tacos. How can you pass up the meat that tastes you back?
author: Paolo M.

description: Ahhh!! I lOVE THIS SPOT! Best Tacos In the Mission District. Its like im back at abelitas casa eating the great tacos. Place is great everyone is welcome even the pigeons lmao Totally recommend this spot U will not be disappointed! Friendly people, open late, variety of meats and drinks as well Oh and price friendly $1.50 per taco, sound affordable? i think yes. like i said totally recommend this spot!
author: Luis M.

description: I come here two ways: I come first  to get the carry out tacos, the carne asada is to die for. Er, I mean they are really really good. I am not dying for anything in exchange for a taco. I mean, really. The shrimp burrito is another carry out item I go for about once a month. I come second to sit down and eat in so to speak. I just  think they are keeping it real here. No added fluff, just what you order.
author: Gwen H.

description: Taqueria Vallarta, your tacos and salsas are pretty awesome, but no free chips?  C'mon now.
author: J. V.

description:
We just played an outdoor gig for Winter Solstice over in Oakland last night (yeah, it was cold as Jack Frost's nut sack over dry ice) and we were dying for some tacos.  We drove by to the corner of International & High St only to find a mega-line brewing.  We didn't have any patience and we really didn't want to be waiting in that beautiful neighborhood for more than 30 seconds, so we decided to head home to the city and get some grub over there.  

After fighting over what which late night spot to hit up, we all decided on Taqueria Vallarta.  Thankfully it was still open at 1:50am.  

My burrito was good...pretty damn good I will say.  There is something about their green sauce that sets this burrito apart from every other taqueria in the Mission.  My only complaint was there were bits and pieces of severely overcooked steak in my burrito that I mistook for undercooked rice, hence the 2 star deduction.  I will definitely come back though.  I think those burned meat particles in my burrito were just a fluke, or at least I hope so.
author: Larry A.

description: Great tacos, a little rundown, and hilariously bad murals.  Did I mention the great chorizo tacos?
author: John L.

description:
it took me a while to remember the name to this place. i've been here so many times but i'm always too fucked up to ever remember where i end up....

i've had many early mornings here with a what little cash i have left of a night of debauchery. some nights i'll get tacos with whatever meat is available and everything on it. if it's a date night, i'll impress my guest with the most expensive quesadilla. it helps.

pretty much, i give 5 stars for my every single visit. good job.
author: krys s.

description:
Hell yeah! Everything I hoped for from the Mission District during our May 2010 trip.

Meaty, juicy, cheesy joy wrapped in a tortilla. My west-coast burrito craving was sated (for the night anyway). A taco al pastor from the right-inside-the-door cart to finish off.

I could have happily eaten my way right down the menu here.
author: Mike R.

description: This is my go to Mexican restaurant in the Mission. When friends are in from out-of-town and want a flavor of the Mission they hear so much about, this is the only place I go and everyone raves about it. Their Al Pastor burritos have generous portions of tasty meat, oozing with flavor. Alambres are also great, as long as you don't mind a triple bypass afterward. All of the salsas, especially those from the taco bar add a depth of flavors. I haven't yet tried their tacos but can't wait to next time I'm in. The only complaint I have (and this happens to me with all good taquerias in the Mission) is that it feels like I have a rock in my stomach several hours after leaving.
author: Ben S.

description: Greasy floors, greasy walls, and greasy food.  Possibly the best tacos I have ever had in my entire life. Even broke as a joke I can get a taco from these guys for a $1.50. I have tried other things in the place and they all are great but the chicken tacos are as close to perfection as you can get. I also love the murals with broken English translations and some questionable stories. Apparently the artist had a bit of trouble painting feet since most of the figures are lacking them. They are open super late so if you are a post cocktail zombie you can hit them up to at least 1 am.
author: Atom H.

description: Shrimp burrito, chicken wet burrito and a bottle of water for about $16. This ended up being a pretty good deal because one burrito was more than I could eat. Did I mention they both were delicious? Especially the wet burrito, which ended up being bigger than my head. I don't live in the area but I can see myself stopping by here again.
author: Nate A.

description: BEST taqueria I've ever been to in the city.  I strolled in here in a hurry to grab a simple breakfast burrito and ordered a rancheros breakfast thinking it was off the burrito menu.  One of the best mistakes of my life: eggs were done perfectly, the beans were delicious and not watered down by the rice (which was also good), and great tortillas.  Naturally, I had to go back there for lunch and try the tacos.  Best tacos I've had in SF.  Simple street tacos with your choice of a bunch of meats, great salsas, and you choice of other authentic delicious Mexican tidbits like sodas, agua frescas, and popsicles.  Keep in mind, this is a taqueria so don't expect table service, or that you'll be eating in a sterile environment.  I have been to the mountaintop and the view is DELICIOUS.
author: Kevin E.

description:
Vallarta is one of my favorite taqueria's in SF. I first found it years ago on a Friday night.  I was having a great conversation with a friend late on a Friday night.  We saw the taco cart outside, folks were crowded around.  We went in a had the best carne asada tacos ever! Since then I often stop by with friends on a late night.  But I even took my in-laws from Virginia there on a Sunday afternoon.  They loved it too.  I was just there yesterday with my two sons.  Great stuff.  Excellent prices. 

The only thing I don't like is that they charge less for cash, than credit.  I hardly carry cash with me.  Bummer that we're penalized for using a card.
author: David L.

description:
tacos made at the outside stand (though have not seen that open recently) are the best in the city - and some of the best i have had - aside from home made.  But inside the food is still good - but not as good as the outside stand.

Just drove by and saw they are closed.  makes me sad.  I like la taqueria and el farrolito (the one on mission has always been better to me than the one on 24th), but this was the best.  :(
author: Greg M.

description:
FINALLY.

I have found my taqueria of choice in San Francisco.  Or for that matter, all of Northern California.  

A dear friend who has also known the goodness and reasonable prices of San Diego taquerias dragged me here last week, and her assessment of Taqueria Vallarta's quality was dead-on.

Be prepared to watch me pack on 10 pounds due to late-night taco consumption.
author: Sara B.

description: Didn't think it was anything great. Maybe the daytime taco dude isn't up to par with the late night t. dude.  Or maybe people are drunk & hungry.  I do like $1.50 a taco!!!
author: Ramon L.

description: For being in the Mission District, I expected something better. I ordered carne asada y camarones. The carne asada was ok, nothing great, on the small portion side. The camarones were over grilled and dry. The beans were watered down and spread over the plate to make them look like there was a bunch.  The rice was bland and placed in between the asada and beans, almost hidden by the watered down beans. The dish had a grilled green onions that were too over grilled. The salsa was watered down and not hot at all, disgraceful. The lady behind the counter was rather rude and indifferent about the service. There are so many better choices around the Mission District to settle for this place.
author: Tony N.

description: I always get the tacos and they are always delicious. Best I've had outside of Mexico. At a 1.50 a pop they can't be beat.
author: Sam C.

description:
On my way to La Palma because of their 4.5 star review on yelp, I seen this place on the way, and I asked some dude if it was good and he said the tacos are amazing.  I went a couple blocks down and La Palma was closed, so I headed back.   I got in the pretty big line at around 8 pm on Sunday night.  There were some really hott chola chics that arrived and were surrounding me looking at the grill in front of us.  Everyone was really excited ;) lol  anywayz ya so its a grill right as u walk in and there is a big circle grill and the guy jus throws on tacos and you order right there its kinda different and convenient all the condiments are right there in front which is kind of weird when ur reaching for salsa and the people in line are blocking you, kinda a cramed experience but not too bad when ur reaching for cilantre between Salina, and Shakira and they are flirting with you.   Just reminds me of how stuck up and fake a lot of American girls are.
I got 2 steak and 2 chicken tacos.  The chicken was A+ amazing!!! The carne was about an A  minus the grease, maybe I got the meat ont he bottom that had all the juice, it was real good but a little much of a grease overload.  I will go back any time im in this area and go here again, really good tacos!!!  They are $1.50 each, peace
author: Chris B.

description:
To date, this is the best place I've been to for street-style Mexican food in the Mission. Those of you who side with other places-step aside, you clumsy drunks-you have no idea what you're talking about!

The taco stand in the front is just like what I knew from south of the border, with the large metal pan shaped like an oversize sailor's hat to cook the meat in the middle, while the juices trickle to the sides and simmer the onions and other bits of things. The tacos al pastor are great, the chips are decent, the burritos are really good depending on who's wrapping them, and the flavored aguas are also pretty solid.  

I would go not during the 7pm rush--go later, because they try to cook too much on the pan and things get soupy--you want that seared taste.  This type of food is all about fire and freshness, which makes up for wallet-friendly quality. (No, it's not from Nieman Ranch) Also, if you like hot salsa or spicy guacamole, you should bring your own--their salsas are pretty gentle. Though you might try to ask them if they reserve a special hot sauce on the side, because I bet they do.
author: Angel S.

description: Great for vegetarians like me. Fresh food, open till 2AM on weekends and midnight during the week. Great place to grab a bite if you are hungry late at night. Not foo far from the freeway either. My favorite there is Super Vegetarian Nachos, they make it the way it should be with real cheese. MMMMM!
author: S S.

description: I love this place. People talk about how its dirt and pigeons walk in blah blah! Who cares!! You're not watching the staff pick up the pigeon and throw it on the grill! Do you want me to list the places to eat I've seen pigeons in so that you'll avoid them? They haven't been shut down by the city so obviously it is not a health hazard eating here! Food is bomb and thats all you need to know!
author: Astrid I.

description: Really solid burritos and a great, fresh salsa verde. Perhaps overlooked because of the many other options nearby. Crazy murals all over the walls of what is a very large place.
author: Stuart S.

description:
good, cheap food. the menu is pretty huge, ranging from breakfast to seafood to the usual stuff. the giant combo plates look delicious, quesadilla, grilled shrimp, burrito for 11$. but i couldn't eat it all myself. 

i should have gotten a few tacos instead of a burrito. i got a chimichanga for $7, but it was completely overwhelming. it was jam packed solid with meat, and topped with some sour cream and about half of an avocado. it's odd to me that they serve your food on a thick solid ceramic plate, but give you crappy flimsy knives and forks. the non-topped burritos come wrapped in foil in a plastic bowl. 

to get a veggie burrito "wet", it's about $1.50 more than the regular, which is about $4.50. for vegetarians, they also have a grilled veggie burrito, in addition to the regular beans, rice and cheese version. 

in addition to a bunch of bottled drinks, they had 3 kinds of aguas frescas, cantaloupe, pina and horchata. there are 2 salsa bars, one next to the register, one in front of the guy making tacos just inside the door. there is also a second entryway, which has a woman manning a giant steamer of tamales, as well as some other giant jug, maybe a drink? she was sporting the classic early nineties look of no lipstick, with brown eyeliner as lipliner. 

adding to the ambiance was some really random, low-quality murals. the walls and the ceiling are covered in various scenes. a bunch of tents? jesus holding a cross, a bunch of carnival-style dancers, etc etc. there's even a scroll printed with some really weird sentiment: "the 49ers football team has the agility of a tiger, the strength of a bear..." some shit like that.

you order at the counter, but they will bring it out to you in the separate dining room, if you are eating in.
author: Anna S.

description: $1.50 carne asada taco???? hell yes! if you are planning an alcoholic escapade make sure to stop by Vallarta over the course of your journey. Good tacos and they're open late. If they made guacamole i would've given them atleast 4stars.
author: Luis J.

description: Best tacos ever! Randomly yelped this place on the way back from a niners game.  Thank you yelp! At first the taco stand looked questionable but they were seriously the best tacos I ever had.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Elena L.

description: Hands down my favorite taco spot in SF.  Can't really speak about any other menu item as I only go here for the tacos and as much as I want to experiment with other menu items, I just can't seem to stray from the tacos....go with the carne asada tacos and I guarantee you'll be back again!
author: sohail s.

description: tacos for $1.50 each? you can't do better than that! My friend took me hear and I scarfed down so many. Very satisfying!
author: Jennah F.

description: This place is becoming my regular Sunday burrito day joint. I love, love, love their regular veggie burrito. Filled with rice, beans, salsa, a lil cheese, avocado and sour cream. Mmmmm, mmmmm good. Cheap too......about 5 dolla. It's worth my trip to the mission.
author: Kelley D.

description: Buche, suadero, lengua, cabeza y campechano. Repeat
author: Dario B.

description: Best Tacos in SF, hands down.  How do I know?  They are inexpensive, fresh, and they do not offer sour cream or guac.
author: Bryan H.

description: This review is strictly for their tacos, I cannot speak for other foods they serve there.  It is simply THE BEST taco in the Mission!!!!  $1.50 each, what more can you ask for!  My favorite is lengua and tripa, sooooooo good!
author: Candy C.

description: Best carnitas burrito of your life. Hands down. End of story.
author: Arden R.

description: Look no further, this is the best Mexican food in San Francisco. First of all, I was born and bred in San Diego where the best Mexican food outside of Mexico can be found. Yes, I'm one of those stuck-up socal kids that act like their Mexican food is the shit. But that should just go to show, if I'm that sure of myself, then Vallarta really is that amazing. The menu is huge, the prices are very cheap, they stay open late, the service is friendly and fast, they have a taco stand at the front, and the food is very fresh and delicious. Really, what more can you ask? If you don't believe me, go and prove me wrong.
author: Anthony C.

description: I have determined that the $1.50 tacos they have at their stand in front are the best tacos that you can get in San Francisco.  You don't even need to order anything at their regular counter.  Just get a bunch of tacos.  And don't just get the regular meats, try all of the different weird ones because they are awesome.  My favorite is the cabeza.
author: Jon N.

description:
Me Gusta!

I ended up moving in across the street from this joint after sampling their food last March. One taste was all it took, and I'm still a fan eating mexican most days of the week as I frequent Vallartas often.  Being from San Diego, my taste for quality mexican food is distinguished and this place is one of few in SF that meets those standards. 

Dos pulgares arriba!
author: Esteban R.

description:
very cheap prices
yuck...watered down horchata
burrito was aite
author: stevie b.

description: what a solid place.  messy as anything cheap tacos that you pick up by the door, especially when you heap on   pico de gallo and salsa.  they came with a small pile of caramelized onions to the side that melted in my mouth.  I'll be back for more tacos and to try out their plated dishes!!
author: Rachel M.

description: I think I may have just had the best taco of my life. (So far.) I've been meaning to try this place for years, and tonight I joined the line coming out the front door--and I'm so glad I did. Two of the juiciest, sweetest carnitas tacos I've ever tasted. Grilled onions, perfect. And I'm out a whopping three bucks, plus one for the tip jar.
author: Jamey M.

description: Good tacos - I tried the vegetarian ones, but the meat ones looked really good. I suppose if you see natives eating dinner there, it must be quite authentic! Interesting decor - didn't feel like I was in San Francisco at all.
author: Shweta V.

description:
I went to Taqueria Vallarta last week to experience "the best tacos in San Francisco" according to a friend I made at Burning Man.  Taking my roomie, gf, and two other burners; we made the surprisingly short walk from 24th Street BART station to the Taqueria.  Another yelper mentioned the numerous health code violations, which made me weary, but according to my friends ... "This looks a lot different than before ... its too clean in here."  I felt relief.

There are three separate food counters here ... one for tacos, tamales, and the final for all types of food complete (and many types of meat; the carnivore in my was delighted).  After waiting ten minutes for my order of nachos and my gf's burrito, I started to get pissed and accosted the cashier (my pals had already finished most of theirs).   Turns out they lost my order (there were only four other groups at the restaurant) and with many apologizes, she rushed to have them prepared.  Normally this would doom the place in my eyes, except, magically my nachos transformed into super nachos and my gfs burrito was seriously upgraded with disturbing amounts of sour cream.  Mistakes happen and I'm glad they were willing to make us happy and admit their error.

Four stars because the TV is the backgrounds was a little loud and despite a rockin' chimichanga and chicken enchiladas, my other pals grub was kinda crappy.
author: Justin T.

description: Nowhere else in SF have I found a taco stand INSIDE of a tacqueria. It's like a Russian doll, but it's Mexican and tastes better. Fortunately the stand is right by the entrance, which is convenient because you need go no further than The Wheel of Meat. Now I don't speak much Spanish, but neither should you - just tell the guy "uno de cada" and he will lace you up. I have never had such a tasty taco in my life. What really puts these over the top is the onions which sautee in the juices from half a dozen different meats all day. Toss these in each of your tacos and they will explode in your mouth with meaty goodness like some kind of magical carniceria-inspired Starburst. Chase it down with an aqua fresca - the horchata is retarded - and you might as well clock on out, because life will not get any better for you my friend.
author: Dil D.

description:
I went trolling for murals in the Mission this weekend, and passed this taqueria with enticing aromas POURING from its open doors. After walking aimlessly for a while checking out the other options, I decided this was the place I wanted to eat. The mural filled (albeit not the best murals) dining area with pigeons running around like bus boys cleaning up the floor made for great atmosphere. In Hawaii, pigeons running around cleaning up after you is perfectly normal, except these pigeons were much more polite, so I was very pleased and felt right at home.

I ordered the carnitas which was PERFECTLY prepared. I wasn't a big fan of the beans, but they grew on me a bit. I've had enough bad experiences with taqueria seafood to be steered clear of trying that again, but one of my friends ordered the seviche, and another got the "San Francisco," an all seafood platter. I tried the seviche, and it was surprisingly good, certainly not food poisoning. The girl with the seafood platter however said her fish tasted "unfresh" and didn't finish it. I know she's a picky eater, and since I didn't try it personally I'm only rating this place for the carnitas and seviche. Good job!

Also, the lady who took our order spoke very good English, which was a plus :)
author: James Y.

description:
good foodie vibe here, taco stand
tacos are tasty, and for only $1.50
even though the soft tortillas were not made by hand, the meats were delicious, and they had the fresh lime, onion, cilantro, and red/green salsas available, plus some sauteed onions
the oils of the meats nicely heating the tortillas
had the al pastor (marinated with the right amount of pineapple flavor), carne asada, pollo asado
selection is good, like what you'd expect from a taco stand
sometimes the al pastor here is not consistent though (too much pineapple, or too mild)
the lime onion cilantro green salsa tacos are good (sometimes they don't chop the cilantro fine enough)
this is the style i like, and top it off with some pina agua fresca
sometimes the carne asada chunks are too big
have you tried cabeza?
price gone up to $1.75
author: Rob C.

description:
This is the best taco place in the mission!  Variety, price, authenticity!
Their melon aqua fresca, 2 tacos al pastor and 1 carnitas...then on to Humphries ice cream
author: marc m.

description:
the taco bar at the entrance. it was so good i fell on my hands and knees and wept. my journey has ended.

1.50 for greasy goodness wrapped in a corn tortilla. HIGHLY recommended. lots of seating. enjoy.
author: David B.

description:
one of my two favorite burrito haunts.

they got great tacos, and I like the suadero.
one o the only places you can find it.

Aqua Frescas $1.50
taco $1.50
author: Asa D.

description: I was lucky  to work close enough to walk here everyday.  They got so familiar with me, I did not even have to ask for what i wanted to order, which is the simple pinto bean and cheese burrito, or like they say in Tucson...Burro, after all it is big enough.  They always charge $2.30 for this simple, yet delightful lunch and are happy to give extra chips.I love the salsa (I like it  super hot and runny baby!)
author: Mai G.

description: It was late and we were hungry travelers last week.  The tacos were amazing!  Fresh and tasty.  We had "al pastor."  Ymmm.
author: Rachele F.

description: Taco and Roll Tonight!   Punk Rock and Mexican Food Galore....
author: Norm P.

description:
this used to be my favorite burrito place, but the last few times i've been there, they weren't very consistent, and not fantastic. worth a try, though, because when they're good, they're REALLY girthy, fun-filled, and succulent.

taco stand is always a winner. 5+ types of meat, always fresh, always hot, always juicy. and $1.50 each.
author: Pris C.

description:
Hey, has anyone read the city's health inspection of this place?  Vallarta got a 49, and it's a riot: rodents, cockroaches, the works.


http://www.dph.sf.ca.us/eh/Violations/FrameCurrentViol.asp?LocationID=2429
author: Jeff B.

description: These tacos are great. This place is just the right level of diviness -- crazy murals all over the walls with hysterical spanglish, bright colored everything, kinda gruby, but the food is being served in high volume and the kitchen looks clean. I can't say we have tried much beyond the tacos - but they are as good as they get. There is literally a taco cart with a comal (the funny upside down wok thingy for cooking the meat/keeping it hot) at the front door. Tacos are a buck fifty, and loaded with meat. And, they have 6 different kinds of fresh salsa and all the other goodies. We drive accross town for these tacos. Very rewarding.
author: Katie K.

description: Without a doubt, the best burritos in the Mission. And might I add, their late night hours make them the best post-dive-bar spot in the city. Nothing like a veggie burrito to cure a Pop's hangover!
author: Elizabeth L.

description: This is the first meal I had in San Francisco as an actual resident. Maybe I'm biased because of that fact, but I doubt it. This is honestly my favorite taqueria in this city. One of my best friends and I are always on the hunt for the place with the best enchiladas sauce and this is it. They also take cards.
author: Matt P.

description: I mostly come for the tacos because I'm not much of a burrito girl, but lately I haven't seen their outdoor taco set-up like I normally do at night. The only thing I can think of is that it's some kind of outdoor street violation and they were called on it, it's a shame I liked ordering the tacos outside. Oh well the prices are right on, three bucks gets you two tacos with your choice of meat and salsa, some lime, and cilatro. The meat is always juicy and available late at night.
author: X marks the spot ..

description: BEST TACOS EVER!!!! Thats it thats all to say about this joint ;)
author: Carlos H.

description: I liked Taqueria Vallarta better before they shut down.  I just went here for the first time since they reopened and I wasn't thrilled.  I ordered my usual al pastor burrito and for possibly the first time in my life, I did not finish it.  First of all, it simply did not taste very good, but when I bit into some little piece of bone or something, I really lost my appetite for it.  There are WAY better burritos to be found on 24th St.
author: Sara H.

description: It's been many years since Ive been here in the daylight hours (hey, it happens) but this is the perfect spot for the late night taco. Last time I went there i was with a couple of girlfriends, drunk and hungry. Jessica convinced me to order the al pastor tacos (I rarely order pork), and i dont believe I'll be able to ever order anything differently again. This place has converted me to the Pig.
author: Mollie M.

description: I hope one day all of San Francisco can recognize that Vallarta is home to the best tacos this side of California.  But let us not forget that their vegetarian burritos are also amazing.
author: Amy L.

description: An excellent find...this is one of the best Mexican restaurants in the Mission. You know it is authentic when they have a spicy camarones diablo. The only problem with this establishment is that they do not serve beer.
author: Cameron K.

description:
I'm re-doing this entire review. Somehow, this place is moving from a FULL FIVE STARS to ONE (I wish I could give them NONE, at this point) over the course of a few months.

The service here SUCKS. When I first started coming here, the lady that worked was awesome. Since then, a dumber-than-bricks girl with heavy, dark, unmatching lip-liner has taken control....and she ALWAYS GETS IT WRONG.

My first run-in with her: "Can I have vegetarians super nachos, without cheese?"

"Uh, *something to the back*, uh, yeah."

Then nothing. She doesn't ring them up; just stares blankly. I watch her write the ticket to go (even though I asked to dine-in). The nachos come with cheese; luckily, I'm okay with that.

Second time: I go in, ask for my usual (yes, I went here a lot): a veggie taco with no cheese. It's ALWAYS $1.90, and somehow she manages to make the total $2.14. I tell her that's wrong as I'm a regular here. She tells me that "no, that's right." All I brought was $2 with me because I've been here THAT MUCH. After I tell her (again) she's wrong, she checked with someone and they okay it. She rings it up and walks away. No chips! She omitted my chips! I always get chips. So, I wait, ask for chips, and she practically throws them at me. She brings out my taco, and the avocado and sour cream that I come for are completely gone from the taco. In fact, it's just beans and lettuce...not even any rice....and it sucked. There was no flavor. UGH, what happened to the tacos I loved!?!?

Last night: I decided to give them one last shot. I come in wanting a burrito, so I decided to try the BURRITO GRILL they have advertised on a hand-written sign above the register. It says it's $4.25 for a regular and $5.50 for a super. I ask for the regular with no cheese and black beans. She rings up $4.30 for the burrito (ugh, that thick?) and the total comes to $4.87. I have my debit card, and she says, "Do you want anything to drink?" and I say, "no" and she says it has to be a $5 minimum. I ask if I can just tip her, and she says, "$5 minimum." Okay, fine...I made it a SUPER burrito. I watch her change the ticket. She rings it up, the total becoming $5.97. I tip three cents on the card and throw some change into the tip jar. She smiles and thanks me. My burrito is done in less than 5 minutes and I take it home. !&@%^#*@^#&*@&# It's a REGULAR burrito. There is NO sour cream or avocado to be found in this thing. OH, and to top it off: I checked my bank statement later on, and they charge me $7.68 for the thing. ISN'T THAT ILLEGAL!??! 

I will NEVER go back. It's a shame, because I really was the definition of a regular. My first review for them on here was beautiful. Five stars. Then, the service went to hell. 

Don't go.

They don't care about customers at all. And let it stay that way...their food's crappy anyway.
author: Danyell K.

description: 2 words: taco bar.  Their al pastor tacos were so good that after having 4, I went back and got 2 more.  And, I was still jonesing for them an hour later.  As Arnold once said, "I'll be baaaaauuuuck."
author: Tim G.

description: The best tacos anywhere. Never too dry or mushy. Very cheap and delicious. They always have a cart outside the taqueria, perfect for late night cravings or pre bar hopping food..
author: joan l.

description: reminiscence of tacos el gordo in chula vista, ca....similar to san diego y tijuana style tacos...menu hanging at entrance....cheek, brain, tongue, al pastor, carnitas, carne asada, etc...amigo grilling meats, soft taco rounds and onions...sizzling hot and amigo with paper plate in hand to serve...placing of two small soft taco tortillas...generous tossing of meat over the two layers of tortillas....juices flowing and dripping....grilled onions by request....self serve squeeze of lemon or lime, sprinkle of cilantro , and a scoop of salsa...perfection!....no beans! no rice! no cheese! no tomato! no lettuce! no fillers!...simple meat taco excellence!...cheap $one.fifty even tacos each....two tortilla required to handle meat and "au jus"...flavorful and tasty....seating plenty to enjoy small tacos....mention vallarta serving regular mexican platters and burritos past taco station....a corn sprinkled with spice and cheese cart by second entrance also....good mix of options for this dive taqueria....
author: Hen A.

description: I love, love, love, love the tacos from here. I make special trips when I am in the mood for tacos only at this spot! For only  $1.50 per taco, you can't beat that and there soooo good! Just walk right in and they will take your order and make them right there on the spot, and don't forget to ask for grilled onions they have a self serve counter in front of ordering that include cilantro, onions, limes, and red or green chile. My last few trips I have been lucky enough to beat the crowd, by the time I am sitting down and enjoying my tacos the line is already out the door.
author: Monica O.

description: Tacos from anywhere else strive to be Vallarta's tacos.  Truly authentic.  One shy away from 5 stars. Reason?  the other menu items.  Stick with their tacos...from the taco stand.  There is no other way.  My mouth is watering...and i just ate!
author: Adrian N.

description: They take credit cards! The burritos are delic and the super quesadilla is intense.
author: Anita C.

description: The idea of having a taco bar by the front door is refreshing. Cheap, good and efficient.
author: Brock L.

description:
The absolute best deal around.  Period.

Argue if you like, but it'll fall upon deaf ears.

Lengua all the way.  The taco's are the absolute best!!!!!  Late Friday or Saturday, great.  Dinner time during the week, great!  

Parking is not really ever a problem.
author: james b.

description: The price is ok, not cheap but they give you good size portions. Food is pretty tasty. I like it. Would go back again.
author: Dijon Y.

description: Brent's Taco Test - Buy 3 Taco's see if you can finish them. For good tacos 3 will be enough, and you will walk out feeling fed. For great tacos, you will look up at your friend say "DAMN!" and go order two more. I think I ate 5 or 6 tacos last time I was there... they are great. The grilled onions are a must, and oh, order from the guy at the front, I haven't tried the food from the main restaurant, but there is a guy at the front who serves the tacos out of what Jack B referred to as "The Wheel of Meat" you wont be disappointed.
author: Brent F.

description: As I walked by the umpteenth taqueria in the mission two things caught my eye - (1) the fact that they have a separate cooking station devoted entirely to tacos and (2) wait, lamb stew tacos?  They were indeed fabulous - tender, juicy, not at all gamey.  Plus they provide a selection of self-serve toppings and sauces.  All for $1.75 per hit.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
this is my favorite of ALL mission taquerias.

sit in the back area. theres AWESOME murals all over the place. they will bend your mind. miners, 49ers vs real dolphins, santana, saints, a yellow brick road, visual perspective on whack.

i suggest getting the all meat burrito. according to my cousin who is from san diego, this is how mexican burritos are. not actually all meat, it is meat, cheese, nice avocado slices, pico de gallo, sauteed lettuce, a lil cilantro. no rice, beans, sour cream, or guacamole. get extra napkins because the juices from the pico de gallo collect on the bottom!

if you are a vegetarian, i suggest the burrito grill. this is like the salvadorean burritos from where i grew up. zucchini and carrots and all types of great vegetables, and always really warm and savory.

they make a good torta. all their meats are done very well, i especially like the pastor. free good good warm fresh oily tortilla chips. full condiment bar. super friendly staff. they have a pretty damn nice bathroom for a mission taqueria, plenty of seating, fast service, they bring your food to you so you dont have to stand around waiting, and CHEEP to boot! of course, it is also a much much more relaxed atmosphere than some taqueria on 16th and mission.

im actually not that big on tacos, but their taco desk is VERY VERY popular.

FYI, everything thing they make has HELLA cheese on it, especially the burrito grill, more than i can take
author: drew e.

description:
Vallarta might as well be my second home. The taco bar is freaking amazing! So many delicious kinds of meat, tortillas grilled to order on a rounded comal (the sexiest of cooking implements for sure), as much onion/cilantro/salsa, among other fixins, as you want or can stand, mmmmm. My go-to order: two carnitas (soooo juicy and good!) and one lengua, all smothered in raw onions and absolutely dripping in lime juice. Always always always excellent.
Aaaand they're open late! The best tacos in SF, a city which rolls up its sidewalks depressingly early at 10pm, are available until at least one in the morning. I have no idea what Vallarta's hours actually are, since whenever I need my taco fix, they seem to be open and waiting for me! I don't think they're 24/7, but it seems to be pretty close. Did I mention the awesome price? $1.75 per delicious taco. As your typical broke college student, this place is right up my alley. (By the way, take a stroll down Balmy Alley, the mini-street on the east side of Vallarta, and check out the awesome murals.)
I've never even gotten to their menu, the taco bar always derails me, but having stolen bites of friends' burritos... go for the seafood! The shrimp in a creamy, mildly spicy (but oh how it builds over time) sauce with all your usual Mission burrito goodness has almost drawn me away from my taco bar-loving ways.
Oh, and I know this isn't Vallarta-specific, but if you're not grabbing a beer from the cold case, shove a lime wedge in a bottle of Sangria Senorial, a carbonated, non-alcoholic sangria, for the perfect accompaniment to your meal. It's such an overlooked drink in the face of Jarritos and it deserves a lot more love.
Yeah, this has turned into a total rave, and I know every San Franciscan has their favorite taqueria, but if Vallarta's tacos don't steal your heart, then I'm afraid you might not have one.
author: Juliette J.

description: T-t-t-t-take me to the Taco Bar! Delicious $1.50 tacos.  BYOB- if you are discrete they will look the other way.  I could have eaten 10 of the tacos.  Perfect spicy grease on the chicken and warm corn tortillas.  Salsa verde is yummy.  The place to go on your way home after a night out.
author: Jones D.

description: The cow head, cow tongue and cow intestine tacos are da bomb.  It's only $1.50 each too...
author: Tony C.

description: came here around 11 after a night of drinking for some awesome tacos. when you first walk in the taco guy is grilling up the meat and warming up tortillas right there. order whatever you want for only $1.50 a taco. put whatever u want on them and then pay. i myself decided to sample a chicken, carne asada and a carnitas taco. the meat, salsa and all the condiments are fresh. the decor of the area was quite odd with paintings all over of the walls and ceilings of SF. nice to look at while u're dining. i dont know about the other food but im definitely coming back for late night tacos.
author: edward k.

description: Hands down, the best taqueria I know in the Mission; also one of the more authentic ones. REALLY cheap too ($4.25 for a veg. burrito anyone?). Fairly spicy burritos, the enchiladas are a bit too greasy and salty for me. Actually, the place is a little greasy too, but I don't mind so long as the burritos remain that good (and cheap).
author: Alexander G.

description: OK, I'm just addicted to this place. So simple, and so perfect ...especially at 3 a.m. They are one of the few places I've seen that does carnitas right, and they even got me liking lengua! Even if I've had dinner, I'll stop off there after a night of festivities and grab a couple of tacos to gorge on while while watching late night TV before bed. The greatest thing is you're usually in and out in 5 minutes!
author: Phillip D.

description:
craving for some tacos at 2am?  no taco trucks around?  then come to taqueria vallarta... they've got a taco stand right outside the restaurant and serves up various meat tacos until 3 something in the morning i hear...
