i've had their carne asada tacos a few times and they're pretty scrumptious past midnight :)
one time this person came by and tried selling us this broken toy...
author: charlotte s.

description:
Good
- "THE WHEEL OF MEAT" -- there's a taco cart INSIDE of the restaurant!  It's got a metal wheel on it, split into sections with different kinds of meat.  Need I say more?
- Hip, cheek and al pastor tacos from The Wheel of Meat
- The salsas on the taco cart
author: Anthony W.

description: Stopped here after going to a art show down the street.  We were looking for some really good tacos and saw this place, I just can't resist $1.50 tacos sold at the front of a store that looks like it came straight out of Mexico.  Be sure that you know spanish or you might end up ordering mystery meat, but I am sure that it will be the tastiest mystery meat you have ever had!  The tacos are real tacos, meat a little salsa and some onions, they have radishes and cilantro with different sauces but don't go expecting sour cream, cheese and the works.  Best tacos ever.
author: annie c.

description: Open late and their /grilled/ veggie burrito is something I simply crave from time to time.  Helps if you know some Spanish, as most of the workers only know some English.  Also, they certainly don't have a veggie section of the grill. :/  The burrito's delish, though!
author: Susan L.

description:
never knew the name until now, just realized that i went there last year

the tacos are made right in front of you on the small stand out front, which you really don't get anywhere else except in mexico

head inside and eat up, drink a jarritos, and pretend you're in TJ
author: Charles C.

description: Super burrito, carnitas, tasty. They even shooed the pigeons away from the kitchen before we placed our order.
author: Rob T.

description: I love this spot.  They are open late and serve the greatest tacos. But are they closed or what. The last couple of times I went there they were closed.  =(
author: linda h.

description: This place was closed for a long time and I had missed it dearly.  It has the world's best green salsa, great super nachos, big TVs with soccer or telenovelas on, a jukebox that was crazy way too loud and comes on randomly, fresh cheap-ass tacos on the sidewalk, and often stays open after bar time.  It isn't the most hygenic taqueria, even compared to other ones, even though it usually smells like cleaning products.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Maybe the best burritos/tacos in the mission. Too bad they don't have hard tacos... enjoy giving your change to the drunk bums harassing you.

And remember to try the lamb tacos. I forget what they call it Spanish but I asked for whatever the tacoman suggested and he uncovered a little plate to the side with the HIDDEN MEAT. It did have a pointy little bone in it, but was amazing.
author: blimp w.

description:
Veggie tacos. Two tortillas, whole beans, cheese, lettuce, avocado, sour cream, pico de gallo. You need to order the veggie tacos at the register - they don't have any by the door. 

Tacos were pretty good - reminded me of El Farolito but less cheesy. Not as good as El Metate but a lot cheaper.

The TV was loud, there were homeless people with cuts all over there face and people were cutting in line but food came out quickly, tasted good and was about 1/2 the cost of Pancho Villa.
author: Sarah J.

description: It sure does feel like you re in Tijuana when you eat here but the price is right and the food is too.  Of course it is not the cleanest place, like Tijuana but the food works and the price is unbelievable...outside every night there is the taco stand and if you want the corn soaked in cheese, butter, etc. it is available....just eat it....I have yet to try it...but it looks yummy....remember or pretend you are in Tijuana and nothing will bother you....not even the jukebox
author: Tamara M.

description:
we ordered two tacos al pastor + super nachos and my friend k ordered a wet vegetarian burrito. the tacos were a bit on the greasy side and not as good as the ones from our el farolito experience. the nachos were ridiculously loaded - i think imposing a requirement on nachos such that at least some of the chips are still crispy is not entirely unreasonable (although in the end, we did discover a little pocket of crispiness - a trojan horse as k put it - but by then, it was too late for we were already defeated). again, i preferred the nachos at el farolito. k's burrito was very tasty and smothered with sauce. 

despite the nachos beatdown, we will still go back to this place for the as-close-to-mexico-as-you-can-get-in-sf atmosphere (e.g. telenovelas on the big screen tv, all-latino-music-all-the-time jukebox, little taco stand set up on the sidewalk) and the tostada de ceviche, which we didn't order this time.

UPDATE 1/2008:
reopened after a few months of remodeling, nothing really changed all that much except the taco stand has moved to just inside the front doors. did you know they have cachete tacos (beef cheeks) that are amazing?? i defy you to find meat more tender than that - it literally melts in your mouth and no, it's not because it's all fat. that'd be gross.
author: Angi C.

description:
How did this place get so many stars by so many reviewers?!?!?!?

I gave it 3 stars because really, people, this place is only good for the tacos.  The pastor super burrito was bland and totally boring.  Add a bunch of salsa from the salsa bar and it was passable.  The pollo tacos were awesome.  We also had the carne asada plate which tasted pretty good (saving grace were the green onions drenched and fried in butter).  $16.xx for the plate, super burrito, and two tacos.

You order tacos up front then pay for them in the back, but get everything else from the back... very confusing.  Not enjoyable either were the spanish-speaking men who were eyeing me and trying to flirt with me (a blue-eyed white girl) when they figured out I have a pretty darn good spanish accent when I'm ordering mi comida. yuck.  But no fault of the taqueria!

NOTE: all their meat is cooked in butter.  A no-go for my kidlet with a milk allergy!  :(  boo.
author: Kimberly C.

description: I've been coming here for years and I still love this spot.  The burritos can be hit or miss but the tacos are cheap, fatty, and delicious.  Also they're open late and the staff is friendly.
author: Peter F.

description: real f-in' tacos. i'm sure the meat is of incredibly dubious origin, but when you're shitfaced and broke in the wee hours of the morning... this is the place. 1.50 for a taco. and it's authentic; not the usual whitino mexican fare that you can expect at more americanized places. you can get all sorts of cool stuff like head cheese, tongue and brain as well as tamer stuff like asada or al pastor. grub.
author: cyrus t.

description: In my opinion, the best tacos in the city. There's a taco counter right when you walk in. You order from the guy, you add your condiments (onions, cilantro, salsa and make sure you ask for grilled onions) and you pay the cashier. You can't go wrong with this place. The price is right - $$1.50/taco and the variety of meat is delicious - cabeza, lengua, chorizo etc. Definitely my go to spot especially for late night tacos.
author: Lee O.

description: This is by far my favourite tacqueria in the Mission -- the shrimp burrito is absolutely to die for, and unlike many other places (*cough* Papalote's *cough*) is FULL OF SHRIMP.  As it should be.  Other pros: the staff are lovely, the place is always clean, and I am slowly teaching myself Mexican history from the enormous handpainted mural that covers all of the walls and the ceiling.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I'd been waiting for the Watchmen movie for months.

Erik and I had gone out drinking in early February at Pop's and were feeling good, buying round after round of $5 pitchers of Pabst Blue Ribbon, the Mission's official lubricant.  There was no end in sight.  

Pounding them back, I came to she startling realization that Watchmen was only a month away.  Erik immediately whipped out his iPhone and, getting yellow drops of piss water all over it, pulled up his Fandango app.  He bought us both midnight tickets to the IMAX opening, a month in advance.  We were in.  This was already one of the best nights of drinking of the year.  Two more pitchers please.

After a month long hangover, we finally made it to the movie, and it was everything I could have expected.  Now we had another hangover to nurse, the hangover of failed expectations.

I owed Erik dinner for buying the tickets, so we stopped into Taqueria Vallerta, over by Pop's where we had our blacked out Watchmen revelation.  Warming us up instantly, the $1.50 Taco bar was far more satisfing than Zakk Snyder's overblown adaptation, and was far more faithful to the original too (in the taco's case, Mexico).

Yay.  I'm a fan.
author: Brooks R.

description: Taco Bar indeed. My first stop when I moved into this neighborhood was here, and now I've got my roommates hooked as well. I especially enjoy the murals on the ceiling of violence, oppression, and pillaging. Really helps me appreciate the hot meal.
author: Brandy E.

description:
real deal.
taco stand in the doorway, real burritos. drunk or sober, awesome.
author: Cleveland M.

description: Probably the best tacos I've had in San Francisco, and I've tried nearly all the  Mexican places in the Mission.  Reminds me of Mexico City.  Plus they are open very late on the weekends...
author: Jeremiah J.

description: Best tacos in the city! None of that frou frou nonsense--it's all about the meat!
author: Alessandra M.

description: very authentic. helps if you know a little spanish. the chicken tacos are incredible.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Dude, where's my taco?
Taqueria Vallarta!
Mmm biddy biddy num nums!

The above is an almost perfect taku* for an almost perfect taco. I really, really, REALLY wanted to give Taqueria Vallarta a rating of ¡Oh Dios Mios! ^_^, but I couldn't... I just couldn't.

It makes me wonder: can a taco so close to perfection, so damn delicious, really be topped? Is there even such a thing as a perfect taco? I don't know. I just... don't... know!!!#@%@#$^

Okay--so what exactly is it that makes Taqueria Vallarta's tacos so tasty? Is it the pool of greasy goodness that the carne asada swim in? Or is it the taco man's mad taco skillz? Perhaps it's both. But I've done some extensive specimen analysis and self-observational studies and have come to the conclusion that Taqueria Vallarta tacos contain traceable amounts of methylbenzoylecgonine, otherwise known as crack. One should proceed with extreme caution when consuming these tacos, because along with being highly addictive, these tacos are cheap--only $1.50 a hit! The tacos also come from a taco stand placed near the front of the taqueria, thus allowing you to quickly and conveniently pay the dealer then proceed to your fix.

Okay--but seriously--these tacos are legit. Firstly, the meat is quality--just take a couple bites and you'll taste the difference. Along with great quality comes great flavor, and Vallarta fully fills their carne asada with TONS of it. The crack marinade coupled with the grease bath creates a taste to the tongue unparalleled to any taco I've come upon in The Mission thus far. You could almost eat the taco sans salsa roja--but I wouldn't recommend it, for the salsa roja here in unreal.

There's something very unique with what they do to the red sauce. It has this kind of smokey flavor that goes really well with the meat. Try it with just a chip and you'll see what I'm talking about. Please note that on the taco stand, there are three kinds of salsas: the orange one blows; the dark red one should go on the carne asada taco (obvi!); and if you are in the mood to try a pollo asada taco, the green one goes well with it. Also, you can top your taco with as much onion and cilantro as you want. Can't go wrong with that. And don't forget to grab some of the grilled onions. When the tacoman asks, "¿Sea-boy-ah?", you say "Sea!" The grilled onions, along with the radishes, are a damn good addition to the taco. Just try it: take a bite of taco, then immediately take a bite of radish wrapped with the grilled onion--it's biddy biddy num nums!

So if the meat and the salsa roja are so super sabrosa, why did this taco not receive an ¡Oh Dios Mios! ^_^? They FUCKED up the tortillas! God dammit! Vallarta excels in all the difficult areas of taco construction, but they eff up on what I think is the easiest part to master: corn tortillas! It really is a bummer, because like I said, the tacos are almost perfect. Basically, the corn tortillas lack that burst of corn flavor, and the tortillas weren't grilled long enough. The result was that the juice from the carne asada dampens the tortilla and makes for a kind of soft texture. This is a no-no.

But, despite the corn tortilla mishap, the tacos still tasted amazing. Taqueria Vallarta tacos are ¡Que Bueno! :P -- I would come back here in a heartbeat. In fact ::itches tongue erratically:: I needz meh some tacos orita, way!!!

-The Taco Guru



*a taku, pronounced \tä-()kü\, is a haiku tailored towards tacos.

Please note that my rating for Taqueria Vallarta is solely based on the tacos--it is in no way a reflection of the atmosphere or other food that it has to offer. My mission is to review every taqueria based in The Mission. See chapter 1 and 2 of my blog (url located in my profile) for more information about my rating system and the kind of taco I review.
author: Taco G.

description: Cheap, consistently delicious authentic small tacos. They have different varieties of meat and I like the self-serve containers of limes, radishes, onion, cilantro and sauces so you can customize your taco condiments too. I can easily eat 2 even if i'm not hungry. 3 makes a perfect meal. Sweet, sweet football players in the ocean mural with accompanying 49'er legend inside.
author: Aileen T.

description: Found this place after walking down the Mission. I wondered why this place had a line all the way outside the door and onto the sidewalk. So I stood in line and ordered some Carne Asada tacos ... they were soooo good. Loved the salsa selections.  Only bad part was that a few pigeons had wandered into the seating area of the restaurant. I guess they heard about the great food too!  Going to come back soon to try more dishes.
author: Susan T.

description: Yes, this place is a bit of a "dive" if you're unaccustomed to rustic taquerias or prefer antiseptic dining environments, but if what you want is authentic Mexican flavor, this is the spot in The Mission. I started out here with carne asada burritos. I was instantly convinced that they were the best I'd had in the Mission yet ... the meat was even more flavorful than at La Taqueria on Mission, which is famously good as well. As other reviewers have indicated, though, the real star of this restaurant is the barbacoa, which you'll find on the street if the weather is good, or inside if not. I love the lengua y asada tacos from the barbacoa. Amazingly intense flavor, enhanced by the condiments and great salsas provided. As a lifelong San Franciscan, I'm very fond of many of our excellent Mission taquerias. As an ardent Mexiphile, I love this restaurant for its true *Mexicanidad.* Vallarta is one of 24th Street's Latin treasures.
author: Dean E.

description: super good!!!! from the taco bar at night to the tamales and atole plus they open late night , employees are also friendly
author: A C.

description: best cheap tacos in the mission (la taqueria is a little better, but these are only a buck!).  love the cart, feels like a truly mexicano experience!
author: caroline h.

description: Carnitas wasnt any good.  Pollo asado wasnt very good.  Didnt heat up my carnitas it was sitting in the serving vat probably all day then threw it in my burrito.  Plus serving size was misleading.  Didnt throw in much meat it was all filler rice and beans.  Salsas werent very good.  I have been to alot of mexican restaurants in san francisco and this was my least favorite.  That is saying alot because I love mexican food and this was even worse than papalote which doesnt even serve carnitas which is pathetic.  I mean I have probably been to at least 20 different mexican restaurants and taquerias in San Francisco and this one was the worst.
author: christian l.

description: um, this place is on point.  1) late-night  2)$1.50 tacos 3)simple, deliscious and authentic.
author: nzingha s.

description: Great taco for the adventurous.  Very authentic Mexican "street style" taqueria with just about every cut of meat imaginable.  Very tasty.  The tripe tacos were a bit "ripe" for me (maybe just my limits), otherwise delicious.
author: Aaron C.

description: After 2 tacos, your face, neck and shirt will be drenched with grease, and you'll be $3 poorer, and you'll be happy.
author: Brandyn B.

description: I always mention the street tacos here to my friends. They are a must if you are in the mood for some tacos. Look for the outside taco stand in the late afternoon and evenings. They cook it up right in front of you and its cheap too, $1.50 I think. Its a good place to get your feet wet with lengua, tripa, etc. if your tired of the same old carne.
author: David P.

description: this place is the absolute shit. mexico city-style tacos inside, quicker then macdonalds. they pile the meat HIGH. the grilled onions are spectacular. tripas is some of the best i've had recently. yet to be disappointed, and i come here at least 4 times a week. just wish they were open until 3 or something.....
author: Zhenya S.

description: I've been here many times. This review is for the "taco stand" just inside the door (you order separately at it). Inexpensive, tasty, simple tacos with good meat, and you usually get some grilled onions on the side as well.
author: Max D.

description: I suppose the rating depends on what you are looking for. I say anything with as much to offer as this place should be a 5, so I know to check it out. The street tacos (for gringos: the tacos normally cooked in a cart on the street) are the best you're going to find in a couple hundred mile radius. They even have all the great meats to try when you get especially trashed. Cabeza is my personal favorite.
author: Kelly J.

description: My favorite tacos in the city.  About 8-10 varieties of meat to choose from.  I always try different meats... except probably chicken.  Enjoy with a glass of horchata and a side of tortilla chips.  Did try a couple of other items in the menu - didn't find them exceptional.
author: Vajira N.

description: Best Taco's in the city. I can't speak for the burrito's because burrito's are not authentic anyway  If you like real taco's this is the place to go.
author: Mike M.

description: hands down the best place to grab some tacos.Nothing better than simple good tacos at 3am yes a lil dirty inside but whatever i dont ever go in there everything is taken care of outside.
author: Jared V.

description: yum!  you get to put as much onions, cilantro, salsa as you wish on your own tacos!!!  their burrito is hella good too!
author: Yukio W.

description: good tacos -- but DON"T get the chimichanga.  i was in the mood for something gluttinous and got the deep fried burrito.  it came out without any crispness -- the tortilla was still white!  where was the golden hue of a good frying?   that was disappointing.  they basically soaked the burrito in oil but somehow managed to not fry it.  gee thanks -- all those extra calories and none of the tasty rewards.
author: Eddie J.

description: Love this place ... best $1.50 tacos around; love the carne asada, suadero, al pastor, and pollo. Decor is very low key and it helps to order in Spanish.
author: SF P.

description: This place makes the best burritos in the city, in my humble opinion. Their grilled veggie burrito is simply to die for! Last time I tried to stop by I noticed they were closed for rennovations...come back, Vallarta, come back!
author: Jenny Q.

description: this place has the most authentic atmosphere.  it was reccomended to me by the latin staff at another place i used to host.   so i went down there late one night and loved that they were making tacos out on the street.  was good i knew the key words in spanish because its hit or miss whether you get someone who speaks english.  pollo, crema, queso, and you're good to go.  i stopped going there when one night i got home, got comfortable and found chicken bones thru the whole thing.  with the language barrier complaining would have gotten me nowhere, so now i go elsewhere.
author: misskim f.
